text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a strict, unconditional full contributor. They always give the entire endowment to the public fund and never deviate, even as others fluctuate and as their own relative payoff is persistently lower than that of several group members. There is no evidence of conditional cooperation; their behavior does not adjust upward or downward in response to higher or lower average contributions, nor to changes in who is contributing more or less. They appear to hold a strong internal norm that “the right thing” is to fully contribute regardless of what others do, and they tolerate being exploited by lower contributors without reacting in their own contribution choice. Risk tolerance is high in the sense that they persist with full cooperation despite clear information that others free-ride and that this leaves them earning less than others. Fairness norms seem to be internally driven rather than reciprocal: they behave fairly (by contributing fully) but do not condition on whether the environment is fair to them.

<PUNISHMENT>
They never use punishment at all, despite repeated and salient opportunities and despite the presence of clear low contributors and a powerful, high-leverage punishment technology. They also see other players frequently using punishment (in particular against a chronically low-contributing target), yet they neither join in nor imitate this behavior. This suggests a very high threshold for punishing; either they avoid harming others on principle, or they reject the cost of sanctioning as an acceptable tool, even when it would be efficient or group-beneficial. There is no sign of retaliatory punishment, as they are never punished themselves and never punish in return. There is also no sign of using punishment strategically for deterrence or norm enforcement; they do not appear to try to shape others’ contributions through negative incentives. Overall, they present as a non-punisher with strong reluctance to impose costs on others, even on clear free riders.

<RESPONSE_TO_PUNISHER>
Unknown. They are never the target of punishment, so there is no evidence of how they respond when punished or how they treat identifiable punishers afterward. Their tendencies toward unconditional cooperation and non-punishment suggest, with low confidence, that they would be unlikely to retaliate and might either ignore punishment or possibly interpret it as information rather than a provocation, but this is speculative.

<REWARD>
They never use rewards, despite the mechanism being clearly explained and despite visible examples of others using positive rewards. They do not reward either high contributors who match their own behavior or players who reward them. This indicates that they do not engage in explicit positive reinforcement, alliance signaling, or gratitude expression through the reward tool. Given that they already cooperate maximally without conditioning on others, they may see rewarding as unnecessary, too costly, or outside their preferred way of interacting. Their cooperativeness is “silent”: they help the group through contributions but do not invest extra resources to shape or encourage others’ behavior via rewards.

<RESPONSE_TO_REWARDER>
They receive rewards several times from specific co-players, but they never reciprocate with rewards of their own and they do not alter their contribution behavior, which is already at the maximum. There is no observable attempt to form a mutual-reward alliance or to differentially favor those who reward them versus those who do not. Their gratitude, if present, is not expressed through the available mechanisms. This suggests a style where they maintain their own cooperative standard independently of social approval or side payments, and do not translate being rewarded into explicit reciprocity via the reward tool. Whether they feel gratitude internally is unknown; behaviorally, they remain unchanged and non-reciprocal with respect to rewards.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
They repeatedly observe that some players contribute less while earning higher payoffs and sometimes also face heavy punishment from others. Despite this clear evidence of free-riding, payoff inequality, and active sanctioning norms in the group, they neither adjust their own contributions nor participate in enforcement. They tolerate being a consistent net contributor who often earns less than others without any visible attempt to protect themselves or to pressure laggards. They similarly observe positive rewards flowing among others (and to themselves at times) without changing their behavior. Overall, they appear largely indifferent, in terms of strategic adjustment, to others’ payoffs, to how much others spend on punishment or reward, and to who is targeted. Their primary reference point seems to be their own internal rule to fully cooperate, not the evolving distribution of costs and benefits in the group.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a “stubborn moderate cooperator.” They almost always contribute the same intermediate amount, with only one brief deviation downward and one brief deviation upward. Their default is to give a consistent, non-maximal share that is below what many others give but still far from free-riding. They do not systematically adjust contributions in response to changes in others’ average behavior, even when they are repeatedly the unique low contributor among mostly high contributors, and even when they are singled out by punishment. This suggests they treat their chosen level as a personal fairness norm or comfortable compromise between self-interest and group benefit, rather than using a flexible, conditional cooperation strategy. They show low reactive volatility: feedback from others (via punishment, rewards to others, or shifts in group contributions) does not produce sustained upward or downward trends in their own giving. Their risk tolerance appears moderate: they are willing to undercontribute relative to others despite visibility and sanction risk, but they also avoid extreme free-riding that might trigger harsher responses or collapse group cooperation.

<PUNISHMENT>
They never use punishment, despite having multiple opportunities and a clear pattern that one specific partner targets them with costly sanctions. This indicates a very high threshold for imposing costs on others and a strong reluctance to spend personal resources for either deterrence or retaliation. Their behavior does not show targeted or proportional sanctions toward lower contributors, nor retaliation against someone who persistently punishes them. From this, it is reasonable to infer that they either (a) view punishment as inefficient or not worth the cost, (b) are conflict-averse and prefer not to escalate, or (c) are focused on maximizing own payoff without engaging in norm enforcement. Because they themselves are consistently under the group’s contribution norm, it is also plausible that they recognize their own vulnerability and avoid a punishment “war”; however, this is uncertain. Overall, they function as a non-enforcer type: they free-ride somewhat on the norm-enforcement efforts of others without joining those efforts.

<RESPONSE_TO_PUNISHER>
When another player repeatedly punishes them, they do not retaliate, they do not significantly increase their contribution to align with the punisher’s implicit demand, and they do not shift into a punitive stance toward anyone else. Their contribution pattern remains essentially stable after being sanctioned multiple times, including instances where the sanction is substantial. This indicates that punishment does not successfully coerce them into higher cooperation and does not trigger counter-punishment. They appear to “absorb” the punishment and continue with their own strategy, implying either a strong commitment to their chosen contribution level, indifference to others’ attempts to control their behavior, or uncertainty about how to interpret the sanction. They exhibit behavioral forgiveness or at least non-retaliation: even persistent, costly punishment aimed at them does not change their treatment of the punisher relative to other group members.

<REWARD>
They never use rewards, even though several others actively reward high contributors. They do not reciprocate those prosocial signals, and they do not selectively reinforce any partner’s behavior. This suggests that they either place low value on norm-reinforcement via positive incentives, consider the reward mechanism inefficient for their own payoff, or are generally uninterested in actively shaping others’ behavior. The absence of rewarding despite clear evidence that others employ it implies they do not try to join the “prosocial coalition” that uses rewards to sustain high cooperation. Their stance is thus passive with respect to positive incentives: they benefit from a high-contribution environment that others help sustain, but they do not invest in maintaining it.

<RESPONSE_TO_REWARDER>
They never receive rewards from others in this game, so their direct response to being rewarded is unknown. Because they consistently refrain from using reward on anyone, including players who are frequently rewarding others, it is uncertain whether they would respond with reciprocal reward or higher contributions if they ever were rewarded. There is no behavioral evidence that they attempt to form alliances with rewarders or distinguish rewarders from non-rewarders in their own actions.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
They observe a group where several players often contribute close to the maximum and sometimes spend on rewards, while one player regularly devotes substantial resources to punishing them. Despite this, they do not visibly condition their behavior on others’ payoffs, spending, or treatment of them. High contributors’ relatively strong earnings and prosocial signaling do not induce them to match those contribution levels, and the punisher’s lower payoffs (due to punishment costs) do not induce them to exploit that player further or adjust contributions downward. They appear largely indifferent, behaviorally, to whether others are sacrificing for the group (via high contribution or reward) or sacrificing to enforce norms (via punishment). This points to a type that monitors the environment enough to see that cooperation is stable and beneficial, and then “locks in” a personally satisfactory contribution that exploits some of the surplus generated by others’ generosity while avoiding extreme opportunism. Their social style is quiet and self-contained: they neither coordinate with prosocial players nor escalate conflict with punishers, and they maintain their own rule-of-thumb strategy regardless of others’ detailed outcomes.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a perfectly stable, moderate contributor. They always contribute exactly half of their endowment and never adjust this level despite substantial variation in others’ behavior, total contributions, and final payoffs. Their strategy is simple and rule-like: “I put in a fair, middle amount every time,” with no detectable experimentation or trend over the game. They do not try to match the group’s average, do not escalate to full cooperation when others are highly cooperative, and do not drop toward free-riding when others’ contributions fall. This indicates a strong internal fairness norm anchored at “half,” combined with low reactivity to social or payoff signals. They appear risk-averse with respect to strategy change: once they find a behavior that yields solid payoffs, they stick to it, even though higher contributions would raise group and personal returns given the multiplier. They prioritize steadiness and simplicity over payoff maximization and do not appear to condition their contributions on any specific peer’s behavior.

<PUNISHMENT>
This player never uses punishment, despite repeated opportunities and clear variation in others’ contribution levels, including occasional low contributions by peers and visible use of punishment by others. Their inaction persists regardless of whether some players contribute less than the group norm or whether punishment might have been effective at disciplining a specific target. This suggests a strong reluctance to incur personal costs to harm others, even for potential norm enforcement. They do not appear motivated by retaliation, do not mimic others’ punitive strategies, and do not engage in second-order punishment (punishing non-punishers). The pattern is consistent with a non-punitive, harm-averse type that prefers to let the contribution structure “speak for itself” rather than enforcing norms through costly sanctions. Whether this is due to moral discomfort with harming others, skepticism about the effectiveness of punishment, or simple self-interest in avoiding costs remains unknown.

<RESPONSE_TO_PUNISHER>
This player is never punished during the game, so their direct behavioral response to identifiable punishers is unknown. There is no evidence of pre-emptive adaptation to avoid punishment; their contribution level is unchanging from the start and does not react to others’ sanctioning patterns. Given their stable, moderate contributions and non-punitive stance, if they were punished in a future setting, one might expect low propensity for counter-punishment and a tendency to maintain their own norm-following behavior; however, this is speculative and confidence in this extrapolation is low.

<REWARD>
This player never uses rewards, even when others contribute more than they do and when prosocial reward behavior is clearly present in the group. They do not invest to encourage high contributors, nor do they attempt to strategically reinforce allies or cultivate reciprocity. Their stance appears efficiency- and cost-focused at the individual level: they avoid spending coins on mechanisms that transfer payoff away from themselves, even when such transfers could plausibly improve future cooperation. They also show no sign of imitating others’ rewarding behavior. The absence of rewards, combined with steady moderate contributions, fits a “self-contained cooperator” profile: willing to contribute reliably to the public good but not willing to pay extra to manage others’ behavior through positive incentives.

<RESPONSE_TO_REWARDER>
This player is never rewarded, so their direct reactions to identifiable rewarders are unknown. They do not adjust their contributions in response to the general presence of rewards in the environment; their behavior remains unchanged while others use rewards multiple times. There is no observable attempt to signal for future rewards by increasing contributions, nor any sign of forming implicit alliances with known rewarders. Whether they would reciprocate rewards via higher contributions or via counter-reward in another setting is unknown.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
This player observes substantial information each round: others’ contributions, payoffs, and costs spent on punishment and reward. Yet they display no behavioral adjustment in response. They do not increase contributions when others contribute very high amounts and group payoffs rise, and they do not decrease when others free-ride more or when punitive conflict escalates among others. They ignore both negative and positive incentive signals directed at other players and do not seem to take advantage of apparent “safe” opportunities to free-ride when cooperation stays high. This indicates low sensitivity to social comparison and low engagement with the strategic social dynamics. Their primary focus appears to be on maintaining a personally acceptable, predictable payoff stream rather than tailoring their behavior in response to others’ gains, losses, or enforcement activity. Overall, they behave as a stable, internally guided cooperator who treats others’ outcomes as background information rather than as cues for adaptation.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a generally high contributor with moderate downward flexibility. They usually give more than or close to the group average, often at or near full contribution, but occasionally cut back substantially. Their baseline seems to be a “cooperative but not unconditional” stance: they appear willing to forego private payoff to support the public fund, especially when others also contribute strongly.

Contribution levels are not chaotic; they vary within a band rather than swinging between extremes every round. Larger drops occur after stretches where the player has already contributed a lot and/or engaged in costly punishment, suggesting some sensitivity to their own payoff position and possible “fatigue” with shouldering the cooperative burden alone.

They appear conditionally cooperative: when others continue to contribute at high and stable levels, they are happy to match or exceed that. When others’ average contributions sag but remain decent, the player sometimes reduces their own contribution while still staying within the cooperative range. They do not appear to exploit others’ very high contributions by repeatedly free-riding; low contributions are occasional and not a persistent strategy.

They seem to have a fairness norm centered on “everyone should at least give solid amounts.” Players who consistently give much more (especially full contributors) are treated as especially virtuous. The focal player tolerates some asymmetry but reacts sharply to one specific moderate contributor who also benefits from the public good without matching the cooperative effort of the highest contributors; this indicates a dislike of systematic advantage-taking rather than of any deviation per se.

Risk tolerance seems moderate: they are willing to invest heavily into the public fund even without guarantees of reciprocity, but occasionally protect their own payoff by contributing less, especially after investing in costly punishment or when it is unclear whether high cooperation will persist.

<PUNISHMENT>
This player uses punishment actively but very selectively, focusing almost exclusively on a single target. They are clearly willing to incur personal costs to reduce another’s payoff, and they escalate the intensity over time. The target is not the lowest contributor in the group; instead, it is a consistent moderate contributor who tends to earn relatively high payoffs. The focal player does not punish other moderate or low contributors who play similarly, nor do they punish high contributors, indicating that they are not using punishment as a general tool to enforce uniform high contributions.

Their pattern is consistent with a personalized, norm‑enforcing or expressive motive toward that specific player: “you, in particular, should not be allowed to keep doing this.” The repeated focus and occasional escalation suggest they are trying to influence that player’s behavior or reduce an outcome they see as unfair, rather than simply venting once. The absence of punishment toward anyone else, even when they contribute similarly, shows high selectivity and some internal rule about who “deserves” sanctions.

There is no evidence of retaliatory punishment, because the focal player is never punished by others. Accordingly, their punishment motive cannot be described as revenge‑driven. Instead, it appears mixed: partly inequity aversion (dislike of that player’s relatively favorable payoff position given their contributions), and partly a desire to deter that player from continuing a pattern the focal player finds objectionable.

They are willing to spend substantial cumulative resources on punishment, even when it reduces their own payoff noticeably, which indicates that enforcing their perceived fairness standard can override short‑term self‑interest. At the same time, they eventually discontinue punishing once the target’s contributions and the overall group pattern become stable and acceptable to them, suggesting some capacity to “declare victory” or at least to stop escalating indefinitely.

<RESPONSE_TO_PUNISHER>
Unknown. The focal player is never punished in this transcript, so their reactions to being sanctioned—whether they would comply, retaliate, or forgive—cannot be inferred. Any assumptions about their response to punishment would be low confidence and speculative.

<REWARD>
The player is clearly willing to reward and does so in a pattern consistent with “pro‑social reinforcement.” They direct rewards to those who contribute at or near full levels and who appear to sustain group welfare. They do not reward moderate or low contributors, even when those individuals are not being punished, indicating that their standard for positive reinforcement is reserved for the very cooperative.

Rewarding is intermittent: they do not reward every time someone contributes highly, nor do they reward all high contributors in a given round. This suggests they treat rewards as a targeted, somewhat scarce signal rather than an automatic rule. They may be using reward both to express appreciation and to encourage sustained high contributions from particular players who have been especially consistent.

There is no evidence they use rewards strategically to manipulate more selfish players into contributing more; instead, they focus on already‑good cooperators. That is more consistent with helping “heroes” than recruiting “defectors.” Given the positive payoff cost of rewarding, they accept a reduction in their own earnings to support and recognize high cooperators, but they do this sporadically rather than continuously, perhaps balancing altruistic signaling with payoff concerns.

<RESPONSE_TO_REWARDER>
Unknown. The focal player is never rewarded by others in this transcript, so their behavioral or strategic response to receiving rewards—whether they would reciprocate, increase contributions, or form implicit alliances—cannot be inferred.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
The player pays close attention to others’ contributions and resulting payoffs and appears sensitive to the relationship between effort and reward. When high contributors earn moderate or even slightly lower payoffs than some moderate contributors, the focal player intervenes, particularly against the moderate contributor whose earnings often compare favorably despite giving less than the top cooperators. This implies strong outcome‑based fairness concerns with an emphasis on relative payoffs.

They never sanction or reward based purely on outcome size: they do not attack those with the very highest payoffs when these are paired with high contributions, nor do they protect lower earners if those are also low contributors. Their responses are tied to the pattern “contribution level vs. resulting payoff,” not payoff alone.

The player seems comfortable with a differentiated outcome structure where high cooperators do well, moderate cooperators do reasonably, and no one is singled out without a behavioral basis. Once the group settles into a stable, high‑contribution equilibrium and the previously targeted player behaves in line with that standard, the focal player stops using punishment and cuts back on reward use as well. That suggests that they primarily deploy sanctions and rewards as tools to adjust the group toward a desired cooperative and fair pattern, and when that pattern is achieved, they revert to simpler contribution decisions without extra costly interventions.

Overall, this player type is a conditionally cooperative, fairness‑oriented enforcer who uses both reward and targeted punishment to shape others’ behavior and relative payoffs, prioritizing alignment between contributions and outcomes over maximizing their own earnings.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a generally high contributor who experiments with partial free-riding but does not fully defect. They start with full contributions and repeatedly return to full provision even after periods of contributing less, which suggests an internal norm favoring high cooperation rather than pure payoff-maximization. Over time, they increasingly vary their contribution amount, sometimes contributing notably less than most others, then moving back up again. This pattern indicates conditional cooperation in a loose, exploratory sense: they seem to adjust their own contribution when others’ average contributions drift down or when low contributors are punished, but they never drop to zero and rarely go to very low levels. They tolerate some inequity—being more generous than some others for many rounds—without using punishment or reward to change behavior. Their willingness to occasionally under-contribute relative to clear high contributors, while still benefiting from the public fund, shows some opportunism and risk tolerance: they test whether they can keep high payoffs while letting others carry more of the cooperative burden. However, because they frequently return to high contributions even when they could profitably keep free-riding, they appear motivated partly by a fairness or “do my share” norm, not just by short-term gain. Overall, they are a mostly-cooperative, mild opportunist who adapts contributions but avoids extreme defection.

<PUNISHMENT>
This player never uses punishment despite ample opportunities and a relatively efficient punishment technology. They refrain from punishing both persistent low contributors and those who impose heavy sanctions on others. This suggests a strong aversion to costly sanctions, whether for normative enforcement or retaliation. The absence of any “moralistic” punishment, even when some players clearly contribute less or when one player repeatedly targets a specific low contributor with escalating sanctions, implies that this player either does not feel responsible for enforcing fairness or doubts that punishment is worthwhile. Their behavior is consistent with a “live and let live” stance: they accept payoff differences and let others bear the cost of policing. There is no evidence of targeted or strategic deterrence; they do not punish in early rounds to shape behavior, nor later in response to persistent patterns. Personality-wise, this points to conflict avoidance and low taste for confrontation, even when it could be individually or collectively beneficial. If they consider the efficiency of punishment at all, they appear to judge the personal cost as not worth the expected benefits, or they simply avoid negative actions as a rule.

<RESPONSE_TO_PUNISHER>
They are never punished in this game, so their direct response to being sanctioned is unknown. Because punishers are identifiable and one player uses substantial punishment on others, the fact that this player never joins in or mirrors those punishments suggests they do not align themselves with punishers or treat them as leaders to emulate. They also do not appear to “side” against heavily punished players by further punishing them. Thus, in the absence of personal experience of punishment, the best inference is that they neither reward nor reinforce punishers’ behavior and do not use others’ punitive actions as a cue for their own sanctions. Their likely response to a hypothetical punishment is uncertain; given their non-retaliatory baseline, retaliation is possible but not supported by evidence, so any claim beyond “unknown” would be low confidence.

<REWARD>
They never reward anyone, even when some players clearly and consistently contribute more than others and sometimes incur personal costs policing the group. They also receive small rewards from others but do not reciprocate. This indicates they are not inclined to spend their own coins to positively reinforce cooperation or to build goodwill through gifts, despite reward being less harsh and more socially positive than punishment. Their strategy appears narrowly self-focused with respect to the optional mechanisms: they rely on the public good mechanism itself and on others’ use of reward/punishment, while personally free-riding on others’ incentive-provision. The lack of any symbolic or one-off rewarding, even in early phases where norms could be set, suggests that they do not view reward as part of their role in the group, and they are not trying to cultivate alliances or reputations via costly prosocial gestures. This points toward instrumental, cost-averse behavior around side-payments: they will cooperate via contribution, but they will not pay extra to shape others’ behavior.

<RESPONSE_TO_REWARDER>
They are rewarded a few times by other players despite not using the reward mechanism themselves. After receiving rewards, they do not change their pattern in any clearly affiliative or reciprocal way: they do not begin rewarding, they do not unambiguously increase contributions toward the apparent rewarders beyond what they were already doing, and they do not adopt the rewarders’ sanctioning style. Their contributions remain generally high with some variation, consistent with their prior trend, and there is no sign of a step-change in behavior following rewards. This suggests they experience rewards more as windfall income than as social signals that demand reciprocation or loyalty. They do not appear to update into a coalition mindset (e.g., “I should now support those who support me”). As a type, they accept positive treatment without reciprocating in kind, and they do not use reward receipts as cues for alliance-building or reputation management. Their gratitude level is behaviorally unknown; what can be inferred is that gratitude, if felt, does not translate into costly reciprocal action.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
They observe that some players consistently contribute high amounts and sometimes sacrifice payoff through punishment or reward, while others contribute less and are occasionally heavily punished, yet they remain behaviorally detached from these dynamics. They do not move to shield heavily punished players by rewarding them, nor do they join punishers to intensify sanctions. They also see that non-punishers and non-rewarders often achieve higher round payoffs than those who police the group; their own consistent choice to avoid both punishment and reward aligns with this payoff pattern, suggesting they are attentive to the net costliness of sanctions. They adapt their own contributions as group averages fluctuate, but this adaptation is relatively modest and does not track any single player’s treatment—more a response to overall environment than to specific individuals’ fortunes. Their attitude toward inequality in outcomes seems tolerant: they accept that some earn more due to low contribution or due to not spending on sanctions, and that some earn less due to punishing, without intervening. Overall, they behave as a pragmatic cooperator who lets others manage social control while they adjust their own contribution levels to maintain good payoffs, showing low engagement with the social-emotional meaning of others’ costs and payoffs.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a high, steady contributor who anchors close to full cooperation. They frequently give the entire endowment and otherwise hover modestly below the group average only when the general contribution climate looks weaker. They do not appear to condition sharply on small differences in others’ behavior; minor under-contribution by a few peers does not trigger strong downward adjustment. Instead, they maintain a relatively generous baseline that fluctuates within a narrow band, suggesting a blend of prosocial preference and mild strategic caution rather than strict tit‑for‑tat. They tolerate being among the top contributors even when it reduces their relative payoff, indicating low aversion to disadvantageous inequality and a willingness to absorb some exploitation if group contributions remain reasonably high. They do not escalate downward when overall contributions steadily fall; rather, they oscillate between full contribution and a moderate reduction, implying they value sustaining cooperation more than strictly maximizing short‑term earnings. Their choices do not indicate strong risk‑seeking or risk‑avoidant behavior; they stay with a simple, robust cooperative rule rather than experimenting widely.

<PUNISHMENT>
They never use punishment despite the tool being powerful and relatively cost‑effective. This holds even when some peers contribute noticeably less or when defectors are clearly earning higher payoffs. Their nonuse appears systematic rather than situational: even in environments where a strategic punisher might try to discipline low contributors or retaliate against free riders, they refrain. This suggests either a principled aversion to harming others, skepticism about the long‑term value of punishment, or a preference to let others bear any enforcement role. There is no evidence that they use punishment for either deterrence or retaliation. Their strategy seems to omit punishment entirely, not even as a late‑game or last‑resort tool. Overall, they are a non‑punishing cooperator.

<RESPONSE_TO_PUNISHER>
Unknown. The player is never punished, so there is no observed reaction. Their future contributions and continued refusal to punish do not allow inference about whether they would respond to punishment with compliance, retaliation, or indifference. Any characterization here would be speculative; confidence is low.

<REWARD>
They never spend on rewards, even though they routinely observe others investing in positive incentives. This includes frequent cases where other players reward high contributors. Their abstention is consistent across both cooperative and more defect‑prone environments, suggesting that they treat rewarding, like punishment, as outside their strategy set. This likely reflects either a strong preference to avoid spending on social tools altogether, a belief that cooperation can be sustained without explicit reinforcement, or a narrow focus on maximizing personal payoff subject to maintaining their own cooperative standard. They do not engage in alliance‑building via rewards nor do they attempt to shape others’ behavior with positive incentives.

<RESPONSE_TO_REWARDER>
They receive rewards on a few occasions from others who also appear highly cooperative. Their subsequent behavior does not change discernibly: they continue to contribute at similar or slightly varying cooperative levels and still never adopt rewarding themselves. There is no indication of reciprocal rewarding or targeted favoring of those who rewarded them, even though identities are observable. This suggests that, while they may privately appreciate the rewards (unknown), they do not convert gratitude into material reciprocity. Their cooperative pattern appears driven by an internal standard rather than contingent on being rewarded.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
They consistently see others’ outcomes, including payoff differences driven by varying contributions and by some players’ use of punishment and reward. They do not mimic the enforcers’ behavior, nor do they react visibly to shifting payoff ranks: even when defectors earn more, the player neither punishes nor heavily reduces contributions, and even when cooperators are supported by rewards, they do not join in reinforcing them. This points to low sensitivity to outcome inequality and to others’ sanctioning choices. They adapt their own contributions slightly to the general contribution climate, but they ignore the “second‑order” layer of who is punishing or rewarding whom and with what cost. Socially, they behave as a quietly principled cooperator: they uphold a cooperative norm for themselves, largely independent of others’ sanctioning strategies or relative earnings, and refrain from directly intervening in others’ payoffs.
cluster_intro: This cluster groups personas with related strategy patterns around punishment, reward, contribution, contributions, low.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
The player is a moderately prosocial but self-oriented conditional cooperator with high volatility. They do not anchor on a single contribution level; instead, they frequently shift between very low and very high contributions. They clearly understand that contributing can be profitable when others also contribute, because they repeatedly choose high contributions in environments where group contributions appear strong. At the same time, they are comfortable free-riding and sometimes take the full endowment while still benefiting from others’ cooperation.

Their contributions track the perceived cooperativeness of the group in a broad, qualitative way: when others as a whole appear generous, the player is generally willing to join in, though rarely as the most altruistic member. When the group seems more mixed or deteriorating, they reduce their own contribution sharply, sometimes down to zero, even if cooperation has not completely collapsed. They do not insist on strict equality or fairness; they tolerate contributing more than many low contributors around them at times, and at other times they themselves are among the least generous while others are still contributing substantially. This suggests weak or flexible fairness norms: they care about payoff-relevant conditions (is it lucrative to contribute now?) more than about matching others exactly.

Risk-wise, the player shows a willingness to “gamble” on high contributions when the environment looks cooperative, accepting the immediate personal sacrifice for the expectation of a good group return. However, they do not sustain high contributions unconditionally. Their pattern indicates a payoff-sensitive, opportunistic stance rather than a principled commitment to cooperation or a strict free-riding strategy.

Overall, they are a payoff-oriented conditional cooperator: willing to support the public good when it seems profitable and somewhat socially supported, but quick to scale back and free-ride when they sense fragility or unevenness in group contributions. Their strategy is adaptive rather than rigid, but also noisy and inconsistent, suggesting that they update heuristically rather than following a clear, stable rule.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
The player appears aware that the game has a finite horizon, but they do not exhibit a simple linear decay or a pure “end-spurt” of defection. In the final portion of the game, they continue to vary their contributions, sometimes contributing very little and sometimes at moderate-to-high levels. They do not switch into a pure defector mode in the last few rounds, nor do they escalate to full cooperation as a final gesture.

Instead, their late-game behavior remains conditional and opportunistic: they adjust contributions up when the group as a whole still looks reasonably cooperative, and they reduce them when the environment seems more mixed or deteriorating, even very close to the final round. This implies that, even when the end is near, their primary reference remains the current cooperative climate and expected payoff, not a strict backward-induction logic or a moral norm about “finishing strong.”

In short, their end-game strategy continues the same pattern as earlier: flexible conditional cooperation with intermittent free-riding, rather than a clear terminal collapse or a final cooperative surge.
cluster_intro: This cluster groups personas with related strategy patterns around contributions, contribution, cooperation, group, high.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
The player follows a highly asymmetric “all‑or‑nothing free rider” pattern. Across the game, they overwhelmingly choose zero contribution, punctuated by a small number of rounds where they give the full endowment. This creates a bimodal profile: either full cooperation or complete defection, with no intermediate levels.

They appear payoff‑oriented and attentive to the group’s average contribution. When others are broadly cooperative and average contributions are high, they occasionally match that with a full contribution, but they do not maintain that level; they quickly revert to taking everything once they have confirmed that others continue to give. This suggests strategic, opportunistic free riding rather than a stable commitment to fairness or efficiency.

There is no evidence of adherence to proportionality or reciprocity norms in a consistent way. The player does not gradually adjust contributions to “meet others halfway”; instead, they exploit the public good for most of the game while occasionally injecting full contributions when cooperation is already strong. This looks more like testing or stabilizing a high-contribution regime that they can then profit from by defecting again, rather than a fairness-driven impulse.

Risk tolerance appears moderate: they are willing to risk full contributions in already cooperative environments, presumably because the marginal loss from contributing in that context is smaller relative to the large group return. They avoid such risks when cooperation is already eroding, preferring safe free riding to attempting to rebuild trust through further contributions. Their pattern suggests instrumental rather than moralized cooperation: they cooperate when it looks likely to be lucrative, not to enforce a principle.

The strategy is conditionally cooperative in a narrow, one-sided sense: they sometimes cooperate when others are cooperative, but they do not uphold a norm of mutuality. Once they see a cooperative environment forming, they treat it as an opportunity to defect in surrounding rounds rather than as something to protect. This aligns with a “calculating exploiter” type who understands public-goods incentives and positions themselves to benefit disproportionately from others’ prosociality.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
The player shows clear awareness of the finite horizon. Their contribution pattern does not shift into sustained cooperation at the end; instead, they largely maintain their default of zero contribution through the final stretch and do not exhibit a last‑round “gift” or attempt to influence future reputation (which is meaningless here). There is no visible end-game escalation of cooperation.

Their sporadic full contributions continue to appear interspersed with many zeroes across the later part of the game, but these cooperative spikes are not concentrated at the end and do not increase as the game approaches its conclusion. This supports the view that the player’s occasional cooperation is situationally motivated by local conditions (e.g., others’ high contributions) rather than shaped by long-run future interaction concerns.

In the final rounds, they do not attempt to rebuild or amplify group cooperation even when others continue to contribute substantial amounts. This suggests they internalize the classic end-game logic of public goods and prioritize extracting value over sustaining norms once the horizon is short. Their type in new environments is therefore best modeled as horizon-aware, strategically free riding in late stages, and not prone to sentimental or reputational “last-round generosity” in the absence of explicit future benefits.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a highly stable, near-unconditional high contributor. They overwhelmingly choose the maximum possible contribution and maintain this choice across almost the entire game, with a single, isolated deviation where they keep their full endowment for themselves and then immediately revert to full contributions thereafter. This pattern suggests that their default policy is “always contribute fully,” rather than finely tuning their behavior to momentary payoff changes.

They appear willing to contribute at high levels even when others’ average contributions are relatively low and volatile. They do not systematically match the group’s average, nor do they visibly punish low contributors by reducing their own contribution after seeing free-riding. Instead, they continue to put in the maximum, indicating low sensitivity to short-term exploitation risk and a high tolerance for contributing in mixed groups that include defectors.

Their contributions track more with a social or efficiency norm (“it is good to fully contribute”) than with strict reciprocity to individual others. They do not selectively respond to particular peers’ changes in contributions; when others fluctuate between low and high cooperation, this player’s contribution remains essentially constant. The brief instance of zero contribution does not trigger a lasting strategic shift, which suggests either an experiment with self-interest, a momentary test of what happens if they free-ride, or a short-lived reaction to previous low group contributions. Since they promptly return to maximal giving and then stay there, the most consistent interpretation is that they identify as a cooperator and regard the deviation as an exception rather than a new rule.

They show no sign of gradually decaying contributions as the game progresses. High contributions persist through early, middle, and late phases despite significant variation in the group’s behavior. This indicates strong internal cooperation norms and low volatility: they neither escalate nor withdraw in a tit-for-tat manner, and they do not chase the profit-maximizing individual strategy of persistent low contribution despite having enough opportunities to reconsider.

Their fairness norms appear to favor collective efficiency over strict payoff equality. They continue to invest heavily even in the presence of repeat low contributors, which implies they accept some inequity in individual payoffs if the group output stays reasonably high. Risk tolerance is high in social terms: they accept being exploited by free riders rather than adopting defensive defection. From the perspective of classic PGG typologies, they most closely resemble a “strong altruistic cooperator” or “norm-driven unconditional cooperator” with only very limited and quickly reversed experimentation with defection.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
Awareness of the game horizon does not meaningfully erode this player’s cooperation. Across the late portion of the game, including the final rounds, they continue to contribute the maximum amount. There is no visible “end-game unraveling” where they reduce contributions as the remaining number of rounds shrinks. Instead, their cooperative stance is maintained right through the final decision.

They do not attempt to exploit the group in the final round by dropping their contribution, even though doing so would be individually profitable and cannot be punished or rewarded in future interactions. This suggests that their strategy is not based on backward induction about future payoffs, but on a more time-invariant rule or internal standard (“I contribute fully in this kind of game”). Their behavior is consistent with a player who either does not prioritize horizon-based optimization or who values maintaining a cooperative identity or principle more than capturing the one-shot gain from late defection.

The absence of contribution decay near the end of the game also indicates that they either do not expect others to massively defect in the final rounds, or, if they do, they still choose to cooperate despite that expectation. In either case, the looming end does not shift them into a more self-interested mode. They remain a stable, high contributor from start to finish, with no systematic end-game adjustment beyond ordinary payoff fluctuations caused by others’ changing behavior.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a very high, near-unconditional cooperator. Their default is to contribute the full endowment and they maintain this behavior almost the entire game. They briefly experiment with free-riding exactly once, then immediately revert to full contributions and do not repeat the deviation, even when others contribute modestly or very little.

Their contribution pattern is extremely stable: they do not gradually drift downward over time, nor do they fine-tune contributions in response to small fluctuations in group behavior. Instead, they appear to adopt a simple, robust rule—“always contribute the maximum”—and stick with it.

The one zero-contribution instance suggests they understand the incentives and are capable of strategic deviation. However, since they promptly return to full giving, the dominant driver seems to be a strong cooperative or efficiency-oriented norm rather than profit-maximizing self-interest. They behave as if they prioritize the group’s total payoff and are comfortable bearing the cost of contributing even when others free-ride.

They do not condition their behavior much on others’ average contributions: they continue to give maximally when others’ contributions are both high and low. This indicates low responsiveness to short-term fairness violations and a high tolerance for free-riding around them. Their fairness norm appears to be “I do my part regardless,” rather than “I match what others do.”

Risk tolerance toward exploitation is high: they repeatedly expose themselves to being taken advantage of by low contributors and do not self-protect by reducing their own giving. They act as if the moral or strategic value they place on maintaining cooperation outweighs concerns about being treated unfairly.

Belief-wise, they likely infer that contributions are socially desirable and that enough others will contribute that their own giving is worthwhile, even if not everyone cooperates. Their persistence in giving suggests either optimism about group cooperation or a commitment to contributing even without such optimism (which is indistinguishable from behavior alone; confidence: low on motive).

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
Despite full knowledge of the finite horizon, this player does not display a classic end-game decay in cooperation. They sustain maximal contributions through the final phase, including the last few rounds and the very last decision, with no observable reduction.

There is no evidence that remaining-round information changes their strategy: they do not ramp up free-riding near the end, nor do they escalate contributions (they are already at ceiling most of the time). Awareness of the game’s approaching end therefore either does not factor into their decision rule, or is consciously overridden by a stable norm to keep contributing fully.

In the final rounds, even when others’ contributions are mixed or relatively low, they continue to contribute the maximum. This suggests they do not attempt to “cash out” at the end by exploiting the group once future reciprocity is impossible. Instead, their behavior is time-invariant: they cooperate in early, middle, and late stages in essentially the same way.

Overall, their horizon awareness appears behaviorally irrelevant; they act like a rule-following, norm-driven cooperator who does not strategically adjust for the end-game.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a “conditional high contributor with opportunistic dips.” They clearly understand that contributing is socially efficient: they repeatedly make large contributions, often at or near the maximum, and do so both when others are highly cooperative and when the average contribution is only moderate. They are not a systematic free rider.

Their contribution pattern is volatile rather than stable. Contributions move between very high levels and much lower ones, without settling into a simple rule like “always match the group average” or “always give half.” However, the lows never reach consistent full defection; minimal contributions appear sporadically and are interspersed with renewed high giving. This suggests experimentation and mood/assessment shifts more than a stable low-cooperation identity.

The player reacts to the cooperation climate: when the group appears strongly cooperative, they frequently respond with high or near-max contributions, fitting a conditional cooperator profile. When they see weaker or mixed cooperation, they sometimes pull back sharply, contributing little while still collecting a substantial payoff from others’ efforts. These opportunistic reductions are not sustained, indicating they balance self-interest with some internal norm of “doing their part” and possibly with ongoing learning about what yields good returns.

Their fairness norm seems asymmetric: they tolerate contributing more than many peers and do not consistently punish low-contributing environments by switching into permanent defection. At the same time, they appear willing to “test” lower contributions when they perceive others not fully aligned with strong cooperation. This reflects a norm of “contribute generously, but don’t be a sucker indefinitely.”

Risk tolerance is moderate to high in the social sense. They repeatedly stake large portions of their endowment on the public fund in an environment where others’ reliability is uncertain, which exposes them to the risk of being exploited. At the same time, their intermittent low contributions show they are not blindly altruistic; they are willing to protect their own payoff when conditions feel less trustworthy or when they test whether the group will maintain cooperation without their full input.

Overall, this player is best described as a pro-social, payoff-aware conditional cooperator: usually willing to contribute a lot, sensitive to group behavior, occasionally opportunistic, and comfortable with fluctuating between generous and protective stances.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
The player shows clear horizon awareness: their behavior in the final stretch does not collapse into pure defection but becomes more jagged and exploratory. In late rounds, they alternate between high and low giving rather than steadily ramping down cooperation. This indicates they recognize the approaching end but do not interpret it as a strict signal to stop contributing altogether.

There is no evidence of a classic end-game cascade where contributions monotonically decay to zero. Instead, the player continues to sometimes contribute very generously even when only a few rounds remain, suggesting that their cooperative inclination persists despite the finite horizon. At the same time, the presence of some very low late contributions shows that they are willing to take advantage of the remaining opportunities for private gain and may be probing how little they can contribute while still benefiting from others’ cooperation.

They seem to treat the late game as a space for strategic experimentation rather than a simple “grab what you can” phase. This pattern is consistent with a player who values both payoff and a self-image (or implicit norm) of being at least somewhat cooperative, even when future interaction is limited.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a moderately cooperative, strategically flexible contributor who oscillates between full cooperation, partial cooperation, and free-riding. Across the game, they regularly use the full range of possible contributions (0, 10, 20), with 10 and 20 appearing most often. The pattern indicates they understand that contributing to the public fund can be profitable when others also contribute, but they are unwilling to lock into unconditional high contributions.

Their contributions are clearly conditional on perceived group behavior. When they observe widespread high contributions, they often match or come close to the cooperative norm with high or full contributions. When contributions around them become more mixed or partially defecting, they reduce their own giving to a mid-level amount or even drop to zero. This suggests they track the group’s cooperative climate and adjust to avoid being the “sucker” in an uncooperative environment.

They display neither pure altruism nor pure self-interest. Instead, they seem to balance personal payoff with a preference for maintaining a productive group fund. The choice of a mid-level contribution (rather than always going to one extreme) suggests a “hedging” mentality: they seek to retain some private income while still supporting the public fund enough to benefit from others’ cooperation.

There is no clear trend of monotonic decline or escalation; instead, their behavior is volatile but structured. The alternation between full contributions, half contributions, and occasional free-riding appears responsive rather than random. They show moderate risk tolerance: they are willing to fully contribute in uncertain environments when others appear cooperative but also willing to sharply pull back when cooperation looks fragile or unevenly shared.

Fairness norms appear “reciprocal but not punitive.” The player does not consistently insist on strict proportionality, but they do seem to require that others contribute non-trivially to justify their own high contributions. When many others give a lot, they tend to cooperate strongly; when they observe several low or zero contributions, they permit themselves to free-ride or drop to a safer mid-level. This is consistent with a conditional cooperator who mixes in opportunistic phases rather than a rigid fairness absolutist.

Overall, their type can be described as a payoff-sensitive conditional cooperator with moderate volatility, who is willing to lead or support cooperation when it is widely shared but also periodically exploits cooperative groups to boost individual earnings.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
The player shows clear awareness of the finite horizon and uses the late game to experiment and occasionally exploit, rather than following a simple end-game collapse. Near the final stretch, they continue to alternate between mid-level contributions, free-riding, and full contributions, indicating that they do not adopt a straightforward “contribute nothing at the end” policy.

They do not exhibit a smooth decay in cooperation as the game approaches its conclusion. Instead, their behavior remains flexible and context-sensitive: sometimes they reduce contributions sharply even with rounds remaining, and sometimes they sustain high contributions very late. This suggests they do not rigidly apply backward induction logic, but they understand that late-round moves have fewer future repercussions and are therefore more willing to shift to opportunistic strategies.

In the very last part of the game, they continue to condition their decisions on what they see others doing, rather than purely on the fact that the game is ending. They are still prepared to fully cooperate in the final round when the group looks sufficiently cooperative, implying that they value the immediate gains from one more cooperative round more than the short-term benefit of a final free-ride in an already cooperative environment.

Their end-game approach is thus characterized by: (1) sustained responsiveness to the observed cooperative climate, (2) willingness to occasionally free-ride when it seems low-risk to reputation or future payoffs (even late), and (3) no strong evidence of a strict “last-round defection” principle. This end-game pattern is consistent with a player who understands the horizon but remains primarily driven by short-run payoff calculus and conditional reciprocity rather than by a fully rationalized backward-induction strategy.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
Type label: Opportunistic conditional cooperator with oscillating free-riding.

The player mixes medium and high contributions with frequent complete free-riding. They do not settle into a stable level; instead, they alternate between giving nothing, giving about half, and giving everything. This indicates volatility rather than a fixed contribution rule.

Their behavior is clearly conditional on the general cooperation climate. When they see broadly high contributions, they are willing at times to join in with full or substantial contributions, suggesting they value the gains from a well-functioning public fund and are not a pure selfish minimizer. At other times in similarly cooperative climates, they withhold entirely and ride on the efforts of others, showing they also place weight on maximizing own payoff when they expect others to contribute anyway.

They show no strong norm of strict fairness or proportionality. They neither consistently match average contributions nor aim to contribute at a level that would make their share “fair” relative to others. Instead, they accept being above average on some occasions and substantially below average (often at zero) on others, without converging to a stable, fairness-driven rule.

Risk tolerance appears moderate. They are willing to invest the full endowment into the public fund on multiple occasions, implying comfort with short-term “risk” of contributing when others might defect. However, the repeated switches to zero suggest that they are also guarding against the possibility of being exploited. Their pattern looks less like careful, fine-tuned risk management and more like opportunistic toggling between “join the co-op group” and “take advantage of it.”

Overall, their contributions reflect a player who understands that cooperation can be profitable in this environment but does not commit to sustaining it; they selectively support or exploit the cooperative norm depending on moment-to-moment incentives and perhaps mood or short-term payoff considerations.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
The player is aware of the finite horizon and shows a classic end-game shift toward non-cooperation. In the final stretch, they increasingly default to zero contributions, even while others commonly continue to contribute positively. This pattern indicates that as the number of remaining rounds shrinks, they become less willing to “invest” in the public fund and more inclined to secure private coins.

They do not attempt any terminal “gift” or last-round cooperative gesture. Instead, the final decision is to free-ride entirely, which is consistent with standard backward-induction reasoning: with no future rounds, there is no strategic value in maintaining a cooperative reputation. This supports the interpretation that their earlier cooperative moves are at least partly strategic and conditional on ongoing interaction, rather than purely driven by unconditional altruism.

The end-game response suggests the player treats cooperation as contingent on future benefits and continuation of the relationship. As continuation value approaches zero, their willingness to support the group decays, and they rely on others’ residual cooperation to maintain high payoffs for themselves.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
The player fits an “opportunistic alternating free-rider” type. They strongly prioritize personal payoff over group efficiency and repeatedly exploit others’ cooperation, but they occasionally switch to full contribution when group cooperation appears high and stable.

They only ever choose the two extremes: contributing nothing or the full endowment. There is no evidence of intermediate or gradual adjustments. This binary pattern suggests a simple, rule-like strategy rather than fine-grained calibration.

They frequently free-ride in the presence of substantial contributions by others. When others are contributing enough to generate sizable returns, the player often takes the entire endowment and relies on the group to fund the public account. This indicates low concern for fairness in the sense of matching others’ efforts, and a willingness to benefit from others without sharing the cost.

At several points, however, when overall cooperation in the group appears high, the player switches to full contribution. These cooperative episodes tend to occur when others are also contributing heavily and fairly consistently. This is consistent with conditional cooperation in an opportunistic form: the player is willing to help maintain a high-cooperation environment when it appears robust, but is not willing to be a “sucker” when cooperation weakens.

The player shows no loyalty to cooperative norms once cooperation wavers. When they observe drops in others’ contributions or more heterogeneous behavior, they revert quickly back to zero contribution. There is no sign of them “holding the line” to sustain the public good when others start scaling back; instead, they adjust in the self-protective direction.

Because they cannot punish or communicate, they express no direct norm-enforcement behavior. Their only lever is contribution, and they do not appear to use it to signal moral disapproval or to stabilize cooperation beyond what benefits them materially.

Risk tolerance appears moderate: they are willing to sometimes contribute fully when others are cooperating, accepting the short-run risk that others might free-ride. But they quickly hedge away from this risk when signals of group instability appear, preferring the safer personal gain from defection.

Overall, their default is self-regarding and exploitative, with episodic conditional cooperation when the environment is already cooperative enough that their contribution is likely to be matched and rewarded. They are not a pure free-rider, but their cooperative stance is fragile and heavily contingent on others’ behavior.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
The player is clearly aware of the game horizon and behaves in line with a backward-induction style intuition. As the end of the game approaches, they increasingly favor defection over cooperation, even when others continue to contribute substantially.

In the final stretch, they alternate between full contribution and full defection, but the last rounds are dominated by zero contributions despite continued high cooperation by some peers. There is no final-round “gift” or symbolic cooperative gesture; instead, they end on defection.

This pattern suggests that as remaining rounds shrink, the player downgrades the value of sustaining group cooperation and focuses more narrowly on extracting last-period gains. They do not attempt to preserve a cooperative environment for future mutual benefit once the future is short or nonexistent.

There is some residual variability near the end, indicating they are not following a perfectly mechanical “always defect at the end” rule. However, the overarching trend is a decay of cooperation as the terminal round approaches, consistent with strategic horizon awareness and a preference for late-game exploitation over sustained collective welfare.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a strategic, oscillating free-rider who alternates between full cooperation and full defection rather than using intermediate contributions. They use only the extremes of the action space: either keeping everything or contributing the entire endowment, with no partial amounts, suggesting a simple, rule-based heuristic rather than fine-tuned optimization.

Contribution levels are volatile over time but follow a clear conditional pattern. When they observe the group in a highly cooperative state (many peers making high or full contributions), they are willing to fully join the cooperative norm and contribute everything. When group cooperation looks weaker or more mixed, they revert to pure free-riding. They do not appear to punish low contributors through their own behavior in a sustained way; instead, they opportunistically exploit cooperative episodes and withdraw support when cooperation wavers.

They are highly responsive to the current social environment: their cooperative bursts line up with periods where most others are contributing generously. This implies a belief that cooperation can be temporarily profitable or normatively compelling when many others comply, but that there is no obligation to keep contributing once the group’s effort slackens. That is, they practice conditional cooperation with an opportunistic, self-serving tilt.

The player shows no evidence of strong fairness norms in the sense of maintaining their own contribution to match others’ average over time. They are comfortable taking large benefits during phases when others contribute much more than they do. However, they are not a pure, unyielding free-rider: they periodically shoulder a large cooperative burden by contributing fully when they perceive the environment as “worth it” or normatively salient.

Risk tolerance appears moderate. Contributing everything is risky in the sense that, if others defected, the payoff would be poor. The fact that they sometimes choose full contribution suggests they accept this risk when signals of group cooperation look strong. Conversely, they do not “experiment” with small contributions to probe the group; instead, they switch sharply between extremes, implying a coarse-grained evaluation: either “this group is cooperatively safe, so I go all in” or “this is not worth it, so I give nothing.”

Overall, this player is best described as a conditional, opportunistic cooperator who prefers to free-ride when group cooperation is moderate or fragile, and to contribute fully when cooperation appears robust and collectively beneficial.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
The player shows clear awareness of the finite horizon and behaves consistently with end-game defection. In the final portion of the game, they converge to a stable pattern of contributing nothing, even when others continue to contribute generously. There is no last-round “gift” or symbolic act of cooperation; they maintain defection through the final decision.

They do not display a gradual decay from cooperation to defection driven by frustration; instead, their earlier behavior already alternates between cooperative and non-cooperative phases. As the game approaches its conclusion, this alternation disappears and their strategy simplifies to persistent zero contributions. This shift suggests that, once the remaining opportunities for reciprocal benefits or norm-building become small, they prioritize securing individual payoffs over sustaining cooperation.

Their end-game conduct implies that they expect little or no future consequence—material or reputational—from their choices when rounds are nearly exhausted. They treat late rounds as chances to harvest benefits from others’ residual cooperation without feeling compelled to reciprocate. This aligns with a forward-looking, payoff-maximizing mindset that discounts long-term group outcomes as the horizon shortens.

In new environments, this player is likely to maintain some conditional cooperation when many rounds remain and others are cooperative, but to transition toward persistent free-riding as the end approaches, especially if there is no punishment or reputational mechanism to discipline late defection.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
The player is best described as a “principled high contributor with a late-game defection pivot.”

They consistently choose the maximum available contribution in almost all rounds, indicating a strong baseline preference for full cooperation rather than profit-maximizing free-riding. This pattern is stable for long stretches, with only a few, clearly delineated deviations late in the game. Their contributions do not track small fluctuations in others’ behavior; they continue to give fully even when the average contribution of others is modest or when there is visible free-riding. This suggests that they are not using a fine-grained conditional strategy (like strict tit-for-tat) but instead follow a simple rule of “generally contribute fully,” at least until the end of the horizon.

The exceptions to full contribution are isolated and occur only after extensive cooperative play. When they do reduce their contribution, they do so sharply rather than gradually. This shift points to a strategic awareness of the payoff structure and a willingness to exploit the public good once sufficient benefit has been amassed. The player therefore shows both cooperative inclination and instrumental rationality: they are willing to maintain cooperation even in the presence of defectors for many rounds, but they ultimately prioritize individual payoff when the remaining time is short.

They appear tolerant of inequality and free-riding for most of the game, as they keep contributing maximally despite some others contributing little or nothing. Their behavior does not indicate strong negative reciprocity or punishment motives (explicit punishment is unavailable, and they do not “punish” by reducing contributions when others defect mid-game). Their risk tolerance seems relatively high regarding trusting the group: they repeatedly expose themselves to the risk of being exploited and do not hedge by contributing intermediate amounts during most of the horizon. Fairness norms appear to be present in the sense that they support a high-contribution regime, but these norms are not strict enough to prevent an eventual switch to self-serving low contributions once the end is near.

Overall, they behave like an intrinsically cooperative type who adopts a simple, generous strategy early and mid-game, with a calculated, non-gradual shift toward selfishness close to the end, rather than a constantly conditional or spasmodically reactive contributor.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
The player clearly exhibits horizon awareness and an end-game effect.

For the majority of the game, they maintain full cooperation, even when others’ contributions vary and when free-riding is evident. This persistence implies that the eventual drop in contributions is not driven by ongoing disappointment or gradual erosion of trust, but is more tightly linked to the knowledge that the game is finite and approaching its conclusion.

As the remaining number of rounds becomes small, they shift from their long-standing pattern of full contribution to low or zero contributions. This transition is abrupt rather than incremental, indicating a deliberate strategic pivot rather than a slow decay in cooperation. Once they start reducing contributions near the end, they do not revert back to a fully cooperative stance in the final round, instead moving to complete free-riding at the very end. This aligns with a classic end-game defection pattern: they take advantage of the group’s continued cooperation when reputational or future-round concerns are nearly irrelevant.

The pattern suggests that earlier cooperation is likely sustained by a mix of intrinsic prosocial preference and forward-looking reasoning (“cooperate while many rounds remain, because mutual cooperation is valuable”), whereas the final-round choices reveal that, given a clear horizon and no punishment/reward mechanisms, they are willing to exploit the public good when future consequences are negligible. Their end-game behavior therefore shows that they are not a pure unconditional cooperator; they are a conditional cooperator whose condition is primarily tied to time horizon and future-interaction value, rather than directly to fine-grained observation of others’ current contributions.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
The player is a “conditionally generous cooperator with mild opportunism.” They reliably give a substantial share of their endowment, often at or above the group’s central tendency, but they do not commit to a rigid norm like “always give everything.” Instead, they oscillate mainly between moderate and full contributions, occasionally dropping to low or zero when the environment appears already strongly cooperative or when they test the limits of free-riding.

Their baseline seems to be a medium–high contribution: they frequently choose values around half their endowment and regularly move up to the maximum when others appear to be cooperating at high levels. This pattern suggests they recognize and respond to the marginal per-capita return: they behave as if they understand that contributing is collectively efficient and often act in favor of that efficiency, but they are not purely altruistic. The one clear free-riding instance—taking the entire endowment while others continue to contribute heavily—indicates a willingness to exploit strong public cooperation at least occasionally.

Contribution choices are somewhat volatile but not erratic: they vary within a constrained band (from full free-ride in one case up to full contribution, and otherwise mostly medium–high amounts). Changes appear to be conditional on recent group behavior, not random. When the environment looks highly cooperative, the player tends to sustain or raise contributions, but they also sometimes “reward” a very cooperative environment by temporarily taking more for themselves, suggesting a self-interested balancing rather than a strict fairness rule.

Fairness norms are present but flexible. The player often contributes in a way that is roughly proportionate to the apparent group effort and does not systematically undercut high contributors. However, they do not insist on matching the most generous peers; they appear comfortable being slightly below the top cooperators while still contributing enough to support the public fund. This points to a norm of “doing one’s share” rather than “leading by example at all costs.”

Risk tolerance appears moderate. The player is repeatedly willing to put substantial amounts at stake even when some others defect or contribute very little, indicating some tolerance for the risk of being exploited. Yet the occasional downward adjustment and the isolated full free-ride show that they also hedge against being the “sucker” and are attentive to payoff implications.

Overall, their strategy is best characterized as adaptive conditional cooperation: they prioritize group efficiency and are usually generous, but they retain enough flexibility to protect their own payoff and to occasionally test how much they can benefit from others’ contributions.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
The player shows awareness of the finite horizon but does not strongly unravel their cooperation near the end. In the final phase of the game they continue to make substantial contributions, sometimes at the maximum level and sometimes at a medium–high level, without any clear downward trend toward full defection. There is no evidence of a systematic end-game collapse in their own strategy.

Instead of gradually decreasing contributions as the last rounds approach, they maintain their established pattern of conditional generosity with some variation. Their behavior suggests that they either discount the classical backward-induction logic, prioritize maintaining a cooperative norm for its own sake, or simply continue to apply the same myopic, round-by-round conditional rule without special adjustment for the fact that the game is ending.

The absence of a sharp final-round free-ride, and the presence of a high final contribution, implies that they do not treat the end-game as a unique opportunity to exploit the group. Their horizon awareness is observable in the sense that they know the number of rounds, but their decisions indicate either limited strategic use of that information or a preference structure in which sustaining cooperation remains valuable even when there is no future interaction in this specific game.
