text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a predominantly low contributor who intermittently makes medium or high contributions when others are clearly sustaining high cooperation. Across the game, they more often keep the full endowment than not, indicating a primary incentive to maximize individual payoff rather than to consistently support the public fund.

Their pattern is conditional rather than random: when the group’s average contribution is high and widespread cooperation is visible, they sometimes shift to contributing a substantial portion of their endowment, occasionally even the full amount. When contributions from others drop or become more uneven, they revert to zero. This suggests that they recognizes the efficiency of the public good and is willing to participate when they perceive a reliably cooperative environment, but they are not willing to be a “pillar” of cooperation when others seem less committed.

Contribution levels show a limited range of voluntary sacrifice. They move between no contribution, partial contributions roughly around half the endowment, and, more rarely, full contributions. The willingness to sometimes give up the whole endowment, but only in cooperative contexts, indicates moderate risk tolerance with strong reliance on social cues: they take the “risk” of contributing more only when free-riding risk appears low because many others are contributing heavily.

They does not appear to enforce or follow a strict fairness norm like “match the group average” or “always give half.” Instead, they behaves more like a cautious opportunist: they exploits cooperative periods by sometimes free-riding and sometimes joining in, and they systematically exploit low-contribution periods by not contributing. There is no evidence that they tries to lead the group toward higher cooperation; rather, they adapts to it when it exists and withdraws support when it weakens.

Overall, their cooperation is unstable and reactive. They is capable of cooperative behavior but does not internalize a firm norm of consistent fairness. Their default is self-interested low contribution, softened by occasional conditional cooperation when the environment looks very favorable.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
This player shows no strong, classic “end-game collapse” where contributions steadily decline as the final rounds approach. Instead, their contribution pattern near the end remains inconsistent and conditional, similar to earlier behavior.

In late rounds, they alternates between zero and moderate contributions, sometimes making a substantial contribution even very close to the final decision. This indicates that they is aware of the game horizon (they can see how many rounds remain) but does not simply apply a backward-induction logic of “always defect at the end.” Instead, they continues to condition contributions on the perceived cooperativeness of the group, even when only a few rounds are left.

There is no clear escalation of generosity in the final round, nor a complete shutdown of cooperation. The final decisions look like another instance of the same rule they uses earlier: when others appear to be contributing reasonably well, they sometimes join in with a nontrivial contribution; when conditions look less favorable, they contributes nothing. Any end-game adjustment is subtle at most and cannot be clearly distinguished from their overall conditional, opportunistic style.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a highly stable, moderately cooperative contributor who anchors on a fixed, mid-level contribution and almost never deviates. Across the game, they contribute the same amount in nearly every round, with only a single, brief upward adjustment. This pattern indicates a rule-based or heuristic strategy (“stick to a chosen amount”) rather than round-by-round recalculation or emotional reacting.

They appear to adopt a compromise between self-interest and group interest: they give enough to clearly support the public fund but keep a substantial portion each round. Their contribution is typically below the modal high contributors yet far above consistent free-riders, suggesting a “moderate cooperator” or “tempered contributor” type.

Their behavior is weakly conditional on others: when the group swings from very high to much lower cooperation, they do not systematically ramp up or cut back. The single upward deviation coincides with a generally high-cooperation environment, which may indicate some weak positive reciprocity or a test of slightly higher giving, but they quickly revert to their baseline. There is no evidence of punitive withholding or retaliatory under-contribution when others defect.

They show no signs of risk-seeking experimentation (e.g., trying extreme contributions or zero) despite substantial variation in group behavior and returns. This points to moderate risk aversion and a preference for predictability over chasing marginal gains.

Their fairness norm seems to be “steady, reasonable contribution” rather than strict matching. They neither try to maximize their own payoff at the group’s expense nor sacrifice a lot to match the highest cooperators. They tolerate the presence of both strong cooperators and low contributors without visibly adjusting, so they likely accept some payoff inequality as the cost of sticking to a simple personal rule.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
This player shows no classic end-game unraveling. Contributions remain at their established baseline through the final phase, including the very last round, with no visible decay, escalation, or switching to exploitation even when they know the game is about to end. They do not ratchet contributions up to be altruistic “on the way out,” nor do they drop to free-ride in the final opportunities.

The lack of horizon effects suggests they either (a) are not strategically focused on the finite horizon, (b) prioritize following their internal contribution rule over short-run optimization, or (c) do not strongly believe that others will change behavior at the end and therefore see no reason to adjust. In new PGG environments, this indicates that their cooperation level is likely governed more by a stable personal policy than by forward-looking end-game logic, and that they maintain that policy even when continuation incentives disappear.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
The player is a strict, stable free-rider. They consistently contribute nothing in every decision, regardless of others’ behavior, the average contribution level, or changes in group size. Their strategy does not exhibit exploration or adjustment; it is a fixed rule rather than a reactive or conditional approach.

They appear to reason in payoff-maximizing terms given the game’s structure: the marginal per-capita return is below 1, so keeping the full endowment strictly dominates contributing from an individual-profit perspective. Their behavior aligns with a purely self-interested best response in a linear PGG without punishment or reputation consequences.

They do not follow reciprocity or fairness norms. They continue to free-ride even when others are clearly contributing very high amounts and could plausibly expect mutual cooperation. The player shows no tendency to “reward” cooperative episodes with partial giving, nor to “sanction” low-contribution periods with any change in their own behavior; they simply ignore these social signals.

Risk tolerance in contribution space is effectively irrelevant for them because they never stake any coins on the public fund. This indicates either high aversion to downside risk for oneself, complete disregard for group payoffs, or both. Given that they repeatedly enjoy high returns generated by others without ever sharing costs, they are comfortable benefiting from positive externalities with no evident guilt or corrective impulse (though internal motivations are unknown).

The contribution pattern is highly stable and non-volatile: there are no switches, partial contributions, or reactive spikes. This stability suggests a pre-committed strategy (“always keep everything”) rather than trial-and-error learning. Conditional cooperation, inequality aversion, or norms of proportionality are not expressed in their actions.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
The player shows no end-game shift because their baseline behavior is already full defection. They begin with zero contributions and maintain this level through the final decision. As a result, there is no visible decay or escalation in cooperation tied to the known time horizon; their play is horizon-invariant.

Awareness of the number of remaining rounds does not alter their strategy in any detectable way. Since they never cooperate at any point, they have no cooperative posture to unwind as the end approaches, nor do they attempt any last-round exploitation spike (they are already exploiting the group from the outset).

From an inferential standpoint, this is consistent with a belief that contributing is never privately optimal, regardless of stage in the game, and that others’ tendencies to contribute can be treated as an exogenous resource to harvest rather than a pattern to cultivate or preserve. Whether they consciously model others as potentially reacting to their free-riding is unknown, but their unchanging strategy implies low concern for sustaining future cooperation.

In new PGG environments with similar incentives and no effective sanctions or reputational mechanisms, this player type is expected to defect from the start and stay that way, independent of remaining rounds or observed shifts in group behavior.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a *rigid full cooperator*. They always contribute their entire endowment and never adjust, regardless of others’ behavior or payoff fluctuations. Their contributions are maximally stable and show no volatility or contingent response to free-riding, partial cooperation, or shifts in overall group contribution levels.

They follow a simple, fixed rule: fully invest in the public fund every time. This suggests they prioritize the social optimum or a strong internal norm over individual payoff maximization. They do not appear to condition on fairness (others contributing less does not reduce their own contributions, and spikes in group cooperation do not increase them because they are already at the maximum). There is no evidence that they try to match, punish, reward, or strategically respond to particular peers’ patterns.

Given that the marginal per capita return is above 1 for the group but below 1 individually, this unwavering full contribution implies high tolerance for exploitation risk. They are willing to be taken advantage of by low contributors, at least within the confines of the game, and do not hedge or “test” the group. They behave as if the correct or expected thing is to cooperate fully, independent of short-term personal incentives.

Their behavior is consistent with a strong, possibly unconditional prosocial or rule-following orientation: once they understand that contributions benefit the group, they lock into the cooperative option and do not deviate. There is no observed learning curve or strategic experimentation; if learning happens, it is completed before or immediately at the start of observed play.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
The player shows no visible end-game effect. Their strategy remains unchanged when the game is near completion: they keep contributing fully even when the remaining number of rounds is small and when many others either maintain cooperative behavior or drop/oscillate. There is no sign of the typical cooperation decay, last-round defection, or even a mild reduction in contributions as the horizon approaches.

This suggests that they either do not factor the finite horizon into their strategy, or they choose to ignore it in favor of a fixed cooperation norm. They act as if the time horizon is irrelevant to what they “should” do. If they reason about the end-game, they still prefer to maintain a consistent cooperative identity rather than exploit the final rounds.

Overall, they appear to be a time-invariant, principle-driven cooperator whose behavior is not strategically altered by approaching termination.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
The player is a strict, unwavering full cooperator. They always allocate their entire endowment to the public fund, regardless of changes in group behavior, fluctuations in others’ average contributions, or variations in their own payoff. Their contribution pattern is perfectly stable and shows no experimentation, no reciprocity dynamics, and no evident response to free-riding or to high-cooperation episodes.

They behave as if guided by an internal rule like “always contribute everything,” rather than by short-term payoff optimization. There is no indication that they condition on the previous round’s average contribution, on the distribution of free-riders vs. cooperators, or on trends in cooperation. They display extreme tolerance for exploitation: they continue maximal contributions even when a sizeable subset of others consistently contributes little or nothing.

They likely operate with a strong efficiency or prosocial norm, acting as though the socially optimal action is to always give the full amount, and that this norm should be followed even if others do not fully comply. Because they never deviate, it is unknown whether they would adjust if the marginal per capita return were below 1; their behavior here is consistent with either principled cooperation or with a simple rule that coincides with both altruism and self-interest when cooperation is efficient.

Their risk tolerance in the social sense is high: they repeatedly risk being the “sucker” in the presence of free-riding. At the same time, they show no risk-taking in the strategic sense—they never try mixed strategies, intermediate contributions, or responsive adjustments. They appear rule-based and predictable rather than opportunistic or exploratory.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
The player shows no end-game defection or decay in cooperation. Their contribution level remains at the maximum until and including the final round, despite having full knowledge of the round horizon. They do not exhibit the commonly observed pattern of gradually lowering contributions as the game approaches its conclusion, nor do they react to others’ variable behavior near the end.

This suggests that their strategy is not anchored in backward induction or finite-horizon reasoning, but in a time-invariant norm: “I contribute fully every round,” irrespective of how many rounds remain. There is no evidence of last-round opportunism, payoff grabbing, or even subtle shading down of contributions. Their end-game behavior reinforces the view that they are a principled, norm-following cooperator whose choices do not hinge on future interaction or on maintaining reputational incentives within the game.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a flexible, payoff‑attentive conditional cooperator with mild opportunistic tendencies. They are willing to move between full contribution, partial contribution, and zero contribution rather than follow a fixed rule. Early in the game they shift from taking everything to contributing fully once they see others putting in substantial amounts, suggesting sensitivity to group norms and the potential gains from cooperation. They usually match or exceed the group’s average rather than undercut it when they are in a cooperative phase, implying a fairness‑oriented norm when they are engaged in the social dilemma.

Their contributions are not monotonic; they alternate between high and zero contributions across the game. These switches align with changes in group behavior and recent punishment history, indicating strategic responsiveness rather than random play. They do not appear to maximize narrow self‑interest at all times: in many situations they choose high contributions that leave them vulnerable to being exploited or punished, so material payoff is important but not the sole driver. They show no strong evidence of risk aversion or risk seeking; instead, their risk tolerance appears context‑dependent, increasing when cooperation looks stable and decreasing when they perceive instability or hostility. Overall, they act as a pragmatic conditional cooperator who is willing to free‑ride when they feel targeted or when sustaining cooperation seems unlikely.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
The player shows clear horizon awareness and adjusts behavior as the game nears its conclusion. Cooperation decays rather than escalates at the end. In the final phase, they move away from consistent high contributions toward zero or reduced contributions, exhibiting a classic end‑game effect: with fewer future rounds to benefit from reputation or norm enforcement, they become more willing to free‑ride.

This shift suggests that their earlier cooperation is at least partly strategic—aimed at sustaining mutual gains over multiple rounds—rather than purely intrinsic altruism. When the remaining number of rounds is small, they increasingly prioritize immediate personal payoff over maintaining cooperative norms, indicating a forward‑looking but finite‑horizon mindset. They do not attempt a late “moral signal” of continued high cooperation in the final decision; instead, they align with a payoff‑maximizing exit strategy once future reciprocity is effectively unavailable.

<PUNISHMENT>
The player uses punishment sparingly and selectively. They mostly refrain from punishing, even when others contribute less than they do, implying that they do not have a strong, automatic drive to sanction all norm violators. When they do spend on punishment, it appears targeted rather than diffuse; they are willing to incur a nontrivial cost to impose significant deductions on specific individuals. This indicates that they view punishment as a tool for either enforcing norms or expressing disapproval, not as something to deploy routinely.

Because they punish in only a minority of opportunities, and only after having experienced notable deductions themselves, their motive is ambiguous between norm enforcement and retaliation. There is some indication that punishment is tied to frustration with particular partners rather than pure concern for group efficiency. They do not escalate into repeated or large punishment campaigns, suggesting limits to vindictiveness and a preference to contain conflict. They also do not use punishment to reward or protect high contributors (as reward is unavailable and they do not “counter‑punish” low punishers), so their sanctioning is focused on negative behavior, not on building alliances. Overall, they are a reluctant punisher who intervenes occasionally when provoked or when inequities become salient.

<RESPONSE_TO_PUNISHER>
The player is repeatedly punished across the game and appears to notice and react to this, but not in a simple or purely compliant way. They do not consistently respond to being punished by increasing contributions; in some subsequent decisions they continue to contribute at high levels, while in others they reduce or drop their contributions. This pattern suggests that punishment does not straightforwardly train them into stable cooperation. Instead, they sometimes comply and sometimes withdraw cooperation, depending on the broader context.

They also occasionally punish others after experiencing deductions, indicating a willingness to answer sanctions with counter‑sanctions in at least some instances. This hints at a mixture of deterrence sensitivity and retaliatory impulse: they do not passively accept being targeted, yet they also do not spiral into unrestrained revenge. Since punishers are identifiable, their continued willingness to cooperate in some later rounds with likely punishers reflects partial forgiveness or at least pragmatic tolerance when cooperation still seems beneficial. Their stance toward punishers is thus mixed: they neither consistently reward them with higher compliance nor systematically retaliate; instead, they adjust both contributions and occasional punishment in a nuanced, context‑dependent way. Overall, they behave like a cautious, somewhat proud cooperator who resents arbitrary or repeated deductions and will sometimes push back, but not at all costs.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a strategically flexible, conditionally cooperative low–to‑medium contributor who alternates between free‑riding and substantial giving. Early on, the player contributes substantially less than the group average while still participating in the public fund, indicating a willingness to free‑ride when others appear generous. As the game progresses, they occasionally match or approach high cooperative norms, but these higher contributions are not stable; they intersperse generous rounds with clear downshifts back to low giving. Their behavior suggests they adjust contributions in light of observed group behavior and perhaps recent punishment dynamics, rather than following a fixed rule.

They do not appear to follow a strict fairness norm such as “match the average” or “equalize contributions”; instead, they sometimes contribute much less than high contributors, and at other times contribute at or near the maximum even when others are mixed. This pattern is consistent with a player who is exploring payoff‑relevant strategies under uncertainty about others, rather than a principled fairness maximizer. Risk tolerance is moderate: they are willing to deviate visibly from cooperative norms (both upward and downward) despite identifiable punishment, but they also show some responsiveness to how cooperative the group looks, suggesting they weigh the risk of sanctions against potential gains from free‑riding or from sustaining the public good. Their contribution path is best described as adaptive and somewhat opportunistic rather than stable or purely self‑interested.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
The player shows awareness of the finite horizon: near the end, their contributions decline after periods of higher cooperation. Instead of ramping up giving to “leave on a good note,” they move toward lower contributions again, consistent with standard end‑game defection logic. However, this shift is not a sudden collapse from consistently high cooperation; it is a return to lower giving after a sequence of mixed strategies. There is no clear attempt to use the final round(s) to repay kindness, repair norms, or retaliate strongly; rather, the end phase fits a pattern of continued experimentation with some inclination to keep more for themselves once only a few rounds remain. Overall, they display some cooperation decay toward the end, but overlaying an already volatile pattern, making precise inference of horizon thinking low confidence beyond “they do not lock into full cooperation as the game closes.”

<PUNISHMENT>
The player is a frequent and relatively heavy user of punishment, willing to incur substantial personal costs to sanction others across many stages of the game. Punishment is not confined to clear, extreme free‑riders: they also punish in contexts where others appear highly cooperative, implying that their criteria for sanctioning are broader than simply “very low contributors.” It is plausible (but not certain) that they target specific individuals whose contributions they perceive as systematically lower or norm‑violating relative to others in the same round, rather than indiscriminately sanctioning everyone. However, there is at least one phase in which they refrain from punishing despite the presence of conspicuously low contributions, which suggests their use of punishment is selective and contextual, not automatic.

The repeated willingness to spend more than the minimum on punishment indicates an enforcement‑oriented mindset: they seem to treat punishment as a tool to shape others’ behavior or to express disapproval, rather than as a last‑resort, purely payoff‑maximizing decision. Whether they aim primarily at efficiency (deterrence) or at expressing frustration/resentment is unknown. Given the presence of pro‑social and anti‑social punishment both being common in such environments, and since they sometimes punish when they themselves are relatively low contributors, they may engage in both norm enforcement and competitive/hostile punishment at different times. Overall, they are a punishment‑prone, non‑pacifist player who accepts efficiency losses to influence others.

<RESPONSE_TO_PUNISHER>
When they are punished, their subsequent behavior does not show a simple, consistent compliance response such as “I was punished, so I permanently raise my contributions” or “I was punished, so I stop punishing.” After receiving a sanction, they later choose both high and low contribution levels again, and they resume using punishment themselves. This suggests they do not interpret punishment solely as a credible deterrent that must be obeyed; instead, they seem to treat it as one signal among many, or possibly as an unfair or contested action that does not fully dictate their strategy.

There is no clear evidence of direct retaliation against specific punishers, although the data do not reveal their exact punishment targets, so retaliation cannot be ruled out. What can be said is that they do not become passive or withdraw from the punishment mechanism after being targeted. Nor do they clearly “forgive” in the sense of shifting into stable high cooperation; instead, they continue their mixed pattern of contributions and enforcement. Their response profile is best described as emotionally or strategically resilient: being punished does not visibly silence their willingness to punish others, nor does it lock them into a submissive, norm‑following contribution level. Their stance toward punishers is thus active and somewhat defiant, or at least non‑compliant in a straightforward way, though the underlying motives (resentment, experimentation, or indifference) remain unknown.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a generally high contributor who anchors near or above the group average whenever others cooperate, and lowers contributions only when the environment looks unstable or unfair. They are clearly not a pure free‑rider: they repeatedly give most or all of their endowment to the public fund, even when multipliers and others’ past behavior make lower contributions individually profitable. Their pattern shows conditional cooperation with a prosocial baseline: they are willing to contribute a lot if they see others doing the same, and they do not require perfect symmetry to stay generous. They appear to care about fairness but not in a rigid “exact matching” way; they tolerate some variation as long as there is no blatant exploitation. When others’ behavior becomes erratic or includes very low or zero contributions, they adjust downward, but they do not collapse to zero or clearly defect; rather, they reduce somewhat while still contributing nontrivially. This suggests a mixture of efficiency and reciprocity motives rather than pure payoff maximization. Their contributions do not drift randomly; they change in response to observed patterns in peers’ behavior, indicating strategic, belief‑based adaptation rather than noise. Overall, they behave like a conditional cooperator with some willingness to “lead” by contributing high amounts, especially when cooperation seems viable.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
The player appears aware of the finite horizon but does not strongly unravel their cooperation near the end. Their contributions late in the game remain substantial: they do not shift to a purely self‑interested, low‑contribution strategy as the last round approaches. There is some adjustment in the final phase, with contributions becoming more moderate rather than maximal, but the player still contributes a meaningful share of their endowment in the last round. This suggests they either discount the classic backward‑induction logic or give weight to intrinsic or fairness motives that persist even when future retaliation or reward is impossible. There is no evidence of a strategic “last‑round grab”; instead, their end‑game response looks like a cautious reduction in generosity under uncertainty, not a collapse of cooperation. Overall, end‑game awareness is present but does not dominate their cooperative disposition.

<PUNISHMENT>
The player is willing to use costly punishment selectively. They do not punish every deviation, but they do sometimes pay to impose deductions. Given that punishment is costly and relatively powerful, their occasional use suggests they value norm enforcement or retaliation enough to sacrifice payoff at times. The timing of their punishment choices is consistent with responding to perceived unfairness or norm violations rather than punishing randomly. They do not appear to be a relentless enforcer; they leave some low or zero contributions unpunished, implying some threshold before they act—possibly when they see either particularly stark under‑contribution relative to others or a pattern they interpret as intentional exploitation. Their punishment behavior is infrequent enough that they are not spiteful or punishment‑focused by default; instead, they resemble a conditional punisher who intervenes when cooperation is threatened or when they feel clearly wronged. Whether they aim mainly at deterrence (to improve future group contributions) or at expressing disapproval/retaliation is uncertain, but the fact that punishment appears even when they themselves have not been heavily exploited by the target suggests at least some norm‑enforcing motive, not purely self‑protection. Overall, they are a moderate, selective punisher with a fairness and reciprocity orientation.

<RESPONSE_TO_PUNISHER>
The player is punished multiple times. Their behavioral response is not to disengage or switch to opportunistic low contributions; instead, after being punished they continue to contribute at high levels in subsequent rounds when cooperation around them looks viable. This indicates they do not react with simple spite or immediate retaliation against the punisher(s). They also do not show obvious appeasement behavior (like dramatically over‑contributing relative to others right after punishment), but they maintain or resume substantial contributions, which can be interpreted as cooperative resilience or partial compliance with an inferred norm of higher giving. Their use of punishment after having been punished themselves suggests they do not categorically reject punishment as illegitimate; they seem to accept it as part of the interaction repertoire. There is no clear evidence that they target the same individuals who punished them (identity of punishers is not observable in the transcript), so we cannot reliably infer direct counter‑punishment or targeted revenge; that remains unknown. What is clear is that being punished does not cause them to abandon cooperation, and they remain willing to enforce norms themselves. In personality terms, they respond to punishment with robustness and continued engagement rather than withdrawal or clear retaliation, combining a willingness to punish with a relatively forgiving or at least forward‑looking cooperative stance.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a highly variable, opportunistic conditional cooperator. Contributions range from none to full endowment, with no simple monotone trend. The player adjusts behavior in response to the group’s recent contribution pattern rather than following a fixed rule.

They sometimes match or exceed the apparent group norm when others are contributing substantially, but they also free-ride even in clearly cooperative environments. Conversely, they occasionally contribute very generously when surrounded by low or mixed contributions. This pattern suggests experimentation and local payoff-sensitivity rather than a stable fairness norm.

They does not appear to follow a strict “tit-for-tat” or “match-the-average” rule; instead, they oscillate between exploitative low contributions and pro-social high contributions, likely probing which strategy yields better returns. There is no clear evidence of strong inequality aversion or strict reciprocity norms, since they neither consistently match others’ levels nor systematically avoid being below or above peers. Risk tolerance seems moderate: they are willing to take payoff risks by contributing high even when recent treatment by the group is negative, implying that they do not purely optimize short-term income.

Overall, they fit a “strategic experimenter / unstable conditional cooperator” type: sensitive to context and incentives, but without a firmly anchored social norm guiding contributions.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
The player shows no classical end-game defection pattern. Instead of ramping down cooperation near the final rounds, they continue to mix mid-range and maximal contributions, including very high giving at the very end despite prior negative treatment.

This suggests that horizon awareness does not dominate their strategy; they either discount the importance of the final-round payoff or maintain a cooperative or experimental stance regardless of remaining rounds. There is no clear evidence of increasing selfishness or tightening exploitation as the game approaches termination. If anything, their late-game behavior remains erratic and occasionally generous, indicating that they do not strongly condition on the finite horizon when choosing actions.

<PUNISHMENT>
The player never uses the punishment option, despite having multiple opportunities and facing both low-contributing peers and personal deductions imposed by others. They consistently refrain from spending on sanctions even when there are clear “targets” (e.g., low contributors or evident punishers).

This pattern indicates a strong reluctance to engage in costly punishment. They appear unwilling to trade off their own payoff to enforce norms, and there is no behavioral sign of using punishment for deterrence, retaliation, or norm expression. Their strategy treats the punishment technology as effectively irrelevant or too costly relative to its benefits.

Given the absence of any punishing action, underlying motives remain uncertain: they might disapprove of costly sanctions on moral grounds, doubt their effectiveness, or simply prioritize personal earnings. All of these remain speculative; the only robust inference is that they are a non-punisher even under provocation.

<RESPONSE_TO_PUNISHER>
The player is repeatedly punished but never retaliates via the punishment mechanism, even though punishers are identifiable and punishment recurs across different contribution choices. They also do not reliably “comply” with an implied norm from punishers: sometimes they respond to previous negative treatment with higher contributions, sometimes with lower or unchanged levels. There is no stable shift toward either strict conformity or sustained defection after being sanctioned.

Their behavior thus suggests a mix of tolerance and independence. They do not use punishment for revenge and do not clearly adopt a submissive stance of norm-following in response to being targeted. Instead, they continue to adjust contributions in their own exploratory pattern, with limited observable deference to punishers’ signals.

Forgiveness versus indifference is unclear: they may internally register the unfairness or harshness of sanctions, but behaviorally they neither escalate conflict nor systematically accommodate the punishers’ likely preferences. Overall, they can be characterized as a non-retaliatory, strategically independent player who does not let identifiable punishment strongly dictate future actions.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a predominantly unconditional high contributor with occasional, deliberate deviations. Their default is to give the maximum possible amount and they sustain this pattern through essentially the entire game, despite observing repeated under-contribution by at least one peer. This indicates a strong prosocial or efficiency-oriented motive that is not easily undermined by free-riding.

Their contribution pattern is highly stable and predictable: maximum giving is the norm, while reductions are rare, discrete events rather than the start of a downward trend. These few low-contribution choices appear exploratory or retaliatory tests rather than a full strategy shift. Across the game, they repeatedly return to the maximum-contribution baseline immediately after such deviations, suggesting that high cooperation is their reference point.

They exhibit some conditionality: they do occasionally free-ride or partially free-ride when others’ contributions drop or when the group has recently shown reliability. However, these episodes are sparse and short-lived. The player seems to be checking (a) how much personal gain is possible from defecting and (b) whether the group’s cooperation will collapse in response. Once they confirm that others remain largely cooperative, they revert to full contributions. This indicates that they value both payoff and group efficiency but prioritize sustaining cooperation over systematically exploiting it.

Normatively, they appear to hold a strong fairness and efficiency norm that “everyone should give fully.” Their behavior is consistent with someone who treats full contribution as the socially appropriate baseline and tolerates some deviation by others without abandoning that norm. When they do deviate, they do not push the system toward full collapse; instead, they test the margin and quickly re-align with the high-contribution convention. This suggests they see themselves as a cooperator first, not as an opportunistic free-rider.

Risk tolerance is moderately high in a social sense. Continuing to fully contribute even when a free-rider or partial free-rider is present exposes them to exploitation in the short run. They still take that risk, implying trust in the group’s overall cooperative orientation and/or a focus on maximizing total group returns rather than strictly securing their own relative advantage. At the same time, their rare defection episodes show they are not naive: they are aware of the payoff structure and are willing to temporarily prioritize self-gain, especially when they anticipate that group cooperation is robust enough to survive it.

In summary, this player is best characterized as a “principled high contributor with opportunistic tests”: they default to full cooperation, strongly support a high-contribution norm, occasionally probe the limits of that norm through brief free-riding or partial contributions, then reliably return to maximal giving once the test is complete.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a predominantly high contributor who mixes genuine cooperation with calculated free-riding. They usually give the full endowment when the group appears cohesive and generous, but intermittently drop their contribution well below the group norm to exploit others’ cooperation.

Their contribution pattern is moderately volatile rather than stable. Periods of full cooperation are punctuated by occasional medium contributions and a few very low or zero contributions. These reductions do not follow a simple “tit-for-tat” with individual defectors; instead, they reflect opportunistic tests of how much they can keep while still benefiting from a generally cooperative group.

They appear to understand that the public good is highly efficient and that full contribution is socially optimal, as evidenced by their repeated willingness to match a high-contribution environment. At the same time, they are clearly attentive to payoff differences and are willing to trade off social efficiency for personal gain when it looks safe to do so. This indicates a blend of cooperative preference and self-interested optimization rather than pure altruism or pure free-riding.

Fairness norms seem conditional and asymmetric. The player is willing to contribute fully for long stretches even when an isolated peer defects, suggesting a tolerance for some level of unfairness or a focus on maintaining group output over immediate reciprocity. However, when the group remains very cooperative, they sometimes drop their own contribution sharply while others keep contributing at or near the maximum. In those moments they violate strict equality norms in their own favor, implying that fairness is not a dominant motive when it conflicts strongly with personal payoff.

They show some responsiveness to visible defections but not in a purely retaliatory way. Isolated low contributions by others do not reliably trigger immediate punishment via their own defection; instead, the player continues to contribute highly through several such events and only occasionally reduces their own contribution later. This delayed and inconsistent adjustment suggests exploratory or profit-maximizing tinkering rather than emotionally driven reciprocity.

Risk tolerance appears moderate. The player is willing to risk being the lone free-rider in an otherwise cooperative group in order to earn high payoffs, which involves reputational or moral risk in many PGG contexts (even though no sanctions are available here). Yet they do not persistently defect; they revert frequently to full contributions, indicating caution about undermining the group’s cooperative equilibrium and the resulting efficiency loss. Overall, their persona fits a “strategic conditional cooperator with opportunistic leanings”: someone who prefers and sustains high cooperation but intermittently exploits it when they see a chance to personally gain without immediately collapsing the group’s contributions.

This player is an extremely stable high contributor who effectively treats full contribution as a default rule. They consistently allocate their entire endowment to the public fund across almost all decisions, with a single, isolated deviation to a still-high contribution rather than to defection. That one deviation does not trigger a broader behavioral shift; they immediately revert to full contributions afterward. This pattern suggests they use a simple, rule-based strategy rather than fine-grained conditional cooperation.

They appear to anchor on the social optimum and maintain it even when others visibly free-ride or partially defect. Drops in group contributions, including clear low or zero contributions by multiple group members, do not produce retaliation or even moderate downward adjustment from this player. Their contribution pattern is therefore largely unconditional with respect to short-term changes in others’ behavior.

Given the multiplier and group size, full contribution is payoff-maximizing at the group level but not individually dominant. The player’s adherence to full contribution, despite frequent opportunities to increase personal payoff by free-riding, indicates either: (a) a strong internal fairness or efficiency norm that prioritizes group welfare, (b) a preference for strategy simplicity over responsive optimization, or (c) a belief that stable high contributions by everyone will be maintained if they themselves never waiver. Which of these dominates is unknown, but their behavior is consistent with a high intrinsic motivation to cooperate.

The lone reduction in contribution late in the game suggests some sensitivity to group-level wavering or experimentation, but it is not sustained and does not escalate. This looks more like a brief test or moment of doubt than a shift to self-interest. Their subsequent immediate return to full contribution, even when others’ behavior had recently been noisy, implies a high tolerance for the risk of being exploited and a willingness to absorb some inequity to keep the cooperative norm intact.

Overall, this player is best described as a “near-unconditional full cooperator with very high norm adherence and very low reactivity.” They maintain cooperation under adverse conditions, rarely adjust to others, and exhibit high risk tolerance regarding potential exploitation in pursuit of collective efficiency.

This player is a strongly pro-social, high-contribution cooperator with occasional, targeted free-riding tests. Their default is to contribute the full endowment whenever the group appears broadly cooperative, and they maintain this pattern even when a few others intermittently reduce contributions. They shows very high baseline generosity and a stable willingness to sustain near-maximal public-good provision.

Contribution levels are generally stable and clustered at the maximum, with only a few deliberate deviations. Those deviations are not random: they appear when others have just behaved cooperatively, suggesting intentional experimentation with free-riding rather than emotional retaliation. When the group is fully cooperative, the player at times briefly contributes nothing or a partial amount, then quickly returns to full contribution. This indicates:  
- They understand the payoff structure and test whether they can exploit a cooperative group.  
- They do not convert those tests into a long-run defection strategy; they revert to high contribution even after a profitable free-ride, so opportunism is bounded.

They seem conditionally cooperative in an asymmetric way. Persistent under-contribution by a single peer does not push them into broad defection; they keep contributing at the maximum despite periodic low contributions from specific others. Their conditionality is thus weak with respect to punishment or reciprocity: they are tolerant of mild or sporadic free-riding and keep playing a cooperative role.

Fairness norms appear present but not enforced through behavior. The player likely prefers universal high contribution, but is willing to personally shoulder more than an equal share to keep group efficiency high. They do occasionally free-ride when everyone else is fully cooperative, suggesting they also care about personal payoff and are aware of the individual incentive to defect. Still, they restrict these episodes in frequency and duration, implying an internal balance between fairness/efficiency and self-interest.

Risk tolerance with respect to cooperation is high. The player repeatedly chooses strategies that are vulnerable to exploitation: they keep contributing fully even when they could rationally expect that at least some players may defect. They appear comfortable risking short-term disadvantage for the possibility and maintenance of a highly cooperative group outcome.

They appear to follow a simple, fixed rule: always contribute the maximum. This rule holds even when others free-ride or when average group contributions drop substantially. They do not reduce contributions in response to exploitation, and they do not increase contributions in response to improvement, because they are already at the upper bound.

Their behavior aligns with a strong group-efficiency norm: the marginal per capita return is above 1, so full contribution is individually profitable as well as socially optimal. However, they never explore lower contributions, so it is unknown whether they explicitly reason about payoff-maximization or simply adopt a principled “always cooperate” stance. Given the absence of any adjustment to temporary downturns, their risk tolerance for being exploited is high; they accept short-run personal disadvantage in exchange for maintaining a cooperative pattern.

Fairness concerns, if present, are not enforced via behavior. They experience periods where others contribute less, yet they do not retaliate or condition their own contributions on group fairness. This suggests either (a) a priority on maintaining cooperative norms over enforcing equity, (b) a belief that stable high contributions encourage others to return to high cooperation, or (c) indifference to relative payoffs so long as the public good is funded. Which of these is primary is unknown, but their actions are compatible with being a steadfast, norm-driven cooperator who maintains maximum contributions independently of others’ choices.

text:

The player is an unwavering, full-cooperation type. They always contribute the entire endowment and never deviate once, regardless of how others behave or how payoffs change. Their contribution pattern is perfectly stable and non-volatile across the whole game.

They act as a pure unconditional cooperator: their choice does not appear to depend on recent group contributions, temporary drops in others’ cooperation, or fluctuations in their own earnings. Even when multiple others contribute nothing or sharply reduce contributions, the player’s behavior remains identical.

This suggests that they prioritize maximizing group efficiency or adhering to a personal norm over individual short-term gain. Given that the marginal per-capita return exceeds 1, their behavior is also payoff-efficient at the group level, but they do not exploit periods when others free-ride; they continue to invest fully even when this makes them relatively worse off in that moment.

There is no observable evidence of conditional cooperation, reciprocity, or retaliation. They do not match the group average, reward high contributions, or sanction low ones through their own behavior; they simply keep contributing everything. This indicates a strong internal rule such as “always contribute fully” rather than a responsive or strategic rule tuned to others.

Their fairness norm appears to be that everyone should contribute maximally, but they do not adjust behavior to enforce or signal this; if anything, they serve as a consistent anchor of high cooperation, absorbing the cost of others’ deviations. Their risk tolerance is high with respect to the possibility of being exploited: they willingly expose themselves to free-riding without any observable attempt to hedge by lowering contributions.

Overall, the player is best characterized as a principled, non-adaptive, full contributor who follows a fixed cooperative rule independent of context or history, with unknown underlying motives but clear behavioral commitment to group-beneficial contribution.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a highly cooperative, near-unconditional high contributor. They treat full contribution as the default and maintain it across almost all rounds, even when others occasionally reduce their input or free-ride. Deviations from full contribution are rare, modest, and short-lived; they do not escalate into a downward spiral of defection. The pattern suggests a strong internal norm favoring maximal cooperation rather than a finely tuned, round-by-round response to others.

Stability is high: the player repeatedly returns to the maximum contribution after brief dips. This indicates a robust commitment to a simple rule (“contribute fully”) rather than experimentation or fine-grained payoff optimization. Their occasional reductions in contribution appear more like mild probes or momentary frustration than the beginning of a strategic shift; they quickly revert to full cooperation once they see others still largely contributing.

They display conditionality, but it is soft and asymmetric. Severe free-riding by one or two group members does not trigger large or sustained retaliation; at most, it prompts a small, temporary reduction in their own contribution. They seem willing to bear some exploitation to preserve overall group efficiency, indicating a social preference that prioritizes maintaining a cooperative equilibrium over strict reciprocity.

Their fairness norms are strongly pro-social and group-oriented. They act as if the “fair” behavior is that everyone contributes the maximum, and they live up to that standard themselves even when others occasionally fall short. They do not appear to chase individual short-term advantage and tolerate some inequality in their own disadvantage if the group remains largely cooperative. This is consistent with a preference for collective welfare and a reluctance to initiate or amplify breakdowns in cooperation.

Risk tolerance is high with respect to being exploited. The player repeatedly chooses the strategy that is most vulnerable to free-riding (full contribution) despite observing that some others occasionally deviate. They appear willing to risk lower individual earnings in order to stabilize a high-contribution norm. They do not seem risk-seeking in a random or volatile way; rather, they accept a stable, principled risk of exploitation as the cost of adhering to a cooperative rule. Overall, they behave like a principled, norm-driven cooperator who is only mildly and briefly responsive to others’ lapses and who keeps anchoring the group at high contribution levels.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a near-absolute, stable full cooperator with one brief experiment in defection. Their default and dominant pattern is to contribute the entire endowment to the public fund, despite having no access to punishment, reward, or communication and despite occasional defections by others. This indicates a strong internal cooperative rule rather than reactive or tit-for-tat behavior.

They display very high contribution stability: their choice is almost always the same, without gradual decay or conditional scaling in response to others’ deviations. Changes from full group cooperation, including multiple instances of clear free riding by specific peers, do not alter their behavior in a systematic way. The lone zero contribution appears as a single, isolated deviation rather than part of an adaptive shift; they immediately return to full contribution afterward even though incentives or group composition signals have not obviously changed. This suggests either a brief test of the payoff structure, an attention lapse, or a one-off impulse, rather than a strategic turning point.

There is strong evidence of a fairness or efficiency orientation: they keep choosing the socially optimal contribution level even when others temporarily lower theirs and even when doing so reduces their own payoff relative to what they could gain by free riding. Given that the marginal per-capita return exceeds the private return threshold, their behavior is consistent with someone who prioritizes maximizing group surplus and seems to accept personal vulnerability to free riders as a cost of that priority.

They do not appear risk averse with respect to cooperation: they continue to fully invest even when the group’s reliability temporarily worsens, showing comfort with the possibility that others may exploit them. At the same time, their rare defection suggests they are not oblivious to the incentive to free ride; they simply do not adopt that as a persistent strategy.

Conditionality is minimal or very weak: their contributions do not track specific partners’ recent deviations in any consistent, graded way. They neither punish low contributors by lowering their own contribution nor reward high contributors by increasing beyond their already maximal level. They instead behave like a rule-based or norm-driven cooperator: “always contribute fully,” with very limited responsiveness to local fluctuations.

Overall, this player fits a “principled high contributor” or “norm-following altruist” type: they uphold high contributions as a stable default, maintain that stance under mild exploitation, and only momentarily depart from it, quickly reverting to full cooperation. Their approach is simple, robust, and largely nonstrategic in the sense of not finely tuning contributions to others’ moves, while still being compatible with a clear understanding that cooperation generates large mutual gains.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a high, near-maximum contributor with occasional, strategically timed free-riding. Their default pattern is to give the full endowment whenever group cooperation appears strong or quickly recovers after small deviations. They contribute consistently rather than gradually adjusting, suggesting a rule-based approach rather than fine-grained payoff optimization.

Deviations from full contribution are infrequent and come in two forms: rare complete withdrawals and a single moderate reduction. These occur while others still contribute substantially, indicating deliberate tests of how much they can exploit group cooperation without collapsing it, rather than reactive punishment or resignation. After each exploitative move, they revert to full contribution once it is clear others remain cooperative.

They appear comfortable earning slightly less in the short run to sustain a highly cooperative environment most of the time, but they also opportunistically capture extra payoff when they expect the group to hold together without their help. Their behavior is conditional on perceived group norms: as long as the majority continues to give close to the maximum, they maintain full contributions, even when one or two players chronically lag or fluctuate. Attempts by others to reduce contributions do not trigger a downward spiral from this player; they instead recommit to full cooperation, apparently prioritizing group-level efficiency over retaliatory adjustment.

Overall, they combine a strong cooperative norm with calculated, low-frequency defection, resembling a “principled conditional cooperator with opportunistic tests.” They seem to accept some inequality in their disfavor (contributing fully when others give slightly less) as long as the cooperative equilibrium remains intact, and use occasional free-riding primarily as an information-gathering or profit-maximizing tactic rather than as a new standard. Their risk tolerance is moderate: they are willing to risk small drops in group contributions to test defection, but they quickly stabilize back to maximal giving rather than escalating volatility.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a stable, unconditional high contributor. They consistently allocate their full endowment to the public fund every round, regardless of how much others give, whether cooperation is high or low, and whether they are personally being rewarded. They behave as if full cooperation is the default and morally or strategically “right” choice, rather than something to be varied in response to others’ behavior.

Their contributions do not appear contingent on short-term payoff maximization: they continue to cooperate fully even when the group under-contributes and their own per-round payoff is relatively low. This suggests a strong internal norm in favor of contributing, with low sensitivity to exploitation risk. They tolerate free-riding by others without retaliating through reduced contributions.

They seem comfortable shouldering more than their “fair share” when others contribute less, yet they also remain engaged and mildly critical when some players do not match the cooperative norm. Overall, they embody a prosocial, high-trust type who treats contribution as a near-absolute rule, not a negotiable strategy.

<COMMUNICATION>
Their communication is sparse but socially attuned. They respond politely to greetings and acknowledge successful coordination with a brief, positive signal. Their tone is friendly and light; they use a small expressive cue (a simple emotive symbol) once cooperation stabilizes, which reads as contentment or relief at the emerging norm.

They do not initiate detailed strategic proposals, but they do make at least one pointed, critical remark aimed at those not fully cooperating, implying awareness of and mild frustration with perceived hypocrisy or free-riding. This criticism is framed in a casual, somewhat joking style rather than overt aggression, suggesting they prefer soft social pressure over confrontational shaming.

They are reactive rather than leading in the chat: they respond after others talk about strategies and contributions, and they do not attempt to micro-coordinate specific contribution levels or reward patterns. Their engagement style is low-frequency but responsive, with a mix of politeness and light norm enforcement through comments rather than detailed argument.

<REWARD>
They are willing but selective in using the reward mechanism. They rarely spend on rewards overall, and when they do, they spend modest amounts rather than systematically reinforcing all cooperators. Their use of rewards coincides with periods where others are contributing relatively more, suggesting that their reward behavior is conditional on observed cooperation level.

They do not use rewards to compensate themselves (since rewarding others is payoff-neutral by design, and they still choose to do it at times), implying that when they pay to reward, they are expressing approval or trying to support cooperative behavior rather than pursuing direct material gain. They show no clear pattern of rewarding in proportion to others’ exact contributions, and they do not reward every time cooperation improves, so their reinforcement is intermittent and somewhat cautious.

They refrain from rewarding during some full-cooperation episodes, which may reflect uncertainty about the impact of rewards, a desire to conserve payoff, or a belief that verbal and collective norms are sufficient once cooperation is established. They never use rewards punitively or manipulatively (the mechanism is symmetric cost/benefit), and their pattern suggests a primarily prosocial, norm-affirming intent: they are willing to incur small costs to encourage or acknowledge cooperative behavior but do not treat rewarding as a central or heavily strategic tool.

text:

They are not purely self-sacrificing; they balance own payoff with group returns and sometimes keep a substantial portion despite others’ full cooperation. Their behavior indicates awareness that high group contributions are profitable, but they are willing to deviate downward when they can still benefit from others’ generosity. They appear comfortable taking advantage of a cooperative norm at times, but not to the extreme of contributing nothing. Their risk tolerance is moderate: they repeatedly invest heavily even after seeing others defect or fluctuate, implying they are willing to risk being the “sucker” occasionally to preserve or regain high group payoffs.

Their tone is cooperative and non-confrontational; there is no sign of irritation or defensiveness, and they appear willing to align with the group once attention is on them. Overall, they adopt a low-visibility, reactive communication style: they monitor the chat, intervene minimally, and only speak when socially prompted.

They do not systematically reward every instance of strong cooperation, nor do they appear to run a consistent “reward-the-highest-contributor” strategy. They receive rewards in several cooperative contexts, which may reinforce their sense that contributing relatively high amounts is socially approved, but their own rewarding does not clearly escalate in response. Overall, they show a moderate willingness to reward, with no evidence of targeted strategic reinforcement or explicit gratitude signaling beyond the bare act of rewarding itself. text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
The player fits a “confused-but-corrective conditional cooperator” type. Early behavior shows a mix of very high and very low contributions, which aligns poorly with the surrounding group norm and suggests misunderstanding of the interface rather than deliberate exploitation. The player explicitly states that they have reversed the intended action and later apologizes; this makes it plausible that some low contributions during a period of group encouragement toward full contributions stem from misinterpretation rather than calculated free-riding (medium confidence).

Once they appear to understand the norm and mechanics better, they shift to consistently contributing their full endowment in the later phase of the game, aligning with a cooperation norm promoted by others. This indicates conditional cooperation: they are willing to bear substantial cost to match the group’s apparent consensus once they feel responsible for earlier deviations and once expectations are clear.

Their contribution pattern is volatile early on and stabilizes later. They oscillate between full contribution, partial contribution, and taking everything, which is inconsistent with a simple selfish or pure altruist type. The change toward stable full contributions following apologies and peer clarification suggests they update based on perceived group expectations and their own sense of having made a mistake.

Fairness norms appear to matter: when they perceive that the norm is to “put everything in,” they later try to align their behavior with that standard. They show no evidence of exploiting others once they understand the cooperative expectation, and they tolerate the personal risk of over-contributing relative to at least one slightly under-contributing peer. Risk tolerance regarding payoff variance is moderate to high: they are willing to forgo secure private payoffs in favor of matching a cooperative strategy that depends on others continuing to contribute.

Overall, the player is best characterized as norm-following once norms are understood, with early deviations driven by confusion, not stable selfishness.

<COMMUNICATION>
Their tone is friendly, polite, and deferential. They initiate a greeting once they notice the chat and respond in a socially appropriate, upbeat way, fitting a cooperative social style rather than a hostile or confrontational one. They later express explicit apologies and self-blame for previous misaligned actions, indicating concern about others’ perceptions and a desire to repair group trust.

They use chat primarily for social alignment and clarification rather than for persuasion or strategic manipulation. When other players advocate for full contributions, the player does not lead or argue; instead, they express that they had misunderstood and then quietly adjust behavior. This indicates a responsive rather than directive communication style.

They are attentive and reactive to group feedback. When another player indirectly criticizes low contributors and confusion emerges about who is at fault, the focal player queries their own status (“I am ?”) and later explains that they had reversed the meaning of the decision. This suggests they monitor how others interpret actions and care about being seen as cooperative.

They do not engage in explicit coordination proposals of their own but willingly endorse and follow others’ proposals once they understand them. They show no signs of trolling, sarcasm, or hostility. The overall communication style is conciliatory, self-correcting, and socially sensitive, with a mild tendency toward embarrassment when they realize earlier mistakes.

<REWARD>
The player shows limited, somewhat puzzling use of the reward mechanism. On one occasion they spend a substantial amount of their own payoff to distribute rewards, even when rewards are cost-neutral at the margin. This suggests an attempt to actively encourage cooperation or express approval, but the pattern is too sparse to establish a stable “strong reciprocator” type (low confidence).

They otherwise almost never use rewards, even when others behave cooperatively. This could indicate that they either do not fully understand or notice the reward stage, or they do not view the reward tool as necessary or impactful. Given they explicitly mention reversing the contribution decision and show confusion about mechanics in general, miscomprehension of the reward’s role is plausible (medium–low confidence).

They do not appear to use rewards strategically to shape future group behavior in a consistent way, nor do they systematically reciprocate when others reward them. The scarce use of the mechanism suggests that their primary cooperative tool is direct contribution itself, not indirect reinforcement.

In summary, their reward behavior is best described as sporadic and non-systematic, likely driven by a vague sense of encouragement or approval rather than a clear, calculated incentive strategy.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a steadfast unconditional cooperator. They consistently allocate their entire endowment to the public fund in every situation, regardless of others’ behavior or the recent payoff environment. Their contribution pattern is extremely stable and shows no strategic adjustment to free‑riding, partial cooperation, or shifts in group norms. They uphold a strong fairness norm that “everyone should put everything in” and treat this as the obvious or correct rule, explicitly advocating this norm in group communication and never deviating from it themselves.

They appear insensitive to short‑term individual payoff maximization: they continue full cooperation even when others repeatedly under‑contribute and when returns from the public fund are relatively low. There is no observable risk‑hedging or conditional cooperation; they do not experiment with lower contributions to test others, nor do they reduce contributions in response to persistent defectors. Their behavior is consistent with a principled or norm‑driven type rather than an outcome‑driven or strategic type. Whether this stems from intrinsic pro‑social preferences, a desire to be “the good player,” or misunderstanding of the payoff structure is unknown, although their explanations to others suggest they do understand that group payoffs are maximized when all contribute fully.

They show patience with temporary miscoordination: even when others misunderstand the mechanism or reverse their decisions, this player maintains full contributions and instead uses communication to clarify what should be done.

<COMMUNICATION>
Their tone is friendly, brief, and cooperative. They engage early with a simple greeting and then use the chat primarily to support coordination around full contributions. They explicitly endorse the “everyone contributes everything” strategy and later clarify how the decision interface should be interpreted, indicating that they are both attentive to others’ confusion and willing to help correct it.

They are responsive to social dynamics: when another player seems to imply that some birds are not cooperating, they defend their own cooperative status without aggression, asking for clarification in a neutral way. They express positive reinforcement when the group finally reaches high, synchronized contributions again, celebrating the restored cooperation with a short appreciative comment. Their communication style is low‑volume but targeted: they speak when it can help coordination, clear up misunderstandings, or affirm group success, rather than chatting for its own sake.

They do not pressure or shame specific individuals; instead, they talk in general terms about what “we” should do and about how the interface should read. This suggests a mild, prosocial, norm‑setting style rather than a confrontational or punitive one. They respond to others’ apologies and confusion by offering constructive guidance, not blame. Overall, they engage but do not dominate the conversation, and they use language to align the group around cooperative norms.

<REWARD>
They never spend any coins on reward, even when others clearly cooperate and even when they themselves receive rewards from others multiple times. Their willingness to reward is therefore either zero or extremely low in this environment. They do accept and acknowledge cooperative behavior via chat (e.g., verbally affirming when the group finally all contributes fully again), but they do not translate that approval into use of the formal reward mechanism.

Given that the cost and benefit of reward are symmetric here, the lack of rewarding is not obviously profit‑maximizing versus neutral; it is more consistent with an assumption that formal reward is unnecessary, that cooperation should be its own norm without side payments, or that they prioritize keeping their own payoff once they have already contributed fully. They may view full contribution as sufficient pro‑social action and see additional reward spending as redundant or costly without added value. They also never appear to threaten or promise reward in chat, nor do they mention the reward mechanism, indicating it is not central to their strategy.

Their reinforcement of norms is thus primarily verbal and by example rather than through incentive manipulation. They rely on modeling perfect cooperation and using brief, positive communication to guide others, rather than paying to selectively reinforce behavior. Whether they would reward in a setting where reward is more clearly efficacious or differently structured is unknown.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player fits a “conditional, talk-cooperative but payoff-conscious” type. They do not follow a simple high- or low-contribution rule; instead they vary contributions widely and appear responsive to both group behavior and chat.

They sometimes fully free-ride, sometimes fully cooperate, and sometimes choose intermediate amounts. This volatility suggests they are exploring how others behave and how their own payoff responds, rather than following a fixed norm. They are willing to put in full contributions multiple times, especially when others also seem to contribute highly. They also occasionally contribute nothing even when several others are contributing a lot, implying that maximizing short-term personal payoff still matters.

They express in chat that “everyone should put everything in” (paraphrased), and they later return to full contributions after coordination improves, indicating that they endorse a high-cooperation norm. However, their own behavior does not strictly match that norm: at times they keep all or half of their endowment despite others contributing more. This pattern is consistent with a conditional cooperator who is also opportunistic when they see a chance to benefit from others’ generosity.

They show moderate sensitivity to fairness. They call out a peer’s relatively low contribution and later acknowledge when that peer increases it. This suggests they monitor relative contributions and care about group members matching an implicit “all-in” standard. At the same time, they do not consistently hold themselves to that standard, indicating some asymmetry: they approve of high group contributions but allow themselves deviation.

Their risk tolerance appears mixed. They are willing to risk full cooperation even after earlier rounds where high contributions did not always pay off maximally, suggesting they value the prospect of group-level gains or social alignment. Yet they also revert to low or zero contributions in multiple rounds, which may reflect caution when cooperation appears unstable, or simply alternating between exploiting and supporting the public fund. Overall, they are more experimental and situational than strictly risk-averse or risk-seeking.

<COMMUNICATION>
Their communication style is friendly, informal, and socially engaged. They initiate conversation, respond to others, and use light humor and small typos/playful corrections, indicating comfort in the social environment. They do not appear hostile or confrontational; even when they point out another’s low contribution, they frame it casually and later affirm that things are “good” once the behavior aligns with expectations.

They clearly attempt to coordinate the group. They explicitly advocate for everyone to contribute the full amount and repeat this idea more than once, framing high contributions as beneficial to all. This shows a preference for explicit norm-setting rather than silent adjustment. They also acknowledge when their own earlier message might have been mistaken or misdirected, suggesting some self-awareness and willingness to correct themselves.

They respond to others’ confusion with mild guidance. When another player admits to misunderstanding the mechanics, they do not scold; instead they continue to promote the “all in” idea and later accept the corrected behavior. This indicates they see chat as a tool to align expectations rather than to punish.

Their engagement is steady but not dominant. They speak multiple times, but do not flood the chat or try to micromanage every round. They show enough responsiveness to follow the emerging group mood; when others celebrate improved cooperation, they affirm it succinctly rather than pushing further demands. Overall, their style is cooperative, norm-promoting, and socially lighthearted.

<REWARD>
They never spend any coins on rewarding others, even when others’ contributions are high or align with the norm they promote. They do receive rewards from others but do not reciprocate. This indicates that, in this environment, they treat the reward mechanism as personally costly without sufficient perceived benefit, and they prioritize keeping their own payoff over reinforcing others’ cooperation through formal rewards.

Their reinforcement of norms thus occurs exclusively via chat and contributions, not via the explicit reward channel. They use verbal encouragement and social feedback rather than material incentives. This suggests they either see rewards as strategically unnecessary, do not find them intuitive or salient, or simply decide that the one-to-one cost-benefit of the reward option does not justify use.

There is no evidence that they use reward to signal gratitude or to cement alliances; any appreciation for others’ high contributions is expressed only in words (e.g., affirming when others “get it right”) and in occasionally matching full contributions. Their willingness to invest in cooperation is selective and occurs through their own contribution choices, not through paying extra to boost others. Their reward behavior is therefore best characterized as non-rewarding and chat-based norm-enforcing, with no observed strategic use of the formal reward mechanism.
