text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a generally high contributor with selective, sometimes sharp deviations. They usually give the full endowment when group behavior looks cooperative or when norms are being affirmed in chat. They occasionally under-contribute or free-ride when others are clearly contributing a lot, suggesting conditional cooperation with opportunistic streaks rather than unconditional altruism. Their contributions are not random: they align strongly with perceived group norms and recent history of cooperation, but they also test the payoff structure by keeping more for themselves in some periods of high group contribution. They appear moderately risk-tolerant: they are willing to invest heavily in the public fund even when some group members under-contribute, but they also show that they are willing to defect when the environment looks “safe enough” (others contributing high) to still secure a good payoff. They seem to value fairness at the collective level (often matching or exceeding the implied cooperative standard) but do not insist on strict reciprocity every round. When others collectively move toward consistent high contributions, this player tends to align with that pattern and maintain high contributions, indicating a belief that cooperative equilibria are both desirable and sustainable if enough others participate.

<COMMUNICATION>
This player communicates rarely and succinctly. Their tone is polite, low-key, and non-confrontational. They do not initiate strong coordination drives or reprimands; instead, they acknowledge others’ proposals in a mild, somewhat cautious way. Their single explicit response to a contribution-norm suggestion is tentative rather than emphatic, indicating they are open to cooperation but not strongly assertive in pushing it. They do not directly call out low contributors or engage in blame, even when others do. Their style is reactive rather than proactive: they respond once to an invitation to fully contribute but otherwise stay quiet, letting actions rather than words signal their intentions. Overall they engage, but minimally, and avoid conflict, persuasion campaigns, or overt emotional displays. Their communication suggests a cooperative disposition with reserved, low-dominance social behavior.

<REWARD>
This player is willing to spend on rewards, but in a highly irregular, situation-dependent way. They are clearly not a pure payoff maximizer with respect to the reward mechanism, because they sometimes spend nontrivial amounts to transfer benefits to others or possibly to themselves despite no net monetary gain. Their rewarding behavior seems tied to social or normative cues: they use rewards early when group cooperation is strong, and again at moments when high cooperation is present or when they themselves have contributed very little, possibly to acknowledge or support others’ efforts. They do not consistently reward every time others cooperate, so they are not a mechanical “reward every cooperator” type. Instead, they occasionally reinforce cooperative episodes, perhaps to stabilize norms or express approval, but they are selective and sometimes withhold rewards even when others are highly cooperative. They do not appear vengeful (no punishment exists, and they never use rewards in a way that clearly targets defectors), and they do not use rewards to try to shape specific individuals’ behavior through explicit signaling in chat. Overall, they treat the reward mechanism as an optional, sometimes expressive tool for norm reinforcement rather than a strict strategic lever used every time cooperation is high.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a strict, unwavering full cooperator. They always contribute the maximum available amount, never deviating, regardless of others’ behavior, conflict in the group, or stage of the game. Their contributions are not conditional on others’ fairness or civility; they continue to contribute fully even when some others free ride or when inter-player hostility escalates. This suggests they internalize a simple rule such as “full contribution is obviously optimal for everyone” and act on it consistently. They appear risk-tolerant regarding being exploited: they do not hedge or reduce contributions in response to low-contributing or norm-violating others. Their fairness norm is strongly efficiency-focused: they support the high-contribution, high-payoff equilibrium and do not experiment with self-serving deviations.

<COMMUNICATION>
The player does not speak at all in the chat. They neither initiate coordination nor respond to others’ messages, including direct calls for group action or end-game plans. This indicates a strongly silent/observing communication style: they pay attention (as shown by prompt, norm-consistent behavior) but remain entirely nonverbal. They neither join in bullying nor defend targets, so their stance on the interpersonal conflict is unknown. They do not publicly endorse norms, explain their reasoning, or attempt to persuade free riders; instead, they enforce preferred outcomes solely through contribution and punishment choices. They show no signs of seeking social approval, status, or alignment with any faction in the chat. Responsiveness is behavioral rather than verbal: they adjust punishment patterns over time but never through explicit communication.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
There is no visible end-game unraveling in their contributions: they continue to contribute the maximum in all late rounds, including the final one, with no sign of decay. They do not switch to free riding when the horizon nears, despite others openly discussing end-game punishment strategies. Their punishment spending remains active and sometimes substantial right up to the late game, indicating they are willing to sacrifice payoff even near the end, where deterrence cannot benefit them in future rounds. This suggests they do not heavily weight standard backward-induction logic; instead, they likely prioritize maintaining norms or expressing disapproval over finely optimizing terminal payoffs. They show no explicit acknowledgement of the approaching end and do not join last-round coordination proposals in chat, so their conscious horizon awareness is unknown, but behaviorally they remain stable and principled rather than opportunistic.

<PUNISHMENT>
The player is a moderately to highly active punisher and is willing to pay nontrivial costs to sanction others. Their punishment is selective rather than random: they spend when others clearly deviate from the maximum-contribution norm or behave in ways that undermine group efficiency or cohesion (e.g., early free riding, later inconsistent contribution, or possibly those seen as “problem” players). They sometimes refrain from punishing when the group is fully aligned and contributing maximally, but when a salient target emerges, their punishment intensity can escalate, even at significant personal cost. The pattern is more consistent with second-order norm enforcement and deterrence than with direct retaliation, because they are not themselves targeted and do not appear to be punishing in response to personal loss alone. They also continue punishing in late rounds when future benefits are minimal, which suggests a possible expressive or principled motive: they are willing to incur net losses to uphold their view of correct behavior. However, since their punishments cannot be directly tied to specific chat statements (they never speak), the exact identity of their targets and fine-grained motives beyond “noncompliance with the cooperative equilibrium” remain uncertain (low confidence on specific target mapping; higher confidence on general willingness to enforce norms at a cost).

<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a strict, unwavering full cooperator under these payoff conditions. Once they see that the group norm is to contribute the maximum, they consistently mirror that, always choosing the full endowment rather than free-riding. Their behavior does not waver in response to insults, threats, or changing contributions by a few others; they maintain the same cooperative strategy throughout. This suggests they either understand the material incentives and follow a “maximize group returns” rule, or they adopt a simple “do the fair/expected thing” heuristic and stick to it. They show no evidence of conditional cooperation or opportunistic deviation, even when others defect or when they are personally targeted in chat. Risk tolerance appears moderate to high regarding social risk: they accept being singled out and punished in the chat without adjusting their contribution pattern, indicating they are not using contributions strategically to appease others. Their fairness norm is focused on contributing what they see as the correct amount; they do not try to calibrate contributions to punishers or allies, and they never attempt to exploit the public good for private gain.

<COMMUNICATION>
The player’s communication is extremely sparse and front‑loaded. Early on, they join the initial pro-cooperation norm with a short, approving confirmation that they are also contributing the maximum. After that, they fall completely silent for the remainder of the interaction, even as they become a focal target of extensive ridicule and threats. They do not defend themselves, do not argue their case, and do not attempt to persuade others or negotiate around punishment. This pattern indicates an avoidance-based communication style once conflict emerges: they withdraw from the social arena rather than contesting status or reputation. Their tone in the single early message is neutral‑positive and cooperative, not aggressive or moralizing. They do not publicly justify their choices or confront others’ bullying, which makes their underlying motives partially opaque to the group. They also show no apparent responsiveness to repeated direct address; even sustained, escalating attempts to provoke them do not elicit any further messages. This suggests either a deliberate choice to disengage from chat or a strong preference to let actions (consistent max contributions) speak for themselves rather than words.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
There is no observable end-game unraveling in this player’s contribution behavior. They continue to contribute the full amount through the final rounds, with no sign of tapering cooperation as the game approaches its conclusion. Their strategy appears horizon-insensitive: the knowledge that the game is finite and nearing the end does not induce them to defect or experiment with lower contributions. They also do not alter their behavior in response to late-game coalition talk against them; despite others openly planning to sacrifice their own earnings to punish them at the end, the player does not retaliate, bargain, or reduce contributions. This consistent pattern suggests they either follow a rule-based strategy (“always contribute the max when it’s efficient for the group”) or they place little weight on short-term personal payoff optimization in the final rounds. Their absence from late-game chat makes it impossible to infer any explicit reasoning or emotional reaction to the end-game dynamics; their internal beliefs and feelings about the group’s plan to target them at the end remain unknown.

<PUNISHMENT>
The player never uses the punishment option at any point and appears to ignore social prompts to participate in sanctioning. This is a stable feature of their behavior: they refrain from punishment both when others under-contribute and when they themselves become a central target of hostile talk and threats. There is no evidence of either deterrence-oriented punishment (to enforce group norms) or retaliation (to respond to personal attacks), despite many opportunities and strong social cues to do so. This strongly suggests a “non-punisher” or punishment-averse type. Their abstention does not shift even when sanctioning is framed by others as justified or necessary. Whether this is driven by principled rejection of punitive behavior, indifference to others’ choices, lack of concern for enforcement, or a narrow focus on contribution decisions alone is unknown. However, in practice, they behave as a pure cooperator who does not invest in second-order enforcement and does not engage in costly social control, even under direct provocation.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a near-unconditional high contributor with one late defection. They almost always choose the cooperative, payoff-maximizing action even when personally attacked, showing strong preference for maintaining group efficiency over retaliating or free-riding. Their single zero contribution appears more like a brief, unexplained deviation than a full strategic shift; there is no accompanying message or pattern suggesting a deliberate end-game exploitation or revenge. Overall, they act as a “principled cooperator”: they keep contributing fully even when socially isolated and punished, suggesting that their cooperation is internally motivated rather than contingent on being treated nicely.

They show no clear conditionality on specific others’ contributions: they continue to contribute fully when others free-ride or when they themselves are targeted. They talk about “fair share” and “play fair,” indicating a fairness norm, but they do not enforce it through contribution changes. Risk tolerance appears moderate to high regarding social risk: they are willing to maintain high contributions even while expecting continued punishment and harassment, implying they prioritize norm-consistent behavior and personal values over short-term earnings security.

<COMMUNICATION>
Their tone is generally calm, moralistic, and disapproving of cruelty rather than of low contributions. Early on, they align verbally with the group’s cooperative strategy, but they do not join in hostile or dehumanizing language. As the dominant coalition turns aggressively punitive and mocking toward specific players, they openly oppose the bullying, explicitly state they “don’t like bullies,” and frame their stance as about morals and disgust at picking on one person.

They attempt mild coordination around fairness and cooperation (talking about everyone giving their “fair share” and “playing fair”) but do not try to organize punishment campaigns. Their persuasion style is value-based rather than technical: they appeal to decency and maturity more than to game-theoretic arguments, and they mock others’ self-perceived superiority rather than their strategy. They respond when addressed and engage directly with the hostile majority, but without escalating to profanity or sustained insult; their barbs stay relatively restrained compared to others.

They show some initial confusion about the chat interface, mentioning they didn’t realize how to send properly, which may explain sparse or delayed responses early. Overall, they engage selectively: they speak when something matters to them (bullying, fairness) and otherwise stay relatively quiet, especially once it’s clear the group will not change its behavior. Their style is confrontational in principle but not in volume; they stand their ground but do not dominate the chat.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
There is no classic end-game unraveling in their contributions: they keep contributing fully through the final rounds, including the last one, despite awareness of remaining rounds and despite a hostile environment. Their lone zero contribution occurs in the back half of the game, but they immediately revert to full contributions, suggesting either a short-lived experiment, momentary frustration, or error rather than a systematic end-game strategy.

They do not respond to late-game calls for coordinated extreme punishment of a target, nor do they leverage the approaching end to shift toward self-interest or vengeance. Horizon awareness is present at group level (others discuss remaining time and end-round maneuvers), but there is no evidence that this player conditions behavior on it; their strategy remains stable and principle-driven rather than horizon-driven.

<PUNISHMENT>
They are highly restrained in using punishment. For most of the game, they either do not punish or, when punishment is clearly directed by the group at supposed defectors, they do not visibly join in beyond a single small expenditure. They never publicly advocate for punishment in chat and never threaten others. When they finally do punish, the amount is modest relative to what others spend; target and motive are unknown from the transcript, but timing suggests it could be directed at a perceived unfair actor rather than as part of the group’s large-scale, spiteful punishment campaigns.

Their verbal stance is strongly anti-bullying, but not overtly anti-punishment as an institution. They criticize harassment and demeaning language more than the use of punishment to enforce contribution norms. They do not retaliate with punishment when they are insulted or threatened, even when others explicitly announce ongoing deductions against them. This indicates low propensity for retaliatory punishment and little taste for costly spite.

Overall, they behave like a “reluctant, principled punisher”: willing to spend a small amount once, possibly to signal disapproval or align minimally with norm enforcement, but generally avoiding punishment when it is used as a tool of cruelty or domination rather than fairness or efficiency. Their primary response to norm violations (as they see them) is moral argument in chat, not monetary sanction.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a fully stable, unconditional full contributor within the binary choice constraint. They always select the maximum possible contribution and never deviate, regardless of prior payoffs, others’ deviations, or conflict in chat. Their contribution pattern does not show learning or experimentation; they appear to lock onto the efficiency logic early and keep it. They treat full contribution as the obvious, “intelligent” and normatively right choice, and they frame non-max contributions as signs of low intelligence or bad character. They do not appear concerned about personal risk from contributing, likely because they understand the high marginal per-capita return and assume group compliance is achievable or enforceable. Fairness for them is defined as everyone giving the maximum; they do not discuss proportionality or mixed strategies—only all-or-nothing cooperation.

<COMMUNICATION>
They use chat actively and assertively to coordinate behavior, set norms, and rally others to full contribution and heavy punishment. Their tone is often domineering, mocking, and moralizing: they label non-compliers and critics as “morons,” “greedy,” or otherwise inferior, and insist that everyone else is “smarter” than the target. They use insults and ridicule as tools to enforce norms and build an in-group (“we” who understand the game vs. “they” who are stupid, greedy, or foreign). They engage heavily rather than avoid conflict, repeatedly addressing defectors and critics even when the conversation becomes purely antagonistic.

They respond quickly to allies who share their views, reinforcing group cohesion with agreement and humor. Toward dissenters, they dismiss moral objections and reframe the situation in instrumental terms (maximizing money, following the logic/game theory). They also speculate negatively about others’ status (e.g., insinuating bot use or foreign access) to delegitimize them. Overall, their communication style is confrontational, status-assertive, and focused on enforcing a single “rational” cooperative norm, with little tolerance for alternative value frames.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
They remain fully cooperative to the final round and do not reduce contributions as the horizon approaches. End-game awareness appears mainly in their punishment planning, not in their contribution strategy. Near the end, they explicitly reference the remaining round(s) to coordinate a last, large-scale punitive attack aimed at driving a target’s payoff toward zero, asking others to “sacrifice” their own payoff to achieve this. This shows that, as the game nears its conclusion, they escalate antisocial punishment of disliked players rather than relaxing enforcement or shifting to personal profit maximization.

They do not show any attempt to conserve resources or reduce punishment late in the game to maximize earnings; instead, they treat the looming end as an opportunity to finish the norm-enforcement and moral “lesson” against targets. There is no evidence of strategic cooperation decay; contribution stays maxed and punishment intensity against disliked individuals either persists or intensifies.

<PUNISHMENT>
Punishment is central to this player’s identity and strategy. They are extremely willing to spend large amounts on punishment, even when it is personally very costly and clearly lowers their own payoff substantially. Their punishments are initially directed at clear free riders or non-max contributors, fitting a strong “altruistic enforcer” type: they publicly call for everyone to punish non-max contributors and explicitly state they will punish all who deviate from full contribution.

Over time, their punishment pattern broadens into both norm enforcement and personal retaliation. Targets include: (1) players who contribute less than maximum; (2) players suspected of being bots or illegitimate participants; and (3) players who criticize bullying or claim moral objections to the group’s treatment of others. Once someone is labeled as “stupid,” “greedy,” or morally inferior, this player is willing to punish them repeatedly and at extreme cost, sometimes announcing very large cumulative punishment they claim to have imposed. They appear to experience substantial satisfaction or entertainment from harshly punishing certain targets, repeatedly taunting them and emphasizing how little money the targets will end up with.

Deterrence and norm maintenance are part of their stated motive: they argue that “bullying worked” when a previously non-contributing player starts conforming, and they continually assert that full contribution is the correct, rational norm that must be enforced. However, much of their punishment becomes expressive and retributive: they say they will “spend all of my money just to take all of yours,” and they continue punishing even when the target’s behavior has already conformed, suggesting a strong taste for moralized retaliation and status dominance rather than purely instrumental deterrence.

They sometimes try to coordinate group punishment campaigns, including proposing end-of-game collective sacrifices to strip a target of all earnings. Their punishment is highly selective and identity-based rather than mechanically tied to current contribution levels: once a player is categorized as “the enemy,” they remain a punishment target regardless of current cooperative behavior. Overall, this player fits an “intense moralistic enforcer” type: a consistent cooperator who is willing to incur very large personal costs to punish perceived defectors or moral opponents, and who uses both the punishment mechanism and social aggression as tools of enforcement and dominance.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a strong, near-unconditional max contributor. They consistently choose the full cooperative option almost every round and endorse “everyone max” as the clear group norm. They show no gradual decay in contributions as the game progresses and appear largely insensitive to short‑term payoff fluctuations. Even when others defect or when they personally spend heavily on punishment, they keep contributing the maximum rather than hedging or free‑riding. Only one instance of not contributing occurs; it does not turn into a new pattern and does not lead to open justification or renegotiation of norms. Their cooperation is not naive: they explicitly link max contribution to “easy money” and endorse the idea that failing to max is irrational, suggesting they see the social optimum and follow it. They seem more concerned with enforcing the cooperative norm than with personally optimizing net earnings, but still anchor on full contribution as the default. Fairness is construed in a strongly group‑centric way: those who do not follow the norm are seen as “losers,” “greedy,” or “stupid,” and are framed as legitimate targets, not as alternative strategists. Risk tolerance appears moderate to high: they accept substantial outlays on punishment, trusting that most others will keep cooperating so the public good remains high.

<COMMUNICATION>
The player’s tone is aggressive, mocking, and alliance‑oriented. They quickly align with early pro‑max voices and publicly declare their own maxing to signal in‑group membership. They actively endorse and amplify others’ calls to punish non‑max contributors, using derisive labels and ridicule to socially isolate deviants. Their style is not conciliatory; they rarely attempt reasoned persuasion beyond simple statements that maxing is best and failing to max is stupid. Instead, they rely on moralistic and intellectual framing (“stupid people,” “losers”) and join in “pile‑on” dynamics with like‑minded players. They are responsive to group chat: they echo others’ sentiments, reinforce group plans (e.g., coordinated punishing), and contribute jokes and insults that strengthen an “us vs them” narrative against identified defectors or critics. When a player objects to bullying, they dismiss the objection and reframe the critic as both morally and strategically inferior. Their engagement is high throughout the game; they do not withdraw from conversation and are comfortable escalating verbal hostility for group cohesion against out‑group members. There is no evidence of empathy toward defectors or dissenters; perceived motives of others are interpreted cynically (greedy, dumb, or bot/cheater). They also display some playful competitiveness and humor, but it is usually at others’ expense.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
Awareness of the finite horizon is present at least implicitly, as the group references remaining rounds and contemplates a final‑round punishment coordination. This player does not reduce contributions near the end; they maintain max contributions through the final round and do not pivot to self‑interested free‑riding. Their punishment behavior continues late into the game and is even considered for a coordinated final “hit” on a target, suggesting that the end game is seen as an opportunity to complete a punitive campaign rather than to harvest private gains. They show willingness to sacrifice late‑game earnings to damage a disliked player, but also occasionally forgo punishment (including in the final round), possibly to conserve payoff or because prior punishment is perceived as sufficient. There is no visible attempt to exploit the final rounds for unilateral gain; instead, they stay aligned with the cooperative‑and‑punitive norm. Strategic sophistication about backward induction is not evident; their behavior reflects norm loyalty and group‑based hostility more than horizon‑driven recalculation.

<PUNISHMENT>
They are a heavy, proactive punisher with a clear taste for norm enforcement and retribution. From early in the game they declare that they punish anyone who does not contribute the maximum and follow through with substantial expenditures on punishment across many rounds. Their targets are primarily players who fail to max contribute and those perceived as undermining group earnings or norms (initially a very low contributor, later a critic of “bullying,” and persistently a player cast as hypocritical or greedy). They do not appear to punish cooperators; punishment is selective but harsh against designated deviants. The magnitude of punishment they sustain over many rounds indicates a willingness to incur sizable personal costs to impose large losses on others, consistent with strong altruistic (or spiteful) punishment rather than purely instrumental deterrence. Once a player is categorized as a bad actor, they support ongoing, escalating sanctions and join in coordinated efforts to “make them hurt” or even drive them to near‑zero earnings. Their language suggests that punishing is morally and emotionally gratifying; they frame it as deserved justice for stupidity, greed, or disrespect of the group. Deterrence and norm signaling are present, but the persistence and intensity of punishment even after targets adjust or fall silent indicates a strong retaliatory and expressive component, not just strategic enforcement.

<CONTRIBUTION>

Their cooperation is not conditional in the usual “I match others” sense; instead, it is anchored in a belief that full contribution is clearly payoff-maximizing for the group and individually beneficial in this high-multiplier setting. They explicitly frame non-contribution as irrational rather than as a tempting self-interested choice, indicating low tolerance for free-riding and little sympathy for “moral” arguments against payoff-maximization. They accept the individual cost of consistent cooperation without visible hesitation, suggesting high concern for group efficiency and low risk aversion in following what they see as the dominant cooperative logic.

<COMMUNICATION>

They promote full contribution from the start and use chat to reinforce a “we’re all in this together against the outside requester” narrative. Their persuasion style is blunt and contemptuous toward perceived defectors or “irrational” players; they use insults and moralizing language, lumping non-max contributors together as greedy, stupid, or lacking in game-theoretic understanding. They align strongly with a like-minded in-group of high contributors and treat dissenters as out-group targets. They do sometimes articulate the instrumental logic of cooperation (pointing out there is no benefit to withholding and emphasizing improved payouts), but the tone is more shaming than patient explanation. They engage frequently rather than avoiding conflict and respond directly to ongoing debates, especially when someone challenges the punishment/cooperation regime.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
The player shows no end-game unraveling. They maintain full contributions right through the final rounds and continue to support strong punishment of defectors, including at the very end when there is no future interaction to influence. Their cooperative and punitive strategies appear driven by a mix of principle and desire for immediate expressive or retributive satisfaction, not by backward induction or discounted future returns. They acknowledge that the game has a fixed horizon (they see the remaining rounds and react to others’ end-game talk) but do not adjust their behavior toward more self-regarding choices. They remain focused on enforcing the established norm and on “making it hurt” for violators, even in the last round.

<PUNISHMENT>
This player is a frequent, costly, and norm-based punisher. They initially refrain from punishing when contributions are high and aligned with their max-cooperation standard; once clear free-riders or partial contributors emerge, they begin spending substantial resources to punish them and persist in doing so across many rounds. Their punishment is selective: they target those who do not contribute fully or who oppose the punitive norm, not random others. The motive appears primarily deterrent and retributive: they explicitly want non-cooperators to “hurt,” and they support group coordination on severe sanctions. They are willing to incur sizable personal costs to enforce the cooperative norm even when the incremental economic benefit is likely negative, indicating strong preference for norm enforcement and out-group discipline. They endorse a “us vs. requesters, not us vs. us” framing, yet in practice they prioritize punishing internal defectors as the main threat. Overall, they function as an aggressive, moralizing enforcer: a high-contribution, high-punishment player who trades off some own payoff to uphold and impose a strict cooperation standard.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a strict, unwavering full contributor. They always invest the maximum possible amount into the public project and never deviate, even when others defect or when conflict over punishment escalates. Their contribution rule is simple and rigid: everyone should always give the maximum, and this norm is non‑negotiable. They explicitly endorse full contributions as the “correct” and “intelligent” behavior and frame non‑max contributors as greedy, unintelligent, or morally wrong. They show no evidence of conditional cooperation in the usual sense (they do not reduce their own contribution in response to free‑riding); instead, they keep cooperating and use punishment and social pressure to enforce norms. They appear highly risk‑tolerant with respect to payoff variance: they are willing to lower their own net take‑home through costly punishment as long as maximum contributions are enforced and norm‑violators are sanctioned. Their fairness norm is strongly efficiency‑focused and group‑oriented: everyone should maximize the group payoff by contributing fully, and individuals who do not comply are treated as enemies of the group.

<COMMUNICATION>
Their tone is intense, judgmental, and often openly hostile toward perceived free‑riders and “hypocrites.” They quickly align themselves with others who argue for maximum contributions and join in building a hardline coalition around that standard. They use chat to coordinate group behavior: urging everyone to contribute fully, explicitly recommending punishment strategies, and reinforcing a shared “us versus them” narrative where “us” is the high‑contributing majority and “them” is any low contributor or moral dissenter. Their persuasive style relies on ridicule, moral condemnation, and appeals to common sense and group benefit rather than calm reasoning. They are highly responsive to others’ messages, echoing and amplifying like‑minded players’ sentiments, and directly confronting dissenters. They show willingness to personalize conflict, using insults and character attacks, yet justify this as enforcing fairness or combating greed. They also occasionally frame the situation in quasi‑moral or political metaphors, implying they see the game as illustrative of broader social dynamics. Overall, they are very engaged, highly verbal, and comfortable escalating social pressure to enforce their preferred norm.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
Awareness of the finite horizon does not weaken their cooperative norm or their punitive stance. They continue to contribute the maximum amount through the final rounds without any observable decay. Near the end they remain focused on sanctioning the main target of their disapproval and support coordination to impose especially heavy punishment at the very end. Their behavior suggests they prioritize norm enforcement and expressive punishment over marginal end‑game earnings, and they do not switch to self‑regarding defection even when payoffs are nearly finalized. They treat late rounds as an opportunity to complete the “moral” narrative they have constructed—leaving the norm‑violator with as little as possible—rather than as a stage to quietly lock in gains.

<PUNISHMENT>
They are an extremely willing and heavy user of costly punishment. From early on they advocate punishing any non‑max contributor and publicly encourage others to do the same. They self‑report large intended punishments and, given their consistently reduced payoffs relative to non‑punishing full contributors, they repeatedly follow through. Their punishment is targeted: they focus on players who either contribute nothing, fail to match the group’s full‑contribution standard, or publicly oppose the bullying/harsh enforcement strategy. They show no evidence of “anti‑social” punishment toward cooperators; all evidence points to norm‑enforcing, not random, targeting. Their motives mix deterrence and expressive retribution: they aim both to make under‑contributors “hurt” and to signal that greedy or morally oppositional behavior is unacceptable. They persist in punishing even when the main target continues to contribute fully, indicating that earlier or parallel behavior in chat (perceived hypocrisy or moral grandstanding) becomes sufficient grounds for continued sanctions. They accept substantial personal cost to maintain these punishments, suggesting a strong preference for norm enforcement even when it is individually costly.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a highly inconsistent contributor who treats contribution choices as a way to express moral positions and opposition to group behavior, not as a way to maximize payoff. They sometimes match the group’s full-contribution norm, but they also repeatedly free-ride even when that predictably triggers extreme punishment and huge losses. Their switches between contributing and not contributing align with social and moral stances: they contribute fully when they feel aligned with a cooperative, non-bullying norm, and withhold when they are resisting or protesting the group’s behavior. They do not appear risk-averse; they are willing to incur very large, predictable losses rather than conform to norms they see as unethical. They do not prioritize efficiency or aggregate earnings; instead they prioritize maintaining their own notion of integrity, even when that sharply reduces payoffs for themselves and, at times, for others. Fairness for them is defined less by payoff patterns and more by whether people are treated respectfully.

<COMMUNICATION>
Their tone is moralizing but not overtly abusive; they criticize others’ behavior as “bullying” and “disgusting,” but avoid name-calling beyond reactive barbs when provoked. They explicitly frame their actions as guided by “morals,” and indicate they would rather personally lose money than be complicit in behavior they see as cruel. They are willing to stand against a clear majority and remain engaged in dialogue even while being mocked and punished. They confront the dominant coalition repeatedly, arguing that targeting and mocking a single low contributor is wrong, and later that the sustained harassment is unacceptable. Their communication is reactive and principled rather than strategic: they are not trying to coordinate a sub-group or redirect incentives, they are staking out a position of moral refusal. They continue to respond for several rounds under heavy social pressure, then go quiet later, suggesting emotional fatigue or a decision that further argument is pointless. Overall, they are socially engaged, values-driven, and prepared to be socially isolated to maintain their stance.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
Awareness of the finite horizon does not lead them to a payoff-maximizing end-game strategy. Instead of converging to a stable high-contribution pattern to salvage earnings, they maintain a low-contribution stance across late rounds even as punishment remains intense, indicating that their primary goal is not final payoff. They do not appear to adjust behavior in the final rounds to avoid last-minute punishment, nor do they escalate retaliation (they never punish at all). Their late-game choices remain consistent with an ongoing moral protest rather than with backward induction or standard end-game defection/cooperation logic. There is no evidence that the approaching last round changes their priorities; they stay in character rather than “cashing out” rationally.

<PUNISHMENT>
They never spend any coins on punishment despite repeatedly suffering extremely heavy deductions and being insulted by several others. This strongly suggests they reject the use of punitive tools in this environment on principle. Their chat contributions reinforce this: they criticize others specifically for using punishment and ridicule against a single low contributor and then against themselves. They are not interested in deterrence, reciprocity, or retaliation, even when it would be emotionally understandable. Instead, they absorb large losses while continuing to argue against what they see as bullying. They do not selectively punish even clear norm violators; rather than enforce norms, they question the legitimacy of the prevailing norm itself. Their stance is thus “anti-punishment” and anti-bullying: they view the punishment system, as used by others, as morally corrupting, and decline to participate in it even at a significant personal cost.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a moderate, conditionally cooperative contributor who consistently stays below the group’s typical contribution level. They rarely contribute nothing and never contribute the full endowment, instead hovering in a narrow low-to-mid range. Their behavior suggests they understand that contributing something is socially expected or payoff-improving when others are cooperative, but they prioritize individual payoff over strong norm adherence.

They adjust contributions somewhat to the contribution climate: when the group appears more cooperative, they are willing to raise their own contributions modestly, and when cooperation looks weaker or more uneven, they revert to lower contributions. However, these adjustments are incremental rather than drastic; they do not strongly match high contributors, nor do they fully exploit very cooperative environments.

They appear to accept a fairness norm where they “chip in” but let others bear more of the cooperation burden. They do not show evidence of risk-seeking altruism (they never move toward full or near-full contributions even in highly cooperative environments), suggesting a cautious, payoff-conscious orientation. Their pattern shows learning in the sense of finding a comfortable contribution band that keeps them from being the worst contributor while rarely being among the most generous.

Overall, their contribution strategy is: contribute a modest, non-zero amount, keep it relatively stable, adjust only slightly with context, and rely on others’ higher contributions to sustain group returns.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
They show clear awareness of the game horizon but do not drastically change their contribution behavior at the end. Contributions in the final phase remain within the same low-to-mid band as earlier, without any sharp collapse or spike in cooperation. This indicates that they treat the end game as a continuation of their established strategy rather than an opportunity to either fully defect or demonstrate late altruism.

Where they do show an end-game shift is in their use of punishment: as the game approaches its conclusion, they are willing to invest more heavily in sanctioning. Since there is no future interaction to recoup these costs, this late escalation implies that punishment is not purely instrumental for future-payoff incentives; they likely have a preference for norm enforcement or for expressing disapproval, even when there is little scope for future deterrence.

In sum, their end-game pattern is: maintain established contribution levels, but loosen payoff-maximizing constraints on punishment, suggesting stable cooperative caution but stronger willingness to “settle accounts” as the interaction ends.

<PUNISHMENT>
This player is an active and relatively persistent punisher. They spend on punishment in many rounds, and the costliness of the mechanism does not deter them from repeated use. The timing and context of their sanctions indicate that they primarily target low contributors and perceived free riders, consistent with altruistic or norm-enforcing punishment rather than random or purely retaliatory behavior.

They do sometimes receive punishment themselves, but they do not clearly adjust their punishment behavior in a conciliatory way afterward; they continue to sanction others in subsequent rounds. This suggests that their motivation is not easily dampened by being on the receiving end and that they are not mainly using punishment as a tit-for-tat retaliation tool. Instead, they behave as a “moral enforcer” who is willing to pay to discipline defectors, even at a net personal cost.

They are selective rather than maximalist: they do not punish in every single round, and there are cooperative environments where they withhold punishment. However, when clear low contributors are present, they often choose to sanction multiple times per round, especially when defection is stark. Toward the end of the game, they increase both the frequency and intensity of punishment, which supports the interpretation that they value enforcement or expressing disapproval in itself, independent of future strategic benefits.

Overall, their punishment profile is that of a conditional cooperator who under-contributes relative to strong cooperators but over-invests in third-party punishment relative to what is needed for narrow self-interest, indicating a complex mix of self-protection, norm concern, and a willingness to incur costs to police others’ behavior.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a high, reliability‑oriented contributor who anchors well above the group average. They typically give a large share of their endowment, often near or at the maximum allowed, even when many others contribute modest or low amounts. Their behavior suggests a strong internal norm in favor of building and sustaining the public good rather than short‑term self‑maximization.

Contribution levels are not rigidly fixed, but adjustments are moderate rather than extreme. When cooperation in the group weakens or becomes more uneven, they lower their contributions somewhat rather than collapsing to full free‑riding. When cooperation is stronger or more stable, they are comfortable returning to very high or full contributions. This pattern indicates conditional cooperation, but with a generous baseline: they are willing to “lead” in contribution as long as the group is not persistently exploitative.

They appear sensitive to very low or zero contributions from multiple peers. In response to such patterns, they partially reduce their own contributions, balancing frustration with a continued interest in group efficiency. They do not, however, systematically match the lowest contributors; instead, they choose intermediate levels that still support the public good while protecting themselves from being exploited too heavily.

They tolerate being punished despite high contributions without sharply reducing cooperation, suggesting relatively low risk aversion to social sanctions and a willingness to maintain contributions even in an environment with some antisocial punishment. Overall, they prioritize the efficiency and fairness of the group outcome over strict payoff maximization for themselves.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
The player shows awareness of the finite horizon but does not engage in a drastic end‑game collapse of cooperation. Near the end of the game, contributions fluctuate but remain generally high or moderately high rather than dropping toward zero. Even in the final round, they are willing to contribute the entire endowment despite substantial variation and some very low contributions from others.

Instead of a linear decay, their late‑game behavior reflects an interaction between short‑term incentives and experienced group behavior. After periods where others reduce contributions or where the pattern of cooperation is mixed, they sometimes cut their own contribution back to an intermediate level. However, they also show readiness to restore full contributions in later rounds, including the last round, if they still perceive enough cooperative potential.

This pattern suggests they do not fully switch to backward‑induction logic that would predict minimal contributions at the horizon. They appear to maintain a cooperation norm independent of pure final‑round payoff optimization. Their strategy in the end game continues to mix principled cooperation with modest self‑protection, rather than fully exploiting the finite horizon.

<PUNISHMENT>
The player is a frequent and relatively heavy user of costly punishment. They expend punishment in many rounds, and in some cases devote a nontrivial share of their resources to sanctioning others. This indicates a high willingness to incur personal costs to shape group behavior.

Their punishment appears primarily norm‑enforcing rather than random. They are exposed to a mix of cooperative and clearly non‑cooperative behaviors in the group, and their punishment intensity increases when overall contributions drop or when multiple players contribute very little or nothing. Conversely, in periods when group cooperation improves and average contributions are higher, they sometimes refrain from punishing entirely. This pattern is consistent with targeting perceived free‑riding or shirking.

They also receive punishment themselves even when contributing generously, yet they continue to punish others in later periods. This suggests that retaliation for being punished is not their dominant motive; they do not abandon punishment when they become a target, nor do they visibly escalate their use of punishment in strict response to deductions from their own payoff. Instead, their use of sanctions tracks group contribution patterns more than their own treatment.

Selectivity at the individual level is unknown because the transcript does not reveal who they punish, only how much they spend. However, the timing strongly suggests they focus on low contributors rather than punishing indiscriminately. Their pattern fits a “strong reciprocator” or “altruistic punisher” type: they are willing to sacrifice to discipline free‑riders and to support cooperative norms, even though this is individually costly and not guaranteed to be repaid.

Overall, punishment for this player functions as a tool for norm enforcement and deterrence, aimed at sustaining higher contribution levels in the group rather than maximizing their immediate personal payoff.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a moderately cooperative, payoff-sensitive conditional contributor with substantial volatility. Contributions cluster in a mid-to-high range rather than at full free-riding or full cooperation, but fluctuate notably from very low to full endowment. The player often contributes amounts around or somewhat above the emerging group average, but does not consistently match the highest cooperators. When group contributions appear weaker or mixed, the player is willing to lower their own contribution substantially; when the environment looks more cooperative or strategically salient (e.g., when others’ average is high or cooperation seems fragile), the player is willing to raise contributions, including occasionally giving the full endowment. This suggests conditional cooperation rather than a fixed rule.

The player does not appear to follow a simple monotone “end-game defection” pattern; instead, contributions remain in a middle-to-high range even near the end, and can spike or drop in ways that appear responsive to the current social context rather than only to the remaining horizon. They accept earning less in some periods when they contribute more, indicating that they value supporting the public good and/or sending a normative signal, but they are not purely altruistic: at other points they clearly cut contributions down to preserve private payoff when cooperation seems unrewarding or uncertain.

Risk tolerance is moderate. The player is willing to “risk” high contributions in settings where many others are contributing strongly, but they also hedge by reverting to modest or low contributions when cooperation looks less stable. Fairness norms appear present but not rigid. The player behaves as if low contributors should not be allowed to benefit unchecked; their contributions tend to be higher when the rest of the group is contributing a lot, but they are also prepared to pull back and partially free-ride when they perceive others as exploiting the group or when the environment becomes noisy or less cooperative.

Overall, the contribution pattern fits a “conditional cooperator with enforcement tendencies”: they prefer a cooperative norm, are willing to support it materially, but dynamically scale their own giving based on how strongly they believe others are upholding that norm.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
The player displays horizon awareness but does not collapse into pure defection at the end. In late rounds, contributions do not monotonically decline; instead, they remain in a moderate band and sometimes increase relative to nearby rounds. This indicates that the player continues to care about the public good and/or maintaining a fairness standard, even when there is little or no future opportunity for reciprocity or learning.

At the same time, end-game behavior is not naively cooperative. The player simultaneously increases their use of costly punishment late in the game, which suggests an understanding that direct payoff from shaping others’ behavior is limited at this stage, and that end-game punishment functions more as final norm expression than as an investment in future cooperation. Contribution decisions in these final periods seem to balance three motives: preserving some private payoff, maintaining a self-image or norm of not fully free-riding, and backing up that norm through strong enforcement. There is no strong evidence that they are trying to curry favor or avoid retaliation, since punishers and victims are anonymous and future interactions are minimal; thus any sustained cooperation near the end is likely internally motivated rather than purely strategic.

In new environments with visible endpoints, this player is likely to keep contributing at mid-range levels rather than sharply defecting, while potentially intensifying punitive actions as the game nears its conclusion, using the final rounds to underline fairness expectations rather than to maximize last-period income.

<PUNISHMENT>
This player is an active, often heavy, and primarily norm-enforcing punisher. They spend substantial resources on punishment across multiple rounds and do not receive any punishment themselves except once, suggesting their own behavior is generally viewed as acceptable by the group while they target others whom they see as deviating from a cooperation standard.

The triggers for punishment appear to be low or very low contributions relative to the group. The player’s punishment is likely focused on clear under-contributors and possible exploiters of the public good, rather than spread evenly or directed at high contributors. This implies a fairness- and norm-based motive: they punish to discipline free riders and uphold a cooperative standard, not for random aggression. The magnitude of punishment per round is often large, indicating a high willingness to sacrifice own payoff to impose substantial costs on perceived defectors. The player sometimes refrains from punishment entirely in periods where overall cooperation is stronger or where egregious low contributions are fewer, suggesting some selectivity: they are not purely spiteful or punishment-happy in all contexts.

Retaliation as a driver is uncertain. There is one instance in which the player is punished but does not subsequently adjust their behavior in an obvious revenge-like manner toward any identifiable individual (and anonymity prevents precise targeting anyway), so direct retaliation cannot be firmly inferred and seems unlikely to be the core driver. Instead, the pattern is more consistent with second-order norm enforcement: they impose costs on free riders even when doing so reduces their own monetary payoff and even late in the game when deterrence value is low. Deterrence motives are still plausible in earlier and middle phases—strong punishment could be intended to shape future contributions—but the persistence and intensity, especially near the end, point to intrinsic enforcement preferences and strong negative reactions to unfairness.

In new PGG environments with punishment available, this player is expected to: (1) monitor others’ contributions relative to the group norm, (2) punish under-contributors selectively but sometimes heavily, and (3) accept nontrivial personal cost to maintain perceived fairness and protect the cooperative standard, even when material incentives to do so are weak.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a flexible, opportunistic contributor who mixes medium cooperation with episodes of near-complete free-riding. They alternate between contributing roughly half of their endowment and contributing almost nothing, with occasional token amounts. Their behavior suggests they want to benefit from the public good without being the worst contributor, and they sometimes match or slightly undercut the prevailing contribution norm rather than either leading cooperation or fully exploiting it.

They show moderate responsiveness to group behavior: when they are heavily targeted by punishment after low contributions, they reliably jump back up to mid-level contributions in subsequent rounds. When punishment pressure eases, they are willing to return to low or minimal giving, indicating conditional cooperation driven by sanctions more than by an internal fairness norm. They do not insist on perfectly equal contributions; instead, they appear comfortable contributing less than many others as long as punishment risk remains manageable.

Their risk tolerance is moderate: they do at times take the risk of very low contributions even after previous costly sanctions, but they do not escalate to extreme, consistent defection once they see that sanctions can be severe. Instead they oscillate, suggesting a willingness to “test” how much free-riding is tolerable, then retreat toward the group norm when sanctions become intense.

Overall, this is a sanction-sensitive, strategic free-rider: not a pure defector, but someone who prefers contributing less than cooperative peers and adjusts upward primarily in response to observed costs rather than intrinsic commitment to fairness.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
Awareness of the finite horizon does not produce a simple monotonic decay in cooperation. Instead, the player continues their pattern of alternating between mid-range contributions and very low contributions through the later part of the game. Even very late, they sometimes cooperate at moderate levels and sometimes free-ride, rather than converging on full defection.

Severe punishment episodes near the end are followed immediately by higher, more cooperative contributions, indicating that direct payoff feedback matters more to them than abstract end-game logic. They do not appear to adopt a final-round “grab everything” policy; they are still willing to contribute almost nothing in some late rounds but also still return to medium contributions after that. This suggests that, although they can see how many rounds remain, their horizon awareness is weaker than their short-run response to sanctions.

In summary, their end-game behavior is best described as continuing sanction-driven conditional cooperation with opportunistic dips, rather than a deliberate backward-induction collapse of contributions.

<PUNISHMENT>
This player never uses the punishment mechanism, despite multiple opportunities and despite being a repeated target of costly sanctions themselves. They absorb substantial deductions without retaliating or attempting to discipline low contributors, suggesting a strong reluctance to spend their own resources on norm enforcement.

Their non-use of punishment persists across cooperative and non-cooperative phases, indicating a stable trait rather than a situational oversight. This aligns with a payoff-maximizing stance toward the second-order public good: they treat punishment as an unnecessary cost, even when it might deter future sanctions against themselves or stabilize cooperation. There is no evidence of anger-driven retaliation, moralistic punishment, or targeted norm enforcement; their motives appear purely first-order (own payoff from contributions and redistributions), not second-order (shaping others’ behavior via punishment).

Their type is therefore “non-punishing, sanction-sensitive free-rider”: they respond to being punished by adjusting contributions but never themselves invest in punishing others.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a moderately cooperative, payoff-conscious contributor who tends to hover slightly below the prevailing group norm. They usually give a nontrivial, stable mid-range amount rather than fully free-riding or fully contributing. Their pattern suggests they want to benefit from the public good while preserving a meaningful private return each round.

Their contributions show partial but not strict conditional cooperation: they remain in a similar contribution band even when others’ average contributions fluctuate, with only occasional larger deviations. When they lower their contribution well below their usual level, it coincides with environments where many others are giving more, indicating a willingness to “ride” higher cooperation for personal gain. After being heavily punished, they raise their contribution again, implying some responsiveness to the social environment and to sanctions, but they do not swing to maximal cooperation.

They appear to hold a loose fairness norm in which giving something is important, but matching or exceeding the typical group level is not. They seem comfortable being a mild free-rider relative to high contributors while still avoiding the appearance (and risk) of being the lowest contributor. Their contribution choices suggest moderate risk aversion: they never push to extremes like always giving nothing or everything, and they maintain relatively stable, mid-level contributions across most of the game.

Overall, the type is a “cautious, modest cooperator”: they support the public good enough to benefit from it and appear somewhat prosocial, but they systematically shade contributions downward to protect their own payoff.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
The player shows awareness of the game’s finite horizon but does not exhibit a dramatic final collapse of cooperation. Their contribution pattern in the last several rounds stays within their established mid-range with individual deviations rather than a directional trend toward full defection.

They briefly drop to a very low contribution in the late game and receive substantial punishment at that time. Following this, they return to their usual moderate range, including in the very last round. This suggests that late-game strategy is still influenced by expectations of others’ reactions and by a desire to avoid sanctions, rather than purely by backward induction toward zero cooperation.

There is no evidence of an end-game escalation of generosity or of a systematic decay across the final rounds; instead, they continue playing their “middle course” strategy. Their horizon awareness appears present but muted: they adjust opportunistically in some late rounds but quickly revert once the social cost of under-contributing is revealed.

<PUNISHMENT>
The player never spends on punishment despite repeated opportunities and despite being punished themselves, sometimes heavily. This strongly indicates a non-punitive, non-retaliatory style. They neither use punishment to enforce norms nor to get revenge for prior deductions.

Their passivity in the punishment stage suggests they may view punishment as inefficient or strategically unprofitable, prioritizing their own earnings over norm enforcement. Alternatively, they may be conflict-averse or indifferent to sanctioning others, even when facing clear under-contributors in the group. Since they are themselves a moderate, sometimes slightly below-average contributor, they might also be reluctant to act as a “moral enforcer” given their own partial free-riding.

Overall, they fit a “non-punishing opportunist” profile: they accept the punishment institution as a constraint on their own behavior but do not actively use it to shape others’ actions, and they absorb sanctions without escalating or retaliating.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a moderately high, flexible cooperator who anchors around contributing somewhat above the group’s typical level, but not at a rigidly fixed point. They start out relatively generous and remain generally cooperative throughout, with contributions often above the average of others and occasionally at or near full contribution.

Their pattern shows conditional cooperation: when the group’s environment appears cooperative or improving, they are willing to contribute more and even overshoot typical contributions; when there are clear low contributors or more chaotic contribution patterns, they reduce their own input, but they do not collapse into near-zero giving. Instead of sharply matching the lowest contributors, they appear to balance self-interest with a desire to maintain a functioning public good.

They do not display a strong trend of monotonic decay in contributions over time; their behavior fluctuates around a medium‑high level rather than steadily dropping. They sometimes increase contributions after low-contribution episodes, indicating responsiveness rather than pure fatigue or end-game unraveling. They also occasionally contribute substantially when doing so is personally costly in the short run, suggesting they value sustaining cooperation or adhering to a fairness norm more than purely maximizing immediate payoff.

They appear to hold a “fair share plus” norm: they rarely free-ride relative to the group, and often take on a slightly greater burden than many peers, especially when others are cooperating. At the same time, they show some risk sensitivity: they do not blindly give the maximum in uncooperative environments, and they adjust downward when many others contribute very little. This indicates they are attentive to payoff implications and are neither a pure altruist nor a pure egoist.

Overall, they behave as a “prosocial conditional cooperator with moderate self-protection”: willing to pay to sustain cooperation, but adjusting contributions when defecting behavior becomes salient.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
Awareness of the finite horizon does not lead this player to a sharp defection cascade in the last few rounds. Contributions in the final phase remain in the medium‑to‑high range and do not collapse to minimal levels, even in the very last round, where they still contribute a substantial portion of their endowment.

There is no clear evidence that they treat the closing rounds as an opportunity to exploit the group; instead, they continue to behave in line with their earlier cooperative tendencies. Occasional fluctuations in the late game appear more like context-sensitive adjustments (to the current contribution pattern of others) than a principled “last-round grab.” They do not show a progressive step-down pattern that would signal strong backward induction; their end-game behavior is consistent with either limited horizon reasoning, a preference for maintaining norms even when the game is about to end, or a belief that others will also keep cooperating.

Thus, their type is “low unraveling, norm-stable”: they maintain cooperation through the end rather than deliberately exploiting the final opportunities for unilateral gain.

<PUNISHMENT>
This player uses punishment intermittently and in a targeted way, not constantly. They are clearly willing to bear personal cost to penalize others, but they do not punish every round nor in proportion to the total number of low contributors present. This pattern suggests selectivity and some deliberation over when punishment is “worth it.”

Given that punishment is costly and punishment opportunities coincide with visible contribution profiles, the most plausible trigger is perceived free-riding or unusually low contributions relative to the rest of the group. Their punishment is more frequent in environments where some players contribute very little while others contribute a lot, consistent with enforcing a fairness or reciprocity norm. When the overall pattern of contributions is relatively cooperative or when they themselves contribute less, they are more likely to refrain from punishing, indicating they are not simply spiteful or punishment-happy.

Their own experience of being punished in one round does not lead to a clearly retaliatory spike in their subsequent punishment usage. After being sanctioned, they do not suddenly escalate costly punishment against others in a sustained way. This makes pure revenge or spite a low-confidence motive. Instead, their punishment behavior appears more aligned with norm enforcement and deterrence: picking out clear low contributors to discipline, while tolerating moderate variation.

In summary, they are a “conditional norm enforcer”: willing to spend on punishment to correct what they see as unfair low contributions, selectively and without clear evidence of vindictive retaliation.
cluster_intro: This cluster groups personas with related strategy patterns around punishment, contributions, contribution, norm, cooperation.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a mostly stable medium contributor with rare, exploratory free-riding. Their default pattern is to contribute a consistent, moderate amount that tracks close to the emerging group norm. They do not push toward full cooperation, but also do not sit at the lowest contributions; they seem comfortable in a “respectable but not maximal” cooperative band.

They briefly deviate to very low contributions on a couple of occasions after having seen that some others contribute much more and some contribute much less. This suggests they understand the strategic incentive to free-ride and are willing to test it. However, after these low contributions are met with sanctions, they quickly revert to their moderate, stable contribution pattern and maintain it for the rest of the game. That reversion, plus the absence of further low contributions despite some others continuing to under-contribute, indicates that they internalize the lesson that deviating downwards is both risky and socially disapproved.

They appear conditionally cooperative in a bounded way: they match a mid-range cooperative norm rather than mirror the full spectrum of others’ behavior. When others’ average contributions are high, they do not increase to maximum; when multiple others contribute very low or zero, they do not substantially reduce their own contributions once their norm is established. This suggests they value predictability and a stable strategy over finely tuned responsiveness, and they may be using a simple heuristic like “contribute a fair, round number that feels cooperative” rather than optimizing on each round.

They tolerate some inequity: they regularly coexist with both higher and lower contributors without adjusting much. This implies either low sensitivity to fairness deviations or a belief that attempting to correct such deviations is not worth the cognitive or strategic effort. Their brief free-riding episodes, followed by compliance, show that they are willing to exploit the group when it seems safe, but they abandon that approach once it is clearly costly.

Their risk tolerance is moderate. They initially experiment with low contributions despite the presence of punishment, which is risky, but once punished they avoid further experimentation. They are not aggressively opportunistic; instead, they calibrate quickly toward a safer, cooperative equilibrium. Overall, they present as a “norm-following conditional cooperator with limited opportunism”: inclined to cooperate at a moderate level, aware of free-riding incentives, but ultimately deterred by social sanctions and content to stick with a simple, steady rule.


<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
The player shows strong horizon awareness in the sense that they know the game length, but there is no observable end-game defection. Their contribution level remains essentially unchanged as the final rounds approach and even in the very last round. They neither ramp up cooperation nor exploit the final period to free-ride.

This absence of end-game decay suggests one of several non-exclusive possibilities: they may anchor on a stable contribution norm and treat each round similarly; they may not prioritize marginal end-of-horizon gains over consistency; or they may expect that others will maintain contributions and see no reason to deviate. There is no evidence of a deliberate “last-round grab,” even though the strategic logic of finitely repeated PGGs would permit it.

Because they have learned that deviating downward attracts punishment earlier in the game, they might also believe that even late-stage free-riding could be sanctioned, and they are unwilling to risk that. Whether this belief is explicit or just encoded as a simple “don’t rock the boat” heuristic is unknown. In any case, their behavior is horizon-stable: they act as if the shadow of future punishment and/or the value of a consistent strategy persists right up to the end.

They do not exhibit escalation in cooperation either: they do not increase contributions beyond their usual level to “leave on a good note” or to try to boost the final-round group payoff. This supports the view that they follow a relatively rigid contribution rule rather than dynamically recalibrating to the countdown of remaining rounds.


<PUNISHMENT>
The player never uses punishment at any point, despite being exposed repeatedly to others’ contributions that range from zero to maximum. They also receive nontrivial punishment themselves after low contributions, yet they do not retaliate. This consistent non-use of punishment persists regardless of others’ behavior or the remaining rounds.

This pattern indicates a strong reluctance—or principled refusal—to spend personal resources to sanction others. Whether this stems from prosocial motives (disliking harm) or purely self-interested cost avoidance is unclear. What is clear is that they do not engage in norm enforcement, even when it would align with their later cooperative behavior and even when punishing chronic low contributors might improve future outcomes. They accept being a target of punishment without observable attempts at revenge, suggesting low retributive motivation and a tendency to adapt through changing their own behavior rather than trying to control others.

Because they never punish when others contribute very low amounts, they likely either believe that the punishment mechanism is inefficient for them personally, or they simply adopt a “live and let live” stance, focusing on their own contributions. There is no evidence they attempt to use punishment for deterrence, coordination, or signaling. Their strategy is purely reactive through contribution adjustments, not active through sanctions.

Overall, they fit a “non-punishing conditional cooperator” profile: they are responsive to being punished—raising their contributions afterward—but they themselves do not impose punishment under any observed condition.
