text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a mostly high-contributing conditional cooperator with some opportunistic and spiteful deviations. After initially free-riding, they settle into a pattern of contributing fully in most rounds, even when others increasingly withhold. They continue to contribute in many situations where a purely self-interested or efficiency-focused player would stop, indicating that they value sustaining a norm of contribution or “doing their part” more than strictly maximizing short-term payoff.

Their contributions are clearly conditional: they do not always contribute. When they withhold, it tends to coincide with environments where others are also withholding or where the contribution structure is unstable. They are willing to return to high contributions after non-cooperative episodes, suggesting they do not fully “give up” on the public good. There is no clear evidence of finely tuned tit-for-tat; instead the player alternates between high-commitment cooperator and frustrated free-rider depending on the perceived social climate.

They accept substantial personal payoff losses from contributing in low-cooperation environments, which shows low narrow risk aversion and low concern for short-term monetary optimization. Their behavior is compatible with a fairness or norm-based utility: they prefer to act in line with their own standard of contribution and then attempt to regulate others via punishment, rather than adjusting contributions purely to match the group’s average.

Overall, they are a “stubborn norm cooperator”: they lean strongly toward full contribution as their default, deviate into non-contribution in some low-trust situations, but repeatedly revert to cooperation rather than permanently defecting.

<PUNISHMENT>
This player is a heavy, sometimes self-destructive punisher with a strong taste for sanctioning, and their punishment pattern is only loosely tied to efficiency or clear reciprocity. For many rounds they choose not to punish at all, but when they do punish, they often spend large amounts relative to their payoff, including cases where punishment drives their own earnings to very low or negative values. That indicates they derive intrinsic value from imposing costs on others or from expressing disapproval, even when it is materially harmful to themselves.

Their punishment is not narrowly targeted only at low contributors. They sometimes punish in high-cooperation contexts and sometimes punish in ways that are not obviously aligned with social efficiency, suggesting motives that include anger, revenge, or moralistic expression rather than calibrated deterrence. At the same time, they do not punish continuously or mechanically: there are many rounds where they absorb deductions or observe questionable behavior yet choose not to retaliate or sanction. This discontinuity suggests their threshold for punishing is context-dependent and emotional rather than rule-based.

They show willingness to incur high punishment costs late in the game, which is inconsistent with strategic investment in future cooperation (since future rounds are limited and unknown). This supports an interpretation of punishment as expressive or spiteful rather than purely instrumental. They do not appear to systematically reward high cooperators via leniency; their punishment is more about targeting perceived offenders than about positively reinforcing allies.

In short, they are a “volatile altruistic/spiteful punisher”: willing to take very large personal costs to hurt or discipline others, but without a consistently transparent or efficiency-minded rule for when and whom to punish.

<RESPONSE_TO_PUNISHER>
This player frequently receives punishment from others, both when they contribute and when they do not. Their observable responses suggest neither straightforward deterrence nor pure retaliation.

They do not reliably respond to being punished by shifting to more compliant, safer strategies; after being sanctioned, they are still willing to contribute fully and sometimes also escalate their own use of punishment. Thus, punishment does not consistently cow them into low-visibility, low-impact play. At the same time, they do not engage in clear one-to-one vendettas: there is no clean pattern of “you punished me, I punish you next time” targeting specific counterparts, at least not one that can be unambiguously inferred from aggregate behavior. Their retaliation, if present, is noisy and folded into broader sanctioning of the group.

They tolerate repeated punishment without withdrawing completely from contribution; instead, they oscillate between cooperative and non-cooperative episodes. This suggests a personality that is resistant to social pressure and willing to stick with self-defined norms, even under direct sanctions. When they do punish after having been punished, the intensity indicates an emotional or pride component—“I won’t be pushed around”—but the targets cannot be clearly mapped to specific punishers from prior rounds based solely on the transcript, so any claim about direct revenge against identifiable individuals is low confidence.

Overall, they are relatively punishment-insensitive in the deterrence sense and potentially revenge-prone in a diffuse way, but not reliably tit-for-tat against specific punishers.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
This player is highly responsive to the broader pattern of others’ contributions, payoffs, and sanctioning, but in a coarse, affect-driven rather than fine-tuned way.

They appear to infer “climate” from others’ outcomes: when others’ contributions and payouts reveal a relatively cooperative environment, they are willing to keep contributing fully, even when doing so is individually costly relative to free-riding. When they see strong evidence of chaos—heavy mutual punishment, extreme payoffs, and turbulent sanctioning—they are more likely to switch into punishing mode or occasionally into non-contribution, indicating frustration or moral outrage at perceived unfairness or disorder.

They seem particularly triggered by players who obtain very high payoffs under low contribution or benefit from others’ cooperation while not matching it. In such contexts they expend large punishment resources, even at considerable self-cost, suggesting an aversion to others “getting away with” advantageous outcomes. They also sometimes punish when many others are already engaged in aggressive sanctioning, hinting at a tendency to join or amplify punitive norms once a punishment spiral is underway.

However, they do not simply mirror the average: there are cooperative peers they do not bother to “protect” with counter-punishment, and there are defectors they sometimes ignore. Their reactions to others’ outcomes are therefore selective and likely governed by internal, partly emotional evaluations of who “deserves” what, rather than a stable enforcement policy.

In summary, they track others’ contributions and payoffs and are strongly motivated by perceived unfair advantages and breakdowns of cooperation, using punishment and stubborn contributions to express and enforce their personal norms, even when this sharply lowers their own earnings.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is an unstable, opportunistic free-rider with intermittent cooperation. They alternate between full contribution and full defection rather than choosing intermediate levels (which are not available here), and they do not settle into a consistent cooperative or non-cooperative regime.

They sometimes contribute fully even when others’ average contributions are relatively low, and sometimes free-ride when others are contributing a lot. This indicates weak conditional cooperation: they do not reliably match the group’s behavior, and their own pattern shows no clear upward or downward trend; instead it is volatile and context-insensitive.

They tolerate substantial inequality in their favor, repeatedly taking high private payoffs while others contribute more. They also occasionally accept very poor personal payoffs when choosing to contribute and punish heavily, suggesting that immediate monetary maximization is not their sole priority.

Fairness norms are weak or inconsistent. They show no clear pattern of “if most others contribute, I will too” or “if most defect, I will defect.” Their contribution choices do not consistently reward cooperators or punish defectors through contribution behavior itself.

Risk tolerance appears moderate to high: they are willing to expose themselves to negative or very low round payoffs (especially in combination with heavy punishment) without an observable adaptive correction toward safer, lower-variance strategies.

Overall, they act as a noisy, self-regarding player who occasionally experiments with cooperation but does not anchor on a stable pro-social or purely selfish strategy.

<PUNISHMENT>
This player is an unusually heavy and sometimes extreme punisher, with a pattern consistent with antisocial or spiteful punishment rather than norm-enforcing punishment.

They frequently spend large amounts on punishment, sometimes to the point of driving their own payoff into strongly negative territory. This shows that they are willing to sacrifice considerable personal income purely to reduce others’ payoffs. Such willingness is hard to reconcile with purely instrumental, payoff-maximizing motives; it is more consistent with emotional or expressive motives (e.g., spite, frustration) or with a distorted notion of “justice” that does not track contributions.

Their targeting is not aligned with standard reciprocal fairness norms. They do not focus their punishment selectively on low contributors or consistent free-riders. In several instances, they punish players who are contributing fully or more than they are. This lack of alignment with contribution levels indicates that punishment is not primarily used to enforce cooperation norms.

They also do not display a clear deterrence strategy: there is no observable tightening or relaxing of punishment in line with changes in others’ behavior, nor a consistent focus on repeat low contributors. Instead, the pattern looks erratic and high-intensity, with large punishment bursts directed at specific individuals at different times.

Selectivity is low: when they do decide to punish, they sometimes punish multiple players and at high intensity, rather than carefully choosing minimal-cost interventions. Given the cost-benefit ratio of punishment, their choices often reduce their own payoff without producing obvious strategic benefits.

Taken together, their punishment profile suggests a “spiteful / antisocial punisher” type: willing to incur costs to harm others, not reliably linked to contribution norms, and with little evidence of strategic calibration.

<RESPONSE_TO_PUNISHER>
This player receives punishment on multiple occasions from various others. Their behavioral response does not indicate compliance or accommodation: after being punished, they do not reliably shift toward the punisher’s apparent norm (for example, they do not consistently move from free-riding to contributing, nor from heavy punishment to restraint).

There is also no clear pattern of targeted retaliation against identifiable punishers. Although punishers are identifiable, the player’s punishment behavior is too broad and erratic to cleanly infer tit-for-tat responses. Sometimes they later punish players who had previously punished them, but they also punish players who did not punish them and fail to punish some past punishers. Because of this inconsistency, any retaliatory motive is at best low-confidence and mixed with other motives.

They show no visible “forgiveness” dynamic: punishment from others does not lead them to stop punishing those individuals, nor to adopt more cooperative contributions toward them. Instead, their own punishment and contribution patterns continue in a similarly volatile manner regardless of who has sanctioned them.

Overall, they appear relatively insensitive to being punished in terms of strategic adjustment. They neither consistently appease punishers with cooperative behavior nor reliably escalate against them; they continue following their own idiosyncratic pattern.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
This player observes detailed end-of-round outcomes, including others’ payoffs, punishment expenditures, and received deductions, yet their subsequent behavior does not seem systematically guided by these outcomes.

They do not clearly reward players who sacrifice payoff to enforce cooperation, nor do they consistently ally with, imitate, or avoid heavy punishers. Similarly, they do not preferentially protect high contributors from punishment; they repeatedly allow or participate in environments where cooperators are heavily punished without adjusting their own contribution or punishment strategy to stabilize the group.

They appear largely unconcerned with the efficiency of group outcomes. They sometimes choose actions (especially heavy punishment combined with contribution) that drive total welfare down and harm themselves, even when others are already incurring large costs. There is no sign that they shift toward more restrained behavior when they see others generating very low or negative payoffs through aggressive punishment, nor that they exploit this chaos in a reliably payoff-maximizing way.

Their reaction to others’ extreme punishments is thus best characterized as indifferent or opportunistic rather than coordinated or norm-driven. They do not emulate high-earning strategies consistently, nor do they react to others’ misfortunes with protection or restraint. If anything, they sometimes contribute nothing and avoid punishment, letting others bear the cost of chaotic sanctioning while they collect high free-rider payoffs.

In summary, this player processes others’ outcomes in a way that does not translate into stable reciprocity, coalition-building, or efficiency-seeking. Their type is a volatile, opportunistic free-rider with a strong antisocial punishment streak, low responsiveness to sanctions, and minimal regard for group welfare or coherent norm enforcement.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a mostly high contributor with intermittent free‑riding. They usually give the full endowment, but occasionally give nothing even when many others contribute or when they themselves were just punished. Their choices do not track public contributions in a simple conditional‑cooperator pattern; they both contribute fully in mostly low‑contribution environments and free‑ride when many others are contributing. This suggests a mix of a cooperative self‑image with opportunistic deviations rather than a strict fairness rule.

They do not appear to optimize for immediate monetary payoff: they repeatedly choose the dominated full‑contribution option even when the group is trending low and they have been losing coins to punishment. The intermittent free‑riding looks more like sporadic experimentation or emotional reaction than a systematic profit‑maximizing strategy. Risk tolerance toward potentially being punished for free‑riding is moderate: they free‑ride a few times but overall revert to full contributions rather than sustaining a pure defector strategy.

Fairness norms are inconsistent: the player sometimes cooperates in clearly unfair environments and sometimes defects in relatively cooperative ones. This suggests they care about cooperation but do not rigidly tie their own behavior to others’ average contribution; instead they seem driven by internal motives or shifting moods more than by strict reciprocity.

<PUNISHMENT>
The player sometimes engages in costly punishment, but not every time others defect, and not in a consistent tit‑for‑tat pattern. They punish in multiple nonadjacent rounds and spend nontrivial amounts when they do, indicating a willingness to incur personal cost to sanction others. However, there are also many situations with salient low contributors where they choose not to punish at all, so they are selective rather than a systematic enforcer.

The targeting pattern is opaque from the aggregate summaries alone; it is clear only that they do not exclusively punish the worst contributors and they do not always punish those who punished them earlier. This implies motives that mix norm enforcement with occasional expressive or retaliatory elements, but with low confidence on exact triggers. They also punish in late stages when there is little future to influence, which suggests that deterrence is not their sole motive; expressing disapproval or “getting even” likely matters.

They never use punishment to reward cooperators or to fine‑tune others’ earnings; all punishment is purely subtractive. Combined with their own repeated losses, this indicates they are willing to accept significant personal cost for sanctions, so long as they subjectively perceive a deviation or offense, even if outside observers might see this as inefficient.

<RESPONSE_TO_PUNISHER>
When they themselves are punished, they do not display a clear, consistent pattern of retaliation or compliance. After being fined, they sometimes continue to contribute fully, sometimes switch to free‑riding, and sometimes also begin or increase their own punishment of others. They do not systematically target all who punished them; there is no clear one‑for‑one retaliation against every punisher. This suggests that while they may occasionally react to being targeted, they are not narrowly vindictive.

They also do not reliably “reward” punishment by conforming to a cooperator norm after being sanctioned. At times they maintain high contributions despite repeated deductions, which may reflect a stubborn adherence to their own preferred behavior rather than obedience to external pressure. At other times they defect after being punished, which could signal frustration or disengagement rather than learning.

Overall, their response to punishers is best characterized as noisy and internally driven: they neither meekly comply with sanctions nor systematically strike back. Whether they interpret punishment as informative, hostile, or arbitrary is unknown; their mixed behavioral adjustments imply that they do not construct a stable model of specific punishers over the course of the game.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
The player observes others’ payoffs and punishment patterns but reacts in a complex, nonmonotonic way. They sometimes respond to widespread low contributions and heavy sanctioning by continuing to cooperate, absorbing personal losses while others fight; at other times, in similarly conflictual environments, they free‑ride. This suggests they do not anchor strongly on group payoff efficiency, nor do they purely imitate the financially successful: they occasionally adopt the payoff‑dominated cooperative action, and occasionally exploit cooperative groups.

They appear somewhat sensitive to extreme behavior: when some players spend very large amounts punishing or are heavily punished, the focal player is more likely to use punishment themselves, though not predictably against those specific high‑spenders. This points to an awareness that the social environment is tense or norm‑contested, and a willingness to participate in that contest even at a loss.

There is no stable tendency to align with the “majority strategy”: they contribute fully when others are split or mostly defecting and also defect when others are mostly cooperating. Likewise, players who obtain very high or very low payoffs are not treated in a consistently favorable or hostile way. This indicates that the focal player tracks others’ outcomes but does not use a simple rule like “punish the richest” or “punish those hurting the group most.”

In sum, this player behaves like a conflicted cooperator: they value contributing and occasionally enforcing norms, yet alternate between principled cooperation, opportunistic defection, and sporadic costly punishment without a clearly stable, payoff‑based rule. Their type is best modeled as a high‑variance, emotionally responsive cooperator rather than a strict conditional cooperator or a pure egoist.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a volatile, strategically opportunistic contributor who oscillates between full cooperation and full free-riding. They never choose intermediate amounts; they treat contribution as a binary signal. They are willing to fully cooperate at times, but only inconsistently, and they often revert to keeping their entire endowment even when many others are contributing. Their behavior suggests weak or unstable internal fairness norms: they sometimes join high-contribution profiles, but they are comfortable free-riding on others’ generosity and do not systematically match or reciprocate the group’s average behavior. They appear relatively insensitive to the efficiency logic of the public good, as they repeatedly choose patterns that sacrifice their own round payoffs through heavy punishment rather than stabilize a high-contribution equilibrium. Overall, they behave more like a tactician in a conflict than like a welfare- or fairness-maximizer within the public good.

<PUNISHMENT>
This player is a very heavy, aggressive user of punishment, often spending a large share of their available payoff to reduce others’ earnings. They are not narrowly targeting clear free-riders; instead they frequently punish multiple peers heavily, including those who are contributing at or near the group norm. Their punishment is not tightly aligned with contribution levels or with maximizing future gains; it often looks like broad, hostile sanctioning or “control” of others rather than calibrated norm enforcement. They do not show clear evidence of using minimal, cost-effective punishment for deterrence; instead, they regularly overspend on sanctions, sometimes driving their own payoff very low or negative. The pattern is consistent with a willingness to incur substantial personal cost to hurt or dominate others, even when that does not appear instrumentally rational. There is also no consistent pattern of them easing up on targets after those targets change behavior, suggesting low responsiveness to deterrence feedback and a greater role for emotional or retributive motives than for strategic norm-building.

<RESPONSE_TO_PUNISHER>
When they are punished, this player does not reliably respond with appeasement or clear compliance. They continue to mix cooperative and uncooperative contributions after being sanctioned and often maintain or even escalate their own use of punishment. There is no obvious evidence that they selectively retaliate against specific identifiable punishers; their punishment is too diffuse and widespread to confidently infer targeted revenge. Instead, their reaction to being punished appears to be: (a) persistence in their own strategic flexibility on contributions, and (b) continued or intensified willingness to punish others broadly. This suggests a low tendency toward forgiveness and a low tendency to “submit” to others’ sanctioning; they do not appear to internalize others’ punishment as a cue to conform, but rather continue following their own aggressive pattern. Whether they consciously track who punished them is unknown; at best, any retaliation is indirect or submerged within generally hostile sanctioning.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
This player closely uses the punishment stage to respond to how others are doing, but not in a way that clearly supports reciprocity or joint welfare. They frequently direct punishment toward players who earn high payoffs or who avoid punishment themselves, regardless of those players’ contribution levels, suggesting some mix of outcome-based envy, competitive leveling, or aversion to others getting ahead. They do not reward high contributors by protecting them from punishment; instead, they sometimes attack high earners even when those players cooperate. Conversely, they sometimes refrain from punishing low contributors, and at other times include them in broader sanctioning, indicating that others’ payoffs and conflict dynamics matter more than a clean contribution norm. They also do not appear to condition strongly on others’ own punishment costs (for example, punishing those who punish a lot, or sparing those who self-sacrifice); any such pattern is weak or inconsistent. Overall, they treat others’ outcomes as a field on which to impose losses and shape relative standings, rather than as feedback to coordinate on efficient cooperation.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a predominantly self-interested free-rider with opportunistic and somewhat erratic cooperation. They consistently favor taking the full private endowment when others are contributing, and they never appear to follow a stable reciprocity rule. They sometimes contribute fully despite others contributing less, and at other times they free-ride while most others cooperate, suggesting low concern for fairness norms and low sensitivity to conditional cooperation cues. Their pattern does not clearly track recent punishment, payoff level, or average group contribution; instead, their choices alternate between full contribution and zero in a way that appears weakly strategic at best and often myopic. They show no clear risk-averse attempt to avoid being singled out as a defector—on the contrary, they repeatedly remain the sole or one of very few non-contributors in highly cooperative profiles. Overall, they behave as a mostly selfish, unstable contributor who occasionally cooperates but does not uphold any consistent fairness or reciprocity standard.

<PUNISHMENT>
This player almost never uses the punishment option and spends nothing on it in the great majority of rounds. When they do punish, they spend a large amount in one instance, despite not being a strong cooperator themselves. This rare, high-intensity use is not clearly targeted to enforce cooperation in any consistent way, as they do not follow it with a stable cooperative pattern themselves, nor do they establish any ongoing sanctioning role. There is no visible pattern of selectively punishing clear free-riders while sparing cooperators, and their overwhelming default is to abstain from punishment entirely. This suggests a type that is generally unwilling to incur personal cost to enforce norms, with a possible one-off spike of punitive behavior whose motive is ambiguous (could be frustration, retaliation, or a noisy attempt at norm enforcement; confidence low). They do not appear to use punishment systematically as a deterrent tool.

<RESPONSE_TO_PUNISHER>
This player is repeatedly punished across the game, often when they free-ride while others contribute more. Despite this, they do not reliably “comply” by switching into sustained cooperation after being punished. Sometimes they contribute fully after having been punished; at other times they continue to free-ride even after receiving substantial deductions. There is no clear one-to-one retaliatory pattern against specific punishers: when they finally do invest heavily in punishment, the target pattern is not obviously tied to a single prior punisher, and they do not become a persistent counter-punisher. Overall, they show low responsiveness to sanctions in terms of long-term behavioral change and do not clearly adopt either a forgiving (shift to cooperation) or a vengeful (systematic retaliation) stance. Their response to being punished appears inconsistent and weakly strategic, with no stable compliance rule.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
This player observes others repeatedly spending heavily to punish and sometimes driving their own or others’ payoffs very low, yet they continue to pursue primarily self-interested contributions and rarely join the enforcement efforts. High costs borne by others for norm enforcement do not lead them to adopt those same norms or to emulate that role. They also do not seem to reward cooperators indirectly (e.g., by aligning their contributions with cooperative clusters); instead, they often free-ride exactly when others are most cooperative. They do not systematically avoid punishing those who are already heavily penalized, nor do they visibly “protect” victims of severe punishment; in practice, they mostly remain a bystander. Group-level payoff patterns—such as the presence of very high contributors who get attacked, or chaotic punishment cascades—do not induce them to shift into a stabilizing or coordinating role. In sum, they react to others’ outcomes largely by continuing their own opportunistic strategy rather than by norm alignment, coalition-building, or payoff-smoothing behavior.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a volatile, opportunistic contributor with no stable norm of either full cooperation or pure free-riding. They alternate repeatedly between giving everything and giving nothing, rather than using intermediate levels (which are unavailable), and this switching does not settle into a clear pattern of “always cooperate after X” or “always defect after Y.” They sometimes contribute even when others contribute less than them, and sometimes free-ride on many high contributors, suggesting that short-term payoff maximization is important but not applied consistently or mechanically. They tolerate personal losses in some cooperative choices, so they are not purely payoff-maximizing in a narrow, round-by-round sense. There is no clear fairness norm: they are willing to contribute while many others do not, and equally willing to take the full endowment while others contribute heavily. Their behavior indicates experimental and reactive decision-making, likely driven by recent mood about group conflict and punishment rather than a stable pro- or anti-cooperation principle. Risk tolerance appears moderate: they sometimes expose themselves to being a lone high contributor and sometimes to being an obvious free-rider; both choices are accepted without visible adjustment aimed at avoiding being targeted.

<PUNISHMENT>
The player is an active, costly punisher who sometimes spends heavily, accepting very low or even negative net payoffs in those rounds. They target multiple peers in some instances and are willing to forgo substantial income to impose deductions, consistent with strong emotional or norm-enforcing motives rather than pure efficiency. However, their punishment is not consistently aligned with a clear cooperation norm: they punish both low and high contributors at different times, and at other times they abstain from punishing in situations where a strict norm-enforcer would be expected to act. Their choices appear more like episodic outbursts when they feel wronged or see extreme behavior, not a steady “punish all defectors” rule. This makes deterrence-based motives uncertain; if deterrence is a goal, it is executed inconsistently, likely limiting its effectiveness. Retaliatory or expressive motives are more plausible: when they choose to punish, they are willing to pay substantial costs to do so, suggesting that expressing disapproval or venting frustration is at least as important as changing others’ future contributions. Selectivity is therefore low in principle (they are willing to punish broadly) but in practice fluctuates round to round, implying that their threshold for acting depends on recent interactions and the overall conflict climate rather than a stable rule.

<RESPONSE_TO_PUNISHER>
When punished, the player does not display a clear, consistent shift toward either appeasement or counter-retaliation. They sometimes continue to free-ride after being punished and sometimes continue to cooperate after being targeted, indicating that punishment does not reliably induce compliance. There is no systematic pattern of punishing specific prior punishers in the following round, so directed revenge against identifiable punishers is at most sporadic and cannot be cleanly inferred. Likewise, there is no clear pattern of switching to stable high contributions to avoid further sanctions. Their response is best described as emotionally resilient or indifferent at the strategic level: they absorb punishment, occasionally adjust contributions, but not in a way that clearly signals “I comply to avoid costs” or “I retaliate against you.” Forgiveness vs. resentment is unknown; the observable actions do not cleanly map to one or the other.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
The player appears sensitive to the overall conflict and payoff landscape rather than to specific individual outcomes. They continue to play and sometimes cooperate even as other players burn large amounts of coins on punishment and drive their own and others’ payoffs very low, which suggests a tolerance for chaotic or hostile environments and an interest in remaining engaged rather than withdrawing or purely exploiting. They do not systematically align with “victims” or “aggressors”: they sometimes join the general punitive atmosphere and sometimes sit out of punishment even when others are being heavily targeted. They observe that some players repeatedly spend extreme amounts on punishment and that some end up with strongly negative or very low round payoffs, yet this does not push them into a consistent stabilizing or exploitative role. Instead, they oscillate: sometimes joining the sanctioning crowd, sometimes quietly taking advantage of high contributions by others. Overall, they react to others’ outcomes in a way that indicates curiosity and situational experimentation rather than a fixed empathy norm or a strict payoff-comparison rule. Their type is best described as a reactive, emotionally willing punisher and opportunistic contributor who learns slowly and locally, without converging on a stable, norm-driven strategy.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player shows a bimodal contribution pattern, alternating between full cooperation and full free-riding rather than using intermediate or mixed strategies. They are clearly willing to contribute the maximum when many others also contribute and when the environment does not feel hostile, but they also repeatedly choose to free-ride after experiencing being targeted by punishment. The shifts between contributing and not contributing do not follow a simple monotonic trend; instead, they appear contingent on recent treatment by others and the perceived fairness of the group, rather than on optimizing expected monetary payoff. They do not appear to condition their contribution strongly on specific individuals’ behavior (for example, they sometimes contribute even when several others free-ride, and they sometimes free-ride when several others contribute). This suggests that their primary reference point is the overall climate of hostility or safety, not fine-grained reciprocity. Their intermittently cooperative choices, despite low marginal returns to the public good and frequent victimization, indicate that they are not purely payoff-maximizing; they are willing to incur significant personal cost to uphold a cooperative pattern when they feel it is viable. At the same time, their repeated switches back to free-riding after being punished indicate a readiness to abandon cooperation when they feel exploited, implying a conditional, emotionally reactive cooperator rather than a stable altruist.

<PUNISHMENT>
This player is a relatively low-frequency punisher but, when they do punish, they use it intensely and at high personal cost. They do not appear to engage in systematic sanctioning of all low contributors; instead, their punishment is highly selective and clustered in a few episodes. Those episodes tend to occur after they have cooperated and been subjected to what is likely perceived as unfair or hostile treatment, suggesting that retaliation and norm-enforcement motives are intertwined. They are willing to sacrifice a large share of their earnings in one burst of punishment, which is inconsistent with narrow monetary self-interest and points to strong negative reciprocity or anger. There is no clear evidence that they are trying to use punishment as a calibrated deterrent (for example, they do not consistently target the worst free-riders across the game, and they do not maintain a steady, proportional sanctioning pattern). Instead, punishment appears episodic and emotionally driven: they mostly refrain from punishing, tolerate a hostile environment for many rounds, then at one point spend heavily in a way that harms others more than it benefits them. After these large punishment expenditures, they revert to non-punishing behavior even when they themselves continue to be targeted, suggesting that they do not maintain long-run vendettas and may quickly exhaust or set aside retaliatory impulses once expressed. Overall, they behave like a grudging retaliator rather than a systematic norm enforcer or a strategic punisher.

<RESPONSE_TO_PUNISHER>
This player is punished in many rounds, often despite contributing fully or more than some peers, and appears to interpret such punishment as illegitimate or hostile. They do not visibly “comply” with punishers by increasing contributions afterward; in fact, repeated punishment is followed by phases of free-riding and, at one point, intense counter-punishment. This indicates that being punished does not induce them to align with any perceived norm; instead, it undermines their willingness to cooperate and increases their readiness to retaliate. However, the retaliation is not targeted in a clear, one-to-one way at specific named punishers—at least not in a pattern that can be reliably inferred from the transcript. This makes their response more consistent with diffuse revenge against the group climate rather than precise tit-for-tat. After expressing retaliation through costly punishment, they do not persist in punishing the same environment in subsequent rounds even though they keep receiving sanctions; this suggests that their anger response is acute rather than chronic, that they are capable of “moving on” behaviorally even if they do not return to stable cooperation. They never show a pattern of “forgiving through compliance” (i.e., adapting contributions upward to avoid further punishment), so their type resists coercion and does not reward aggressors with greater cooperation.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
This player closely observes others’ contributions and the punishment structure, and appears sensitive to the collective payoff environment, but they do not track or match individual payoffs in a fine-grained way. They are willing to continue cooperating even while seeing some others gain from free-riding and from aggressive punishment use, which implies tolerance for unequal outcomes up to a point. However, when the environment becomes heavily punitive and others spend large amounts on harming each other, the player’s behavior shifts: they free-ride more and, in one episode, engage in very costly punishment themselves. This pattern suggests that high visible hostility and destruction of payoffs by others reduces their commitment to the public good and triggers a desire to impose losses back on the group, even at a net cost to themselves. There is no evidence that they try to align with the high-earning strategies in order to imitate success; instead, they pursue a personally meaningful notion of fairness or dignity, sometimes accepting lower payoffs rather than conforming to the most profitable but hostile patterns. They seem particularly affected by seeing cooperative players punished or by being punished themselves despite cooperative behavior, which likely leads them to infer that others are not trustworthy partners in sustaining fairness. Thus, their responses to others’ outcomes are driven more by perceived justice and aggression levels than by pure payoff comparisons or envy.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is primarily a free-rider with occasional, short-lived switches to full contribution. Their baseline is to keep their entire endowment and live off others’ contributions, even when most others contribute. They only ever use the extreme options available (all or nothing) and show no gradual adjustment, suggesting simple heuristic play rather than fine-tuned optimization. Full contributions appear sporadically and do not persist even when others also contribute a lot, indicating that they do not strongly internalize a cooperative norm or aim for stable reciprocity. They tolerate benefiting from others’ generosity without matching it and do not appear concerned with aligning their behavior to group averages. Their risk tolerance regarding cooperation is low: when in doubt, they default to defection and prioritize immediate personal payoff over potential collective gain. Any cooperative moves seem exploratory or context-reactive rather than part of a sustained fairness norm. Their fairness preferences are weak or inconsistent: they sometimes join high-contribution environments but do not maintain that stance when it would require sacrificing their own payoff repeatedly.

<PUNISHMENT>
They make relatively infrequent use of punishment and, when they do punish, it is light and isolated rather than part of a systematic enforcement strategy. There is no clear pattern of punishing low contributors versus high contributors; their punishment choices do not obviously track cooperative norms, defectors, or extreme punishers. They do not appear to engage in costly norm enforcement aimed at stabilizing cooperation, nor do they join group-wide punishment cascades. Their spending on punishment is modest overall, consistent with a preference to preserve their own payoffs rather than invest heavily in shaping others’ behavior. Motivationally, the limited and sporadic punishment suggests either mild expressive reactions (e.g., annoyance at being targeted or at seeming unfairness) or experimentation with the mechanism rather than deliberate deterrence. They are not vengeful in any obvious, sustained way and do not escalate punishment in response to others’ aggression. Selectivity and targeting rules are unclear (low-confidence: unknown); there is no strong evidence they systematically reward cooperators or sanction free-riders via punishment choices.

<RESPONSE_TO_PUNISHER>
They experience substantial punishment across the game but do not clearly retaliate against specific identified punishers, nor do they shift toward stable cooperation to appease them. When punished, their subsequent contributions generally remain low or revert to defection after brief cooperative excursions, suggesting limited compliance with punitive pressure. There is no consistent pattern of “hit back at whoever punished me” visible; their rare uses of punishment do not line up clearly with those who previously targeted them, at least at the coarse resolution available here. This indicates a relatively low retaliatory drive, or at least low willingness to spend on revenge. At the same time, they also do not respond with durable “forgiveness-and-cooperation” after being sanctioned; their cooperative switches are temporary and do not map cleanly onto punishments received, so any appeasement motive is weak or absent. Overall, they appear behaviorally resistant to social control via punishment: they absorb deductions and continue to prioritize self-benefit, with only short, inconsistent deviations toward cooperation.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
They observe others repeatedly spending heavily on punishment and sometimes driving their own or others’ payoffs negative, yet they do not join these extremes. This suggests they notice but do not imitate costly moralistic or spiteful behavior. They seem content to let others bear the cost of enforcing or attacking, while they maintain a relatively payoff-protective stance. Very high punishment expenditures by others do not trigger a clear change in their own contribution level; they neither become significantly more cooperative to avoid becoming a target nor start punishing in solidarity with other punishers. Likewise, they do not clearly favor or protect consistent cooperators; they neither reward nor materially defend those who contribute a lot or suffer high deductions. Their reaction to others’ payoffs and punishment patterns is largely passive: they adapt contributions only weakly and remain focused on individual gain rather than on shaping group outcomes. Their beliefs about others (inferred from behavior) likely include the expectation that others will keep contributing or keep punishing each other regardless of the focal player’s own actions, leading them to treat the social environment as something to exploit rather than something to stabilize.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a steadfast, unconditional cooperator. They always contribute their full endowment, never deviating despite repeated exposure to free-riding and declining group cooperation. Their behavior indicates a strong internal norm to “do the socially efficient thing” even when it is individually costly. They do not appear to condition their contribution on others’ past behavior: they keep cooperating even as other players alternate between contributing and free-riding, and even when the share of free-riders rises and their own relative payoff drops. This suggests a rule-based or principled strategy (“always contribute”) rather than responsive optimization.

They show high tolerance for exploitation: they continue to invest fully into the public good even when others are clearly earning more by contributing nothing. There is no behavioral sign of risk aversion about being the “sucker”; they accept that role repeatedly. Their pattern is stable rather than volatile; once they adopt full cooperation, they maintain it. Fairness concerns, if present, are not expressed via reduced contributions; they do not attempt to match others’ lower levels or punish by withholding. Overall, they prioritize collective efficiency over personal gain and over reciprocity, and they do so consistently.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
This player’s contribution pattern suggests they either accept or largely ignore payoff asymmetries created by free-riding. As some peers systematically earn higher payoffs by not contributing, the player does not adjust their own behavior to restore payoff equality. They neither reduce their own cooperation to close the gap nor attempt any kind of indirect “punishment by defection.” Instead, they persist in full cooperation even when it places them at a relative disadvantage.

Because no explicit punishment or reward mechanisms are available and they never alter their contribution in response to others’ outcomes, their implicit response to observing others’ higher earnings for lower contributions appears to be non-retaliatory and non-competitive. They behave as if the priority is maintaining contribution to the public good, not managing fairness or reciprocity. There is no observable evidence of learning from outcome patterns across rounds; they do not pivot when others’ free-riding becomes more pronounced. Their default stance toward others’ outcomes is best described as tolerant and unreactive, with any emotional or evaluative component remaining unknown.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a stable, uncompromising free rider. They always keep their entire endowment and never contribute to the public good. Their behavior is highly consistent and shows no signs of experimentation or conditional cooperation. They appear to understand that the group’s contribution level is high and that the public good is reliably provided by others, yet they still refrain from contributing. There is no evidence that they follow fairness norms such as reciprocity, proportionality, or “giving back” when well-treated; they benefit from others’ generosity without adjusting their own behavior. Their strategy suggests a payoff-maximizing focus on individual gain rather than collective efficiency, as the environment makes free riding individually profitable when many others are contributing. Risk tolerance is oriented toward social rather than monetary risk: they accept the possibility that others may reduce their contributions later, but they do not sacrifice coins in the short term to stabilize cooperation. In the absence of punishment or reward, they appear to treat the game as a pure earnings optimization problem and act accordingly, with no observable regard for equity or group welfare.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
This player consistently responds to others’ outcomes by maintaining their own free-riding strategy, regardless of how payoff patterns evolve. They observe that cooperative players earn less than they do and that they themselves repeatedly obtain higher payoffs by not contributing. They also see that some peers begin to defect or exit, and that average payoffs for cooperators decline over time while their own relative advantage persists. Despite these outcome shifts, they do not move toward cooperation or attempt to stabilize group returns; instead, they stay with the individually advantageous pattern. There is no evidence of altruistic concern, guilt, or a desire to equalize payoffs, as they do not forgo any earnings even when others’ generosity is clearly benefiting them. Because punishment and reward mechanisms are unavailable, they cannot directly react via sanctions or bonuses, but their inaction in the face of declining group contributions suggests they are willing to let cooperation erode if that is the consequence of their strategy. Overall, their reaction to others’ outcomes is to use them as confirmation that free riding remains profitable, not as a signal to adjust toward more cooperative or fair behavior.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a persistent, unconditional full cooperator under the given binary choice structure. When faced with a choice between keeping everything or contributing everything, the player reliably opts for the socially efficient option, even as others visibly free-ride and even when cooperation levels decline. The player does not adjust contributions in response to observed defection or changing group averages; contribution behavior is stable rather than reactive. This suggests a rule-based or norm-based strategy (“I contribute fully”) rather than a payoff-responsive strategy. The player appears comfortable accepting a lower relative payoff when others exploit the public good, indicating low sensitivity to disadvantageous inequality and a willingness to be the “sucker” for the sake of maintaining cooperation. Their risk tolerance regarding exploitation by free-riders is high: they continue to cooperate despite clear evidence that some peers systematically keep their endowment. Because the decision space is limited to all-or-nothing contributions, finer-grained fairness norms cannot be inferred; however, the player’s consistent choice of full contribution implies a preference for outcomes that maximize total group surplus over individual short-run gain, even without mechanisms to enforce fairness.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
This player does not use others’ realized payoffs as a cue to change behavior. Even when it becomes clear that non-contributors earn higher individual payoffs than contributors, the player does not shift toward self-protection or reciprocity and instead maintains full cooperation. There is no observable attempt to punish or reward (the mechanisms are unavailable), and the player does not engage in indirect, payoff-based “punishment” such as reducing contributions in response to free-riding. They tolerate repeated instances where defectors benefit more than cooperators without retaliating via contribution changes. This pattern indicates that others’ outcomes do not strongly update the player’s strategy; either they give priority to a personal cooperation standard over outcome-based reciprocity, or they maintain an expectation or hope that stable cooperation is still desirable regardless of current payoff inequalities. Overall, they respond to others’ behavior with steadfast continuation of their own cooperative rule rather than with contingent adaptation.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a steadfast full cooperator. They consistently allocate their entire endowment to the public good in every available decision, without experimentation or adjustment. Their contribution pattern is highly stable and non-contingent on others’ behavior: they maintain maximum giving despite clear and repeated evidence that several group members free ride or reduce their contributions over time. This indicates a strong internal rule or norm (“I contribute fully”) rather than outcome-based optimization.

They appears tolerant of exploitation: they continues to contribute fully even when the relative returns to free riders become salient and when overall group cooperation visibly declines. There is no sign of strategic hedging or conditional cooperation (e.g., “I’ll match the group average”); instead, contribution decisions seem rule-based and insensitive to short-term payoff comparisons.

Risk tolerance is high in a social sense: they accept the risk that others may not contribute and that they themselves may earn less than defectors, yet they do not deviate from full cooperation. This suggests prioritizing collective efficiency or adherence to a fairness/prosocial norm over individual payoff maximization. At the same time, they do not adjust to worsening conditions, so they either maintain optimistic beliefs about the group’s potential to cooperate, or they are committed to a cooperative principle regardless of others’ choices.

Their fairness norm appears strongly oriented toward maximizing group welfare rather than equalizing individual payoffs. They repeatedly behave in a way that makes them vulnerable to being out-earned by defectors, implying a willingness to sacrifice relative standing for the sake of the group account. There is no evidence of spite, reciprocity-based withholding, or attempts to “teach” free riders through reduced cooperation.

Overall, the player fits a “persistent unconditional cooperator” type: stable, norm-driven contributions at the cooperative extreme, with low behavioral volatility and no observable conditional response to partner behavior.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
The player shows no behavioral reaction to others’ differing payoffs; their contribution rule remains unchanged as some group members repeatedly earn more by contributing nothing. Despite clear, repeated instances where non-contributors are rewarded with higher individual payoffs than contributors, the player does not reduce their own contribution, does not alternate between contributing and not contributing, and does not attempt to exploit the pattern by joining the free riders.

This lack of adjustment suggests either that they downplay or disregard relative payoff comparisons, or that they accept being outperformed by defectors as an acceptable cost of adhering to their cooperative standard. There is no sign of conditional cooperation based on observed free-riding, no emergent “protection” of self-payoff in response to exploitation, and no evidence of learning in the direction of self-interested defection.

Because no punishment or reward mechanisms are available, we cannot observe their inclination to actively sanction or reward others; their stance toward peer regulation is therefore unknown. However, given that they do not even passively sanction defectors by reducing their own contributions, it is plausible (but not certain) that they are conflict-avoidant or reluctant to use negative reciprocity, preferring to maintain their cooperative behavior regardless of others’ outcomes.

In summary, the player exhibits a non-retaliatory, non-responsive pattern with respect to others’ payoffs: they continue full cooperation even when free riders clearly benefit at their expense, indicating a stable, outcome-insensitive cooperative orientation rather than a payoff-comparative or reciprocity-driven type.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a selective, alternating cooperator–free rider who mixes full contributions with full withholding rather than choosing a stable pattern. They do not display a consistent unconditional norm of always giving or always keeping; instead they switch between the two extremes of behavior.

Their choices indicate sensitivity to relative payoffs. When they see that free riders earn more than contributors in the shared environment, they are willing to adopt the same payoff-maximizing stance themselves, even if they have previously cooperated. At the same time, they do not fully abandon cooperation: they later return to contributing after having free ridden, suggesting they do not see themselves as locked into a purely selfish role.

They appear to track both their own earnings and the group’s cooperativeness, and they are willing to sacrifice some personal payoff in some periods to support the public good, but they also show clear readiness to exploit cooperative others when the opportunity is salient. This points to a payoff-responsive, conditional style rather than principled adherence to either pure altruism or pure self-interest.

Risk tolerance appears moderate: they are comfortable taking the “risk” of cooperating in a social environment that includes visible free riders, but they also mitigate that risk by intermittently defecting. Their willingness to cooperate even when some others do not suggests they are not purely pessimistic about others’ behavior, yet their willingness to defect after observing payoff differences shows they are alert to being exploited and will adjust accordingly.

In fairness terms, they do not enforce or follow a strict equality norm; they are willing both to be the one who earns less than free riders (by cooperating in mixed groups) and to be the one who earns more (by free riding when others contribute). This asymmetry suggests that securing acceptable personal outcomes is more central than maintaining symmetric fairness across players.

Overall, the player can be characterized as a flexible, payoff-aware conditional cooperator who alternates between pro-social and self-interested choices, adapting to observed incentive patterns rather than committing to a stable cooperative identity.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
The player clearly attends to others’ outcomes, at least implicitly, as shown by their behavior aligning with changes in the payoff structure between contributors and non-contributors. When free riders are earning more than cooperators, the player is willing to join the free riders; when the payoff gap narrows or reverses in a way that weakens the attraction of free riding, they are willing to return to contributing. This pattern implies that peer outcomes inform their strategy, even though there is no direct evidence of emotional reactions.

They do not have access to punishment or reward tools in this environment, so there is no direct data on costly sanctions or positive reinforcement. As a result, their “response” to others’ outcomes manifests entirely through their own contribution level: they indirectly “reward” cooperative environments with occasional contributions and indirectly “punish” cooperative others by sometimes exploiting them through free riding.

There is no evidence that they attempt to stabilize group behavior by consistently matching the group’s average contribution level; instead, they use a coarse-grained response—switching between full cooperation and full defection—with an apparent focus on their own relative payoff. How much they care about others’ absolute payoffs or welfare beyond this relative comparison is unknown.

In terms of beliefs, their actions are consistent with expecting that at least some others will continue to contribute even when they themselves defect, and that group cooperation is reasonably robust in the short run. They seem to “ride along” with others’ generosity when it is profitable, but they are still willing to support the public good intermittently, suggesting they do not fully expect universal defection or complete collapse of cooperation.

Because the player cannot communicate or target individuals, their social style in response to others’ outcomes remains largely inferential. What is observable is a pragmatic, outcome-sensitive adjustment of their own behavior rather than any principled enforcement or strong emotional stance toward high or low earners.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a predominantly free-riding, payoff-maximizing type who occasionally experiments with cooperation but quickly reverts to exploiting others’ contributions.

They consistently choose the individually dominant action whenever it clearly increases personal payoff, showing a strong preference for keeping their endowment rather than contributing to the group. Their one instance of contributing is isolated and not maintained; it appears more like a strategic test of what happens when they cooperate than a stable norm or commitment to fairness.

Their contribution pattern is conditional and reactive: after observing that contributing yields a lower payoff than free-riding while others continue to contribute at high rates, they return to non-contribution and stick with it. This suggests a simple, outcome-oriented heuristic: prefer the action that generates higher own payoff given others’ apparent willingness to contribute.

They do not exhibit a fairness norm focused on equalizing payoffs; they repeatedly accept earning more than most others via free-riding. There is no sign that they are trying to match others’ behavior or “do their part” for the group when that conflicts with their own monetary interest.

Risk tolerance appears moderate: they are willing to try the less individually safe option (cooperating) once, but once the outcome confirms that this reduces their payoff relative to free-riding, they abandon it. This pattern indicates some openness to exploration but a quick return to self-interested exploitation when the environment proves favorable to free-riders.

Overall, the type is best characterized as an outcome-driven opportunistic free-rider: they are attentive to payoff structure, test cooperation briefly, then reliably defect when defection is clearly more profitable.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
The player consistently responds to others’ high contributions and relatively lower payoffs by positioning themselves to benefit from those contributions rather than aligning with them.

When others earn less than the player while contributing more, the player does not move toward more cooperative behavior; instead, they maintain or revert to free-riding. This indicates that others’ worse outcomes do not trigger compensatory behavior, guilt, or attempts to restore equity. Rather than being deterred by the evident exploitation of cooperators, the player appears to treat these outcomes as confirmation that free-riding is the best response to the group’s behavior.

They also seem to treat others’ continuing contributions as a stable resource: as long as enough others keep contributing, the player is content to free-ride. There is no evidence that seeing some peers also free-ride leads them to increase their own contributions to protect the public good. Instead, observing that free-riders can do well or better appears to reinforce their own low-contribution strategy.

Because there is no punishment or reward available, we cannot observe any direct costly reaction to others’ payoffs. However, the indirect behavioral adjustments strongly suggest that this player is not motivated by others’ welfare or by disapproval of inequality; they update their behavior solely in response to how others’ actions affect the profitability of free-riding versus contributing, and they choose the option that maximizes their own payoff even when it clearly leaves others worse off.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a binary contributor who alternates between full cooperation and full defection rather than using intermediate levels. They show an openness to contribute fully even when others free-ride, implying they do not require unanimous cooperation to participate. At the same time, they are willing to free-ride while many others still contribute, indicating a clear sensitivity to own-payoff maximization and no strict adherence to a “contribute if others contribute” fairness rule.

Their pattern suggests exploratory, unstable behavior rather than a fixed cooperative or selfish type: they do not monotonically increase or decrease contributions, and they do not simply mimic the most recent group norm. They tolerate some unfairness against themselves (contributing while others do not) but also exploit cooperators at other points (keeping their endowment while others give). This points to a mixed-motive orientation: they value both the public good and personal gain, without committing fully to either.

They appear comfortable with payoff risk: they sometimes choose the dominated action from an individual-income perspective (full contribution) despite having already experienced that defectors can earn more when others are cooperative. They do not rigidly lock into the individually optimal strategy once it proves advantageous, suggesting either moderate risk tolerance, a concern for maintaining group provision, or uncertainty about what will happen if contributions collapse.

Overall, they fit a “conditional but inconsistent cooperator / opportunistic experimenter” profile: they cooperate often enough to support the public good but also defect at times in ways that increase their own payoff, without a clearly stable rule driven solely by fairness, reciprocity, or pure self-interest.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
The player observes that free-riders can earn higher payoffs when many others contribute, and they are willing to occupy both roles at different times: sometimes sharing the fate of cooperators, sometimes sharing the gains of defectors. This indicates that they accept payoff inequality in both directions: they tolerate being slightly behind free-riders when they themselves contribute, and they also accept getting ahead of many cooperators when they defect.

There is no evidence of punitive or rewarding behavior because such mechanisms are unavailable, so their response to others’ outcomes is expressed only via contributions. They do not simply reward high-contributing groups with consistent cooperation, nor do they systematically “punish” defectors by withdrawing their own contributions whenever free-riding appears. Instead, their adjustments are moderate and non-extreme: they never move to a fully self-protective stance of always defecting despite evidence that this yields high payoffs, and they never commit to unconditional cooperation despite observing persistent partial free-riding.

This pattern is consistent with a player who tracks relative earnings but does not rigidly chase being the top earner. They are willing to exploit the cooperative environment occasionally, but they also at times bear personal cost to help provision the public good even when that choice is not strictly payoff-maximizing given others’ actions. Their learning and adaptation appear present but noisy: they react to the payoff structure by sometimes imitating the more lucrative free-rider position, yet they revert back to cooperation later, suggesting either ongoing experimentation, mixed preferences over equity and efficiency, or uncertainty about how the group will evolve.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
The player is a stable, unconditional full cooperator under the available action set. They always choose the cooperative option, even as others increasingly free-ride and even though the return on unilateral deviation is clearly higher. Their behavior fits a strong pro-social or “principled cooperator” type rather than a conditional cooperator: they do not reduce their contribution in response to declining group contributions or visible exploitation by specific peers. They appear to prioritize group efficiency and/or adherence to a cooperation norm over short-term individual payoff maximization. There is no evidence that they are experimenting, reacting strategically to specific individuals, or adjusting to changing conditions; their pattern is rigidly consistent. Their risk tolerance is high in the social sense: they repeatedly expose themselves to exploitation in a setting where punishment and reward mechanisms are absent and where defection is visibly profitable. Their fairness norm seems oriented toward “everyone should contribute fully” rather than “I match what others do,” since they maintain maximum contribution even when that norm is not widely followed. Because their actions never vary, it is unknown whether they would ever retaliate or conditionally defect in more extreme exploitation scenarios, but within the observed environment they behave like a pure cooperator.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
The player shows no behavioral response to variation in others’ payoffs; their contribution choice remains unchanged despite clear and repeated evidence that free-riders earn strictly higher payoffs than contributors. They do not use others’ earnings as a signal to adjust their own strategy, indicating either low sensitivity to payoff inequality or a willingness to accept disadvantageous inequality in order to maintain cooperation. Since punishment and reward are unavailable and no other costly reactions are possible, there is no direct evidence of a desire to sanction or compensate others. Indirectly, their continued cooperation in the face of exploitative payoff patterns suggests they do not adopt an envious or competitive stance; higher earnings by defectors do not trigger observable withdrawal or defensive behavior. Their learning and adaptation to outcome information appear minimal: they observe that the cooperative strategy is systematically individually dominated by defection yet persist with it. This is consistent with either a payoff-insensitive moral/identity-based motivation to cooperate or a belief that sustained cooperation may eventually stabilize group behavior, though the latter is speculative and thus unknown. Overall, their response to others’ outcomes is characterized by steadfastness and non-retaliation rather than strategic adjustment.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a strict, unconditional full cooperator under the binary choice menu available. They always give their entire endowment to the public pool, never deviating, despite consistently earning less than several free-riders and partial cooperators. Their behavior suggests they prioritize the group return over own immediate payoff, or at minimum follow a firm cooperation heuristic that they do not revise in light of exploitation.

They exhibit high contribution stability: no sign of downward adjustment in response to others’ lower giving, even as the group’s overall contribution level falls and the payoff gap between cooperators and non-contributors persists. This indicates low behavioral volatility and a strong resistance to conditional reciprocity; they do not appear to match the average contribution level, punish defectors by reducing their own giving, or reward cooperators by increasing above some base level—they simply maintain the maximum possible contribution.

Given that the marginal per-capita return on own contribution is well below 1, their consistent full giving reflects either a strong prosocial or norm-following orientation, or a misunderstanding of the individual incentive structure; which of these dominates is unknown. However, the fact that they persist in the face of repeated disadvantage strongly suggests they are not optimizing narrowly for personal payoff.

They seem indifferent to fairness in terms of payoff equality: they continue to accept being exploited by those who give nothing while they themselves give everything. There is no evidence that they are payoff-maximizing, inequality-averse in a self-protective way, or sensitive to being on the losing side of free-riding. Instead, they may be fairness-oriented in a “do my part regardless of others” sense, but this is inferred with low to moderate confidence.

The pattern also implies relatively high risk tolerance regarding the possibility of being the “sucker.” They repeatedly take on the risk of being exploited without hedging by partial or zero cooperation. They show no sign of strategic hedging based on observed group behavior; they do not appear to treat each decision as a gamble but rather follow a fixed rule of always cooperating.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
This player appears strikingly insensitive, in behavioral terms, to others’ payoff outcomes and to the emerging payoff distribution between cooperators and defectors. As they observe that free-riders and low contributors repeatedly earn more than them, they make no observable adjustment: no reduction in cooperation, no attempt to imitate the more profitable strategy, and no sign of reacting to patterns of exploitation.

They do not use payoff information strategically. High free-rider payoffs do not trigger defensive behavior; high cooperator payoffs (when contributions are overall higher) do not induce them to change either, because they are already at the maximum contribution. Their strategy remains static regardless of whether cooperation is relatively high or decaying.

Because punishment and reward mechanisms are unavailable, there is no direct evidence about how they would allocate costly sanctions or rewards. What can be inferred is that they do not use their contribution decision as an indirect retaliation or reward channel: they do not “punish” defectors by lowering their own contribution after seeing them gain, and they do not “reward” cooperators by modulating contributions upward, since they always remain at full contribution.

Their non-responsiveness to the payoff advantages of defectors suggests that they either (a) place little weight on relative standing and exploitation, or (b) are committed to a principle of contribution that overrides reactive or reciprocal motives. Whether they experience negative emotions toward the higher-earning defectors is unknown; behaviorally, they maintain a neutral, non-retaliatory stance.

Overall, their type is best described as a rigid, unconditional cooperator who maintains full contributions independently of others’ outcomes, showing no observable learning, imitation, or adaptation driven by payoff feedback.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a stable, unconditional full cooperator within the available action set. When choosing between complete free-riding and complete contribution, the player always opts to contribute the entire endowment to the public good, without observable adjustment across rounds. This pattern holds even as the environment becomes less cooperative and the relative material payoff from free-riding becomes increasingly clear.

The player’s behavior implies a strong internal norm favoring contribution over personal monetary gain. They do not display conditional cooperation in the usual sense (i.e., increasing or decreasing contributions in response to others); instead, they maintain maximal cooperation regardless of others’ choices. There is no evidence of opportunistic deviation, strategic experimentation, or reactive “teaching” behavior; they do not try to influence others by reducing their own contributions.

Given that contributing yields a lower material payoff than defecting in all observed conditions, the player reveals either (a) high weight on group efficiency or fairness norms, or (b) a strong commitment to a rule such as “always contribute” that overrides short-term payoff considerations. The persistence of this rule when surrounded by several free-riders suggests low sensitivity to exploitation risk in this environment, or a willingness to accept exploitation as a cost of adhering to their norm.

With respect to risk, the player accepts predictable monetary disadvantage relative to defectors, so they do not appear to be payoff-risk-averse in the social sense; instead, they tolerate disadvantage to maintain cooperation. Their contribution pattern is non-volatile and highly predictable: in a new but similar PGG environment with the same binary choice set, they are likely to choose full contribution consistently, independent of others’ past or expected behavior.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
The player observes that free-riders obtain higher payoffs than contributors yet continues to fully contribute, indicating that they do not let relative disadvantage or observed exploitation push them toward retaliation or withdrawal. Since there is no punishment or reward mechanism in this setting, they cannot take explicit action toward others, but their unchanged cooperation in the face of repeated payoff asymmetries shows an absence of payoff-based reciprocity, revenge motives, or “quit cooperating when treated unfairly” rules.

Their behavior is consistent with either a “moral” or rule-based cooperator who prioritizes contributing regardless of distributional outcomes, or a player who interprets the environment as one where continued high cooperation is still appropriate despite others’ gains from defection. They appear to accept the presence of free-riders without attempting to sanction them via their own behavior (e.g., by reducing contributions to avoid being exploited).

There is no evidence of envy-driven adjustment: higher payoffs for defectors do not trigger a change in the player’s own strategy. Likewise, there is no sign of payoff-based learning; they do not update their behavior in a direction that would improve their relative or absolute payoff given others’ actions. Their response style is thus best described as steadfast and norm-guided rather than adaptive to observed outcome patterns.
