text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a predominantly self-interested free-rider with occasional low-cost “masking” contributions. After starting with a modest positive contribution, they quickly shift to contributing nothing in almost all rounds, despite the group maintaining moderate-to-high contributions for much of the game. Their later behavior includes a small contribution spike and brief continuation at a low level, but they revert to full free-riding again. This pattern suggests they prioritize maximizing their own payoff over sustaining the public good.

They do not appear to condition their contributions positively on others’ cooperation: they continue to contribute nothing even when others contribute highly and the public fund is large, and they only make small contributions when free-riding has already been established as common in the group. Their contribution decisions do not track clear fairness norms; they seem comfortable taking a disproportionate share of the benefits generated by others’ contributions. There is no visible concern for risk to group cooperation in the long term, likely because they either discount future rounds or do not strongly believe that their own contribution is needed to maintain the group’s giving.

Overall, their contribution profile fits an “opportunistic low contributor” type: they are willing to give a little when it is cheap and/or when it may help them blend in, but their default is to keep their entire endowment.

<REWARD>
This player never spends any coins on rewarding others, even in settings where others are contributing a lot or where some players are clearly using rewards to encourage cooperation. They also remain unmoved by large, conspicuous reward expenditures from other players directed at third parties. Their behavior is consistent with a strict payoff-maximizing stance toward the reward mechanism: any cost to benefit others is avoided, even when it might strategically improve others’ future contributions.

They do not use rewards to build alliances, to express approval of high contributors, or to respond to patterns of generosity in the group. Their stance suggests they either see the reward mechanism as irrelevant to their own objectives, or they explicitly treat it as a dominated action given the 1:1 private cost-to-benefit ratio at the individual level. There is no evidence that they experiment with small rewards to test reciprocity or influence; their reward behavior is completely flat.

In summary, they behave as a non-rewarder who free-rides not only on contributions but also on the prosocial and strategic efforts of those who pay to reward others.

<RESPONSE_TO_REWARDER>
This player is a pure reward free-rider: they accept rewards passively but never reciprocate. They receive rewards on multiple occasions from identifiable others, yet they never direct any rewards back to those benefactors, nor do they start rewarding anyone at all after being rewarded. There is no sign of gratitude signaling via the mechanism.

They also do not adjust their contribution behavior in clear response to being rewarded. After receiving rewards, their contribution pattern remains largely unchanged in its free-riding orientation. This indicates that, for them, being rewarded does not create an obligation to “earn” that generosity via higher contributions or via reciprocal reward. Their reaction is best characterized as opportunistic acceptance rather than relational engagement.

Thus, when rewarders are identifiable, this player does not use that information to form alliances or to signal reciprocity; they treat rewards as windfall income and maintain their original selfish strategy.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
This player appears largely indifferent to others’ payoffs, reward costs, and reward patterns. They observe striking behaviors from others, including sustained high contributions and substantial reward expenditures, sometimes at great personal cost, yet they never adjust their own strategy toward more cooperation or prosocial reinforcement. They do not mimic high contributors, do not support “altruistic rewarders,” and do not exploit opportunities to reward low-contributing free-riders who happen to reward them.

Their behavior suggests they interpret others’ large reward spending or high contributions as exploitable rather than as signals deserving support. They do not appear deterred or morally influenced when others sacrifice substantial payoffs to encourage or support specific players. Instead, they maintain a stable, self-focused pattern in both contribution and reward decisions.

In terms of beliefs and personality style, the observable pattern is consistent with a player who expects to benefit from others’ efforts without needing to respond. They seem comfortable being an outlier in terms of generosity and do not show visible concern for reputation or fairness norms, even though all actions are publicly visible. Any learning or adaptation that occurs stays within a narrow band of self-interest: small tactical changes in own contributions, but no movement toward rewarding or sustained cooperation.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a moderately variable, outcome-sensitive contributor who oscillates between low, medium, and full contributions rather than following a single stable level. They neither stick to free-riding nor to consistent high cooperation. They sometimes match or exceed the emerging group norm and sometimes fall below it; there is no simple monotonic trend upward or downward.

They appear responsive to the social environment: they try out low contributions early, then later experiment with very high contributions, then settle into mid-level amounts. This pattern suggests they are probing what others do and how that affects payoffs, rather than following a fixed fairness rule. They are willing to make very costly cooperative moves even in the absence of strong direct reciprocation, so pure payoff-maximization is unlikely to be their only motive.

They do not strictly enforce equality norms; they contribute high amounts in some situations where many others are lower, and also contribute low when others are more generous. This points to a player who is exploratory and somewhat risk-tolerant with respect to personal payoff, using contributions as a lever to test group behavior and the effectiveness of reward dynamics more than to stick to a predetermined “fair share.”

Overall, they fit a “conditional experimental cooperator”: they care about cooperation but are willing to deviate in either direction while they learn how the group and the reward system behave.

<REWARD>
This player uses reward sparingly and selectively. Across the game they sometimes pay to reward others but never at large scales, and they do not mirror the extreme “altruistic rewarder” types present in the group. When they do reward, recipients tend to be players who are visibly cooperative or who have played a salient role in sustaining contributions. The pattern suggests they are trying to reinforce pro-social behavior rather than randomly gifting or forming arbitrary alliances.

They are also willing to reward in rounds where they themselves contribute very highly and get relatively modest payoffs, indicating that they accept a personal cost to encourage what they perceive as helpful behavior. However, the magnitude of their rewards remains small compared with what some others spend. This implies that while they value using rewards as a signal and incentive, they also monitor costs carefully and avoid full self-sacrifice.

There is no evidence that they use reward as direct tit-for-tat with any single player; instead, the timing and small scale point to a strategic but cautious use of positive incentives to nudge overall cooperation and to acknowledge particularly cooperative acts.

<RESPONSE_TO_REWARDER>
The player receives small amounts of reward on a few occasions, from different sources, but their own reward behavior does not show clear, targeted reciprocity toward those specific individuals. They neither escalate into mutual reward cycles nor dramatically change their contributions immediately after being rewarded.

Their reaction is best characterized as appreciative but not personally bound: being rewarded does not visibly lock them into a loyalty relationship with any particular benefactor. They treat rewards more as general feedback that cooperation is noticed than as a cue to form exclusive alliances. There is no evidence of retaliatory withdrawal toward rewarders either; they simply maintain their own exploratory contribution and limited reward strategy.

Thus, they display weak or diffuse reciprocity: they may internalize that “the group values cooperation,” but they do not convert identifiable rewarders into privileged partners in a systematic way.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
This player pays close implicit attention to how others’ coins and reward spending play out. Their contribution and reward decisions vary in ways that align with visible shifts in how costly cooperation and rewarding become for different group members. They witness both extreme reward spending by some players and stable free-riding or low spending by others, yet they avoid both extremes.

They do not imitate the very heavy rewarders who sacrifice large portions of their payoff; instead, they continue to use moderate contributions and small-scale rewards, suggesting they perceive excessive spending as unsustainable or irrational. At the same time, they do not react by dropping into pure free-riding when others appear to overspend or when cooperative peers are not always rewarded sufficiently. This indicates a tolerance for inequality and noise in payoffs: they are willing to coexist with big disparities in earnings and in reward costs without making sharp retaliatory moves.

Overall, they interpret others’ outcomes as informative but not binding. They update their own behavior gradually and experimentally rather than in abrupt, punitive or imitative jumps. This points to a type who learns from the environment, aims for a balance between cooperation and self-interest, and remains relatively calm in the face of both exploitation and over-generosity.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a generally high contributor who escalates giving over time and rarely free-rides. They start below the group average but quickly move into consistently above-average contributions, often at or near full endowment. They occasionally drop to moderate levels, suggesting they are not rigidly unconditional; however, even their “low” contributions remain substantial rather than exploitative. Their behavior indicates a strong pro-social or cooperative orientation despite the low marginal per-capita return: they repeatedly choose socially efficient but individually costly contributions.

Their adjustments track broad cooperation levels but not in a finely contingent, tit-for-tat manner. They do not systematically match the contributions of specific others or the exact group average; instead they appear to adopt a “high baseline cooperation with occasional moderation” rule. This points to an internal fairness or responsibility norm (“I should give a lot”) more than a payoff-maximizing calculation. They tolerate being among the highest contributors even when others contribute little, indicating low sensitivity to being exploited and high willingness to carry the public good.

Risk-wise, they accept repeated low personal payoffs, including extreme sacrifice when combining high contribution and heavy reward spending. This shows high risk tolerance and low short-term self-protection in favor of maintaining or signaling cooperation.

<REWARD>
The player is an extremely active and generous rewarder in the first two-thirds of the game, then sharply curtails rewarding later. They frequently spend substantial portions of their payoff on rewards, even when that makes them one of the lowest earners. Their rewards are directed broadly rather than narrowly targeted to a single “partner,” and they favor players who contribute meaningfully rather than obvious free-riders. They also show willingness to reward both mid-level and high contributors, suggesting a norm-affirming rather than strictly selective strategy.

Given that the reward technology is efficiency-neutral, their heavy use of it is not irrational, but the scale and persistence of their spending reveal a strong preference for reinforcing cooperation, even at high variance in personal outcome. They are not purely strategic in the narrow sense: they continue to reward generously even after it is clear that others are not matching their sacrifice level in rewards or contributions. Over time, however, they shift toward zero reward usage, indicating some learning or fatigue—possibly concluding that their heavy rewarding does not significantly reshape group behavior.

Overall, they act as a “rewarding altruist” or “moral investor,” using rewards to endorse and encourage cooperation more than to form tight dyadic alliances.

<RESPONSE_TO_REWARDER>
The player receives very little reward across the game and only modestly later on. They do not reliably repay those who reward them; there is no clear emergence of reciprocating pairs. Their own reward pattern does not pivot toward those who have rewarded them, nor do they maintain high rewards to such players once they reduce rewarding overall. This suggests low emphasis on direct reciprocity and alliance-building.

Instead, their response to being rewarded is muted in behavior: their contribution path remains high whether or not they are personally recognized, and their decision to wind down rewarding appears more tied to the perceived ineffectiveness or cost of rewards in general, not to disappointment with specific rewarders. They seem to treat reward receipt as pleasant but non-central information, not as a binding social contract.

This pattern fits a type who values general cooperative norms more than personal loyalty cycles. They do not punish non-rewarders by withdrawing cooperation or targeting rewards away from them; they simply reduce reward expenditures globally once it appears costly and weakly impactful.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
The player is attentive to others’ outcomes and reacts to the broad structure of payoffs and reward usage rather than micro-managing pairwise relations. They repeatedly observe situations where heavy rewarders or heavy contributors end up with very low or even negative net payoffs, while non-rewarding, sometimes low-contributing players earn high returns. Despite seeing this, they persist for many rounds as a high contributor and heavy rewarder, signaling that they prioritize sustaining or modeling cooperation over protecting themselves against relative losses.

They appear somewhat responsive to extreme anomalies: massive, possibly erratic reward sprees by certain others do not induce them to join in similar extremes, and after observing that reward-heavy rounds leave rewarders very poor while many others free-ride on their generosity, they progressively withdraw from using rewards. However, they do not respond with retaliatory under-contribution or targeted exclusion; instead, they maintain substantial contributions while trimming the most personally costly, low-leverage behavior (the heavy rewards). This indicates a learning process focused on cost control rather than on revenge or status competition.

Overall, they interpret others’ payoffs and spending as signals about the effectiveness and sustainability of cooperation mechanisms, not as direct prompts for punishment or alliance. They remain cooperative even when cooperation is not strongly reciprocated, but they do eventually moderate their “pro-social spending” once it is clear that others’ strategies leave them chronically underpaid.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player fits an “opportunistic, erratic cooperator” type. They are willing to make very high contributions but do not maintain them consistently, and they freely switch between full cooperation and full free-riding. They alternate between giving their entire endowment, half of it, or nothing, without settling into a stable pattern. Their behavior does not track simple conditional cooperation rules such as clearly matching group averages or selectively rewarding high contributors with their own behavior. They sometimes contribute fully when others are contributing moderately, and sometimes contribute nothing when others are contributing heavily. This suggests low adherence to strong fairness norms or consistent efficiency-maximizing principles, and a greater focus on experimenting with payoff structures and taking advantage of high-contribution environments when it is cheap to free-ride. They appear comfortable with substantial payoff variance: they accept low immediate payoffs when contributing fully and no rewards, and later accept very high payoffs when free-riding in cooperative environments. Overall, they show limited concern for aligning their own contributions with others’ efforts and appear relatively insensitive to specific individual contribution levels. Their pattern indicates medium to high risk tolerance in terms of payoff swings and a willingness to “test” both extremes of the strategy space (full cooperator vs. full defector) over time.

<REWARD>
They never spend any coins to reward others, despite frequent and often large reward activity in the group. This holds across situations where many others make very high contributions and where particular individuals are repeatedly using reward at significant personal cost. Their zero use of the reward mechanism suggests either they do not value reward as a coordination or reciprocity tool, or they view its cost as unjustified regardless of others’ behavior. They do receive nontrivial rewards from others in multiple instances, yet still do not reciprocate or use reward strategically to encourage cooperation. There is no evidence that they selectively reward high contributors, consistent allies, or generous rewarders; the mechanism is simply unused. This points to a “reward-averse” or “reward-indifferent” orientation: they take any incoming benefits but do not invest in the prosocial infrastructure themselves. If they have a strategy regarding reward, it is a purely passive one—treat rewards as windfalls rather than as a signal to be reinforced.

<RESPONSE_TO_REWARDER>
They receive rewards in several rounds from different peers, including when they are contributing fully and when they are free-riding. Despite this, they never respond with reciprocal rewards, and they do not visibly adjust their contribution behavior in a way that favors those who rewarded them. When rewarded after cooperative behavior, they do not become consistently more cooperative; when rewarded while free-riding, they do not show signs of guilt-driven correction or loyalty formation. Because rewarders’ identities are visible, their lack of targeted reciprocation suggests that they do not use reward as a basis for alliance formation or reputational exchange. Their stance toward rewarders appears to be “quietly exploitative” or at least strongly self-regarding: they accept the benefits but do not treat them as obligations or signals requiring a response. Their social reciprocity, at least via the available monetary channels, is effectively absent.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
They observe a group with highly heterogeneous behavior: some players repeatedly spend heavily to reward others, sometimes to the point of drastically reducing their own payoffs, while others contribute a lot or very little. The focal player’s pattern indicates that they are largely unmoved by these extreme prosocial expenditures. They do not mirror the generous rewarders, nor do they moderate their own strategy to protect or support highly cooperative individuals whose payoffs are reduced by reward costs. Instead, they appear to situationally exploit environments where others are contributing heavily and rewarding freely, by occasionally switching to zero contribution while still enjoying high redistribution and incoming rewards. Their contributions do not systematically rise in response to others’ high costs or fall in response to visible stinginess; their actions remain loosely coupled to the observed payoff distribution. This suggests limited empathic or fairness-based response to others’ outcomes and a focus on their own payoff opportunities. Learning and adaptation are present only in a coarse sense: they realize that both high contribution and zero contribution can coexist with acceptable or even high payoffs, and they cycle between them, but they do not refine this into a more nuanced conditional strategy based on who is bearing which costs. Overall, they treat others’ outcomes more as background conditions than as moral or strategic signals to which they must respond.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a volatile, payoff-sensitive conditional contributor rather than a stable cooperator or pure free rider. They are clearly willing to make very high contributions in some situations, including fully investing their endowment, but they also switch to very low or zero contributions in other periods. Their pattern suggests that they do not follow a simple “always cooperate” rule: they sometimes match or exceed the (inferred) group norm, sometimes contribute modestly, and sometimes fully free ride, even when many others are contributing strongly.  

Their contribution choices appear loosely conditional on the general atmosphere of cooperation but not tightly tit‑for‑tat with specific individuals. They tolerate substantial inequality in who contributes what and do not consistently withdraw cooperation in direct response to low contributors being present. Instead, they seem to trade off between (a) exploring payoff‑maximizing behavior when they see that free riding yields high returns and (b) occasionally “testing” high contributions, possibly to see if the group will sustain a more cooperative norm, or because they value the idea of contributing in principle.  

They do not show a clear fairness norm (such as closely tracking high vs. low contributors and aligning their own behavior accordingly). They appear comfortable both over‑contributing relative to many others and also under‑contributing while others invest heavily. This points to relatively low aversion to payoff inequality. Risk tolerance is moderate to high: they are willing to risk low payoffs by contributing a lot even in an environment where many others have previously free ridden, and they are also willing to risk future social disapproval by free riding when others are generous. Overall, they act as an opportunistic, experimental conditional cooperator whose behavior is shaped more by individual payoff considerations than by strict fairness or consistency.

<REWARD>
They almost never use the reward mechanism, despite having multiple opportunities and clear examples of other players spending heavily to reward. When they do spend on reward, they do so only minimally and with no obvious pattern of strongly reinforcing high cooperators. There is no consistent targeting of the highest contributors, nor of any specific partner over time. This indicates a low intrinsic motivation to reward others and weak interest in shaping group norms through positive incentives.  

Their rare rewards do not appear to be a direct “thanks” for being rewarded themselves, nor part of a sustained strategic alliance. Instead, rewarding seems incidental or experimental: they test the mechanism once or twice but quickly revert to not using it, even when high contributors exist or when some players spend large amounts rewarding others. They therefore do not behave like a reciprocity‑driven rewarder, a norm enforcer, or a coalition‑builder via reward. Rather, they implicitly treat reward as personally costly and of limited strategic value, preferring to keep coins or use them via contribution choices.

<RESPONSE_TO_REWARDER>
They receive very little direct reward, and when they do, they do not respond with visible reciprocal reward back to the same individual, nor with a clear change in their contribution that can be tied uniquely to that benefactor. This suggests that they do not use reward as a basis for bilateral alliance building or direct reciprocity.  

Because they do not systematically “pay back” those who reward them, they behave as if gratitude, in the sense of material reciprocity, is weak or subordinated to their own payoff calculus. They may appreciate being rewarded on some level (unknown), but behaviorally they do not commit resources to acknowledge or reinforce that kindness. Their strategy thus does not hinge on building long‑term dyadic relationships; instead, they treat reward they receive as a windfall rather than as an obligation‑creating signal.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
They observe large and sometimes extreme uses of the reward mechanism by others (including players who sacrifice substantial payoffs to reward certain targets), yet they do not imitate this behavior or systematically adjust their contributions in line with it. Their contribution path does not track the fortunes of rewarded players or the costs borne by rewarders in a consistent way. This suggests that they are relatively unmoved by others’ sacrifices or windfalls as social signals.  

They do, however, appear to notice broad payoff patterns in the group: they are willing to free ride when it is clearly profitable, and they later return to high contributions even after seeing that some players earn much more by contributing little. This implies they are observing outcomes but not in a norm‑following manner. Instead, they treat the group’s behavior and payoff profile as a shifting environment to exploit or occasionally test with cooperative play.  

In personality terms, they come across as pragmatic, low‑expressive, and individually oriented rather than strongly prosocial or strongly vindictive. They neither join in the heavy rewarding “moralists” nor consistently anchor on the high‑earning free riders. They adapt their own contributions to the general environment but rarely spend extra to influence others’ outcomes directly. Overall, they act as a self‑focused, experimental conditional cooperator who monitors others’ outcomes mainly to inform their own contribution choice, not to enforce or reciprocate social norms.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a mostly self-interested, low-to-mid contributor with sporadic higher contributions and no clear conditional cooperation pattern. Their baseline tendency is to keep the endowment, contributing nothing or very little in most rounds. Occasional spikes to moderate or high contributions occur without a stable link to others’ average behavior or to changes in the group’s cooperation level. The player does not appear to follow a fairness norm such as “match the group average” or “reward high contributors by also contributing more.” Instead, contribution choices suggest either experimentation with different levels or opportunistic giving when it feels low-risk, but not a sustained commitment to group welfare. They tolerate exploiting cooperative others: they frequently free-ride while many peers contribute substantial amounts. There is no evidence of strong aversion to benefiting from others’ generosity. Risk tolerance toward the public good appears low: once they see that they can earn solid payoffs with low or zero contributions, they revert to that pattern rather than investing into the common pool to try to shift group behavior.

<REWARD>
The player never spends on rewards. This holds even when they receive significant free benefits from generous contributors, and even when some peers incur large costs to reward others. They do not use rewards instrumentally to encourage high cooperators, nor do they use them expressively to signal gratitude or group affiliation. The presence of very heavy rewarders in the group does not draw them into the reward system; they remain a pure non-rewarder. This suggests that, for this player, the cost of rewarding is not justified by any expected strategic gain, and that warm-glow or reciprocity motives via the reward channel are weak or absent. They effectively treat reward as a dominated or irrelevant option and focus on maximizing their own immediate payoff instead.

<RESPONSE_TO_REWARDER>
They are rewarded multiple times but never reciprocate through the reward mechanism. They also do not notably increase their own contributions in ways that track specific rewarders’ behavior, so there is no clear indirect reciprocity via higher giving. Overall, they act as a passive beneficiary: they accept rewards when given but do not form observable alliances, do not “pay back” particular helpers, and do not imitate rewarders’ generosity. Being identified as rewarded does not shift their strategy; they neither join the rewarding coalition nor shift toward “reward good types, ignore bad types.” Their default stance toward rewarders is non-responsive and non-committal.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
They observe substantial variation in others’ contributions, reward costs, and payoffs, including extreme prosocial rewarding that severely harms some individuals’ payoffs and massively boosts others’. Despite this, they do not adjust into any role that reacts to those patterns: they neither join the heavy cooperators, nor oppose them, nor selectively support exploited players. High-contribution peers who are not especially rewarded, and low-contribution peers who are heavily rewarded, both coexist in their environment without provoking a targeted behavioral shift. They appear mainly outcome-focused on their own payoff and ignore the social “drama” of large transfers. Others’ very high spending on rewards, even to the point of incurring large losses, does not induce them to intervene or to mirror such behavior. Normatively, they behave as if group-level fairness, rebalancing of payoffs, or defense of victims of extreme reward strategies are not their responsibility. They learn that they can maintain relatively strong earnings with minimal contributions and no reward costs, and they stick to that pattern, suggesting a stable, payoff-maximizing, low-engagement social style rather than an evolving norm-enforcing or alliance-building strategy.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a pure free-rider. They always keep their full endowment and never contribute to the public fund, with no experimentation or adjustment despite large and persistent contributions from many others. Their behavior suggests they prioritize maximizing their own immediate payoff over any norm of fairness or reciprocity, even when others’ cooperation is very high. They appear insensitive to social pressure: observing generous or stable contributors does not induce even a small “token” contribution. There is no sign of conditional cooperation, threshold behavior, or risk-taking in the direction of contributing; instead, they rely entirely on others to fund the public good and accept the resulting high benefits.

<REWARD>
They never spend on reward, even when the mechanism is active and others heavily use it. This indicates strong reluctance to incur any personal cost for social reinforcement, whether to encourage high contributors or to thank those who reward them. Their stance is consistently non-participatory in the reward phase: they do not attempt to steer group behavior, build goodwill, or reciprocate gifts via the available mechanism. This is compatible with a strictly self-regarding payoff focus: since reward here is cost-neutral in expectation, they treat it as useless or not worth the cognitive/effort cost. Unknown whether they conceptually recognize its strategic potential; behavior suggests either indifference or a deliberate choice to free-ride even on the reward system.

<RESPONSE_TO_REWARDER>
They receive multiple rewards but never respond in kind and never change their contribution behavior. This indicates an absence of direct reciprocity toward identifiable rewarders and no attempt at alliance-building. Being rewarded does not trigger gratitude signaling, cooperative turn-taking, or targeted payback; instead, they maintain the same non-contributing, non-rewarding pattern. This suggests they treat received rewards as windfall gains without social obligation attached, or they consider social responsiveness strategically unnecessary. Their response style toward rewarders is thus passive and exploitative rather than relational.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
They observe that some players sacrifice large amounts on reward and/or contributions, leading to wide payoff disparities and visible “heroes” and “victims” in the group. Despite this, they do not adjust their own play: they neither support highly generous contributors/rewarders nor react against extreme behaviors. There is no sign that others’ low payoffs from heavy rewarding elicit concern or solidarity, nor that others’ high or low earnings provoke competitive changes. Their stance toward others’ outcomes is observational but behaviorally inert: they use the system purely to collect benefits and ignore the social signaling embedded in rewards, costs, and payoffs. This points to a personality profile that is detached from group welfare signals and focused on individual gain, with unknown emotional reactions but no observable behavioral empathy or norm enforcement.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a moderately selfish, payoff-focused conditional cooperator with substantial volatility. They contribute non-zero amounts in most rounds but frequently drop to zero, and their levels swing widely rather than following a smooth trend. They are clearly sensitive to the contribution environment: they sometimes match or exceed the group’s typical giving, but at other times free-ride completely despite continued substantial contributions from many others. They do not appear guided by a strict fairness norm such as “match average,” “reward high contributors,” or “never give more than others”; instead, they alternate between partial cooperation and outright free-riding, seemingly testing how much they can take while still benefiting from others’ generosity. Their willingness to occasionally contribute a lot, including once giving their entire endowment, suggests they are not purely risk-averse or purely selfish; they are willing to sacrifice payoff at times, but this does not crystallize into a stable high-cooperation strategy. Overall, they prioritize maintaining good payoffs for themselves and show no clear effort to stabilize group cooperation.

<REWARD>
The player never uses the reward mechanism across all observed opportunities. This holds even when they themselves receive positive rewards and can see others using rewards intensively. They therefore do not engage in strategic reinforcement of high contributors, do not repay kindness with reward, and do not expend resources to guide others’ behavior. This pattern indicates a strong aversion to paying personal costs for others’ benefit, even at minimal or equal efficiency. It also suggests they do not view rewards as a tool for influencing future cooperation or building alliances; any social motives they may have do not translate into action in this institution. Their stance is consistent and unidirectional: they are a non-rewarder by type in this setting.

<RESPONSE_TO_REWARDER>
When they receive rewards, they do not change their reward behavior toward the giver (or toward anyone else), nor do they start rewarding after being targeted. They also do not use contributions to signal gratitude or alliance in any obvious way after being rewarded; their contribution pattern continues to fluctuate in both cooperative and free-riding directions without an identifiable “thank you” response. In a context where rewarders are identifiable, they still abstain from reciprocating. This suggests low propensity for direct reciprocity via institutional tools and little inclination to build bilateral cooperative relationships through costly actions. Any internal feeling of gratitude is behaviorally undetectable; they appear to treat received rewards as windfall gains rather than obligations to respond in kind.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
The player clearly observes that some others sacrifice heavily through rewards (sometimes at extreme personal cost) and that some are steady high contributors, yet they do not materially adjust in a pro-social or supportive direction. They do not step in to help heavily sacrificing rewarders, do not reward consistent cooperators, and do not systematically shift contributions up or down in response to conspicuous generosity or extreme payoffs. Their main behavioral adjustment is between partial contribution and full free-riding, which seems more connected to maintaining their own earnings than to any moral objection or supportive response to others’ choices. They tolerate, and exploit, situations where others’ outcomes are very uneven, making no effort to correct perceived unfairness. Overall, they treat others’ outcomes primarily as background conditions that affect what they can safely extract, rather than as signals that call for normative or emotional responses.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a near-pure free rider with a brief, isolated deviation. They consistently keep their entire endowment rather than contributing to the public fund, with only one exception where they contribute a moderate amount once and then immediately revert to zero. Their default is to treat the public good as something others will provide. This pattern is stable over time and does not track changes in group contribution levels; they do not appear to condition their own contribution on others’ generosity, nor to respond to declines in group cooperation with “matching” behavior. Any concern for efficiency or group welfare is not expressed through direct contribution. Fairness norms about proportional giving are either weak or absent in their revealed behavior. Their risk tolerance around contribution appears low: they avoid paying into the public fund even when many others are clearly cooperating and even when their own past payoff is high enough to “afford” some giving. Overall, they behave as a self-focused, strategically detached contributor who prefers to influence the game, if at all, via the reward stage rather than via their own contributions.

<REWARD>
This player is extremely active and erratic in the reward stage, at times spending very large amounts on rewards and at other times spending nothing. They are clearly willing to incur substantial personal cost to grant rewards, even to the point of pushing their own payoff into strongly negative territory in a given period. This indicates that they do not treat the reward mechanism purely instrumentally for near-term material payoff; non-monetary motives (e.g., expressive behavior, experiments with influence, or strong but shifting preferences about particular others) seem to dominate.

Their targeting is highly selective rather than diffuse. In several instances they concentrate rewards heavily on a single individual, drastically boosting that person’s payoff while sacrificing a large share of their own. At other times they distribute rewards among a small handful of peers, and in other periods they stop rewarding entirely. There is no clear monotonic relationship between others’ contribution levels and being rewarded by this player: some high contributors receive large transfers, others receive none, and some relatively low or zero contributors at times benefit. This suggests that their reward rule is not a simple “reward cooperators” heuristic. Instead, they may be responding to a combination of idiosyncratic criteria: possibly prior interactions, perceived neglect by others, or a desire to “correct” payoff rankings by elevating particular individuals. The fact that they both give and receive reward but do not establish stable reciprocal patterns suggests they are not strategically building long-term alliances in a consistent way.

They do not use rewards in a tightly payoff-maximizing way: they sometimes spend so much that their own payoff is well below what they could have kept simply by not rewarding at all. This indicates a willingness to trade off personal earnings for other objectives, but those objectives are not transparently cooperative; they do not persistently reinforce high contributors or systematically discourage free riding. Overall, their reward behavior is best characterized as high-cost, highly selective, and unstable in direction, driven by their own shifting priorities rather than by a consistent social norm.

<RESPONSE_TO_REWARDER>
This player is intermittently rewarded by others, yet they do not develop any clear pattern of direct reciprocity toward those who reward them. When they are the recipient of reward, they do not reliably channel subsequent reward back to those same individuals, nor do they consistently increase their own contribution in response. Any reciprocity that might exist is weak or noisy rather than systematic.

Their use of rewards toward others appears largely decoupled from the identity of prior rewarders. At some points they spend heavily on players who have not recently rewarded them, and at other points they ignore players who have been generous toward them. This makes it unlikely that they are consciously pursuing reputation-based alliances or tit-for-tat style exchange of favors. If they register being rewarded at all, their behavioral adjustment is subtle or overshadowed by other motives. From the data alone, it is unknown whether they feel gratitude or perceive signaling value in the rewards they receive; what is clear is that those internal states, if present, rarely translate into systematic, targeted reciprocity in subsequent decisions.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
This player pays close enough attention to others’ outcomes to direct large, focused transfers, but they do not respond in a straightforward, norm-enforcing way to payoff distributions. They sometimes dramatically inflate the payoff of a particular peer, even when that peer is already doing reasonably well, and at other times they do not intervene to assist individuals with relatively low earnings. Their behavior cannot be reduced to a simple aversion to inequality, because they sometimes strongly increase inequality by elevating one player far above the rest while accepting a large personal loss.

They also do not appear to punish low contributors indirectly by withholding reward in a systematic fashion; many low or zero contributors simply receive no attention from them, while some get boosted. Their response to others’ high spending on rewards is similarly inconsistent: they do not reliably “support the supporter” or coordinate with other big rewarders, nor do they clearly avoid or counter them. It is more accurate to say that they use the information about others’ contributions, reward spending, and resulting payoffs as a menu from which to make idiosyncratic, sometimes extreme interventions, rather than as cues for enforcing a clear social norm.

In personality terms, they present as unconventional, willing to incur large personal costs to shape the payoff landscape according to their own shifting preferences. They do not try to lead via contribution or via consistent norm enforcement; instead, they occasionally make dramatic moves in the reward phase that reallocate earnings, without visibly stabilizing into a cooperative “type.” Their learning and adaptation are limited: despite feedback about the effects of their actions, they revert repeatedly to full free riding on contributions and oscillate between heavy and zero reward use, suggesting exploratory or expressive behavior rather than a convergent strategy.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is an initially extreme unconditional cooperator who later experiments with defection but never fully stabilizes on a clear conditional rule. They start by always contributing their entire endowment regardless of how much others give, even when average contributions are low and trending downward. This indicates a strong initial norm of full cooperation and willingness to incur substantial relative losses for the group.

They maintain that pattern for most of the game, despite consistently earning less than many lower contributors. Only late in the game do they sharply reduce their giving, first to pure free-riding and then to a low, partial contribution. This shift suggests they update based on accumulated experience of being exploited or seeing inadequate group cooperation, rather than responding myopically to one-off deviations.

Their adjustment is abrupt rather than gradual, implying that they tolerate unfairness for some time and then flip into a more self-protective mode. They do not appear to condition finely on specific individuals’ behavior; instead, they react to the overall environment and their own payoff experience. Risk tolerance is high in the cooperative direction: they repeatedly choose the individually dominated, high-contribution action even when it is clearly not reciprocated by the group.

Fairness norms seem group-focused rather than dyadic: they aim for high public good provision, absorbing inequality rather than correcting it. Only near the end do they partially abandon that stance and allow themselves to benefit materially relative to the group.

<REWARD>
This player never uses the reward mechanism despite having multiple opportunities and clear examples of others rewarding cooperators. They are willing to accept net payoff losses from high contribution, but they are not willing to incur the separate, additional personal costs needed to reinforce others via rewards.

Their non-use spans situations where others contribute very highly, where they themselves receive reward, and where reward is used extensively by others. This pattern suggests either that they do not see marginal benefit in spending further to influence behavior, or that they are unfamiliar or uncomfortable with using targeted incentives, or that they view the cost of reward as wasteful even while being generous in contribution.

Because they never reward, they do not appear to use reward strategically for alliance building, reciprocity, or signaling approval. They behave more like a “pure cooperator” in the contribution stage and a “non-participant” in the incentive stage. The fact that they persistently refrain from rewarding, even after receiving reward, suggests that gratitude does not translate into active reciprocity through the mechanism, at least under this cost/benefit structure.

<RESPONSE_TO_REWARDER>
They receive reward in several rounds from at least some group members. Despite this, they never respond by rewarding those individuals back or by otherwise engaging in targeted reciprocal behavior. They continue their own contribution pattern largely independent of who rewards them. When their contributions remain high, it is because they already choose to be a full cooperator, not because reward changes their action.

They therefore do not build explicit alliances or coalitions with rewarders. If they feel gratitude, it does not manifest in observable, strategic reciprocity within the reward stage. Their behavior suggests that they interpret reward, at most, as a welcome bonus or as confirmation of their cooperative identity, not as a cue to engage in tit-for-tat or partner selection. They do not differentiate between rewarders and non-rewarders in any detectable way.

Overall, their response to being rewarded is passive: they accept it but do not change their own incentive use, and only very late do they change contribution in ways that are not clearly linked to reward patterns. There is no evidence of targeted revenge or reward cycles, so alliance-building and direct reciprocity are weak or absent in their type.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
This player closely observes an environment where others’ payoffs and reward costs vary dramatically, including episodes of extreme over-reward by some participants and persistent moderate to low contributions by many. Despite seeing some players sacrifice heavily through reward while others free-ride and earn high payoffs, they do not mimic either extreme. They avoid costly reward behavior entirely, and only gradually respond to low contributions and free-riding by adjusting their own giving late in the game.

Their early behavior indicates they initially discount relative payoff disadvantages and continue contributing fully even while others who give less earn more. This suggests a high tolerance for inequality when it arises from differing contribution levels, or a strong internal rule to “do the cooperative thing” regardless of payoffs. Over time, however, repeated exposure to low group contributions and inconsistent pro-social incentives coincides with a shift to self-interested choices, first as a full free-rider and then as a modest contributor. This transition implies learning that others’ outcomes and behaviors are not reliably cooperative, and a resulting willingness to protect their own payoff.

They do not react in a differentiated way to spectacularly large reward costs or windfall payoffs for others; these events do not trigger imitation of reward strategies or special treatment of highly rewarded players. Instead, they seem to treat others’ outcomes as aggregate signals about the group’s cooperativeness rather than opportunities for targeted response. Personality-wise, they appear principled but somewhat detached from active social engineering: initially idealistic about group cooperation, patient with exploitation, and eventually pragmatically self-protective once the environment repeatedly fails to meet their cooperative expectations.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a moderately cooperative, payoff-sensitive conditional contributor with substantial volatility. They sometimes contribute the full endowment, sometimes free‑ride completely, and otherwise hover around low-to-medium contributions. They are clearly not committed to any fixed fairness norm such as always matching the group average or always contributing high. Instead, they appear to explore extremes (full cooperation vs. full free‑riding) and then settle into middling contributions later.

They do not visibly reward or match other players’ contribution levels directly; their contributions do not systematically track who is generous or stingy in the group. They seem more focused on their own payoff opportunities than on enforcing norms. When the environment looks “chaotic” (very high variance in others’ contributions and reward spending), they do not take on a stabilizing role and instead shift between high and low contributions in a way that suggests experimentation and opportunism rather than principled fairness.

Risk tolerance appears moderate: they are willing to fully cooperate or fully free‑ride at different points, but they avoid extreme, consistent sacrifice. They show no perseverance in sustaining high contributions once it is clear that others are not reliably cooperative. Overall, they behave like a self-interested learner who is willing to contribute when it seems compatible with good payoffs but quickly adjusts downward when high contributions do not clearly pay off.

<REWARD>
This player never spends any coins on rewards, despite many others engaging heavily in rewarding and sometimes incurring large costs. Their trigger for rewarding appears effectively absent: they do not pay to reward high contributors, they do not reciprocate direct rewards they receive, and they do not use rewards as a strategic tool to shape others’ behavior.

This strongly suggests that they treat the reward mechanism as individually unprofitable or irrelevant, even though it is cost-neutral at the pairwise level. They seem to ignore potential long‑term benefits of reputation-building through reward and instead focus narrowly on immediate payoffs. There is no evidence that they use “selective rewarding” to encourage specific partners or patterns; they simply opt out of the reward stage entirely.

Given this, their willingness to invest in social capital or indirect reciprocity via rewards is essentially zero. They appear to hold either the belief that others will reward regardless of their own rewarding, or that the reward system is too noisy or costly in practice to bother exploiting.

<RESPONSE_TO_REWARDER>
They receive rewards in multiple rounds from various others, sometimes at nontrivial cost to those others, but they never respond with any reward back to those specific individuals or to the group more generally. Their subsequent contributions do not show an obvious jump that could be interpreted as “gratitude-induced” cooperation after being rewarded; instead, their contributions continue to fluctuate according to their own payoff considerations.

This pattern indicates an absence of direct reciprocity toward identifiable rewarders. They do not appear to form alliances, return favors, or establish “reward clubs.” In terms of social signaling, they accept benefits but give no visible acknowledgment through either extra contributions or outgoing rewards.

Personality-wise (as inferred from behavior), this points toward a predominantly self-regarding stance: they do not internalize rewards as obligations and do not act to maintain reciprocal ties. If anything, they might interpret received rewards as free gains rather than as part of a relational exchange that needs to be honored.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
They observe substantial heterogeneity in others’ outcomes: some players burn large amounts of coins to reward others, some receive big boosts, and some stay quiet and accumulate payoffs. Across all this, the focal player does not react by changing their own reward behavior (which stays at zero throughout). Nor do they consistently reward high contributors or punish low contributors via reduced contributions targeted at particular individuals; their own contributions fluctuate without clear alignment to who is being heavily rewarded or who is sacrificing most.

When others incur large costs to reward or to support certain players, the focal player does not step in to share that cost or to “join the coalition” of rewarders. They do not seem impressed or intimidated by others’ extreme prosociality. Similarly, when some players repeatedly free‑ride or contribute minimally while still getting good payoffs, there is no visible backlash from the focal player in the form of increased contributions to counterbalance, nor any attempt to counter free‑riding through reward strategies.

Overall, they treat the outcome landscape as information mainly about payoff possibilities, not as a moral or relational signal demanding a response. Others’ high costs, large rewards, or losses do not induce them to change their basic pattern of play: opportunistic, moderately cooperative when convenient, unwilling to pay for social enforcement. Their “type” is thus best characterized as a payoff-focused conditional cooperator who ignores the reward institution and does not engage in reciprocity, coalition building, or norm enforcement, despite clear evidence that others are doing so.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a highly self-interested, opportunistic contributor who alternates between free-riding and high contributions with no clear cooperative norm. They sometimes contribute nothing despite many others contributing substantially, indicating a willingness to exploit the public fund when others are generous. They also occasionally contribute the maximum or near-maximum, but this does not establish a stable cooperative pattern; instead, these high contributions appear sporadic and not contingent on clear thresholds of others’ behavior. There is no evidence that they systematically match others’ contributions or try to move the group toward an efficient cooperative equilibrium. They show no clear fairness norm: they are comfortable taking a full free-rider position even when others contribute a lot, and they do not consistently continue high contributions after group cooperation improves. Risk tolerance appears moderate: they sometimes make large contributions that leave them relatively low in that round’s payoff, but they also often revert to low or zero contributions to secure high personal earnings when others carry the public fund.

<REWARD>
They never spend any resources on reward in any observed instance, despite multiple opportunities where some peers incur substantial costs to reward others and where high cooperators are visible. This suggests a strong reluctance to incur any personal cost to shape others’ behavior via positive incentives. They do not use reward strategically, either to encourage high contributors, to reciprocate, or to build coalitions. Their behavior fits a “pure consumer” of the reward environment: willing to accept rewards but never to fund them. This strongly indicates low intrinsic preference for altruistic rewarding and a narrow focus on personal payoff maximization in the reward stage. There is no sign they experiment with even minimal, symbolic rewards; the threshold to spend is effectively infinite for them.

<RESPONSE_TO_REWARDER>
They receive rewards from others on some occasions, but they never reciprocate to those rewarders in later reward stages, nor do they shift their contribution pattern in a way that clearly rewards or supports those individuals. This points to an absence of positive reciprocity toward identifiable benefactors. Their later decisions do not show targeted generosity toward those who previously rewarded them. Socially, they behave as a one-way beneficiary: they accept rewards as windfalls without treating them as the start of an alliance or a relationship. Their type is therefore non-relational in this environment; they do not convert being rewarded into obligations, gratitude signals, or strategic cooperation.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
They observe rich variation in others’ outcomes, including very costly reward behavior by some players and repeated high contributions by others, yet they remain behaviorally detached. Large reward expenditures by some participants, and the substantial payoff sacrifices those players incur, do not trigger any visible response in either their contribution level or their reward decisions. They also witness certain players repeatedly ending rounds with very high or very low payoffs due to their reward activity, but they neither emulate nor support those patterns. Their own strategy appears insensitive to these social signals: they treat others’ costs and payoffs primarily as background information rather than cues for norm enforcement or coordination. This suggests they believe others’ prosocial or extreme behaviors are not worth responding to; they prioritize stable personal gain over engaging with apparent norms, generosity, or attempts at group structuring by others. Overall, they function as an adaptive egoist: attentive enough to exploit a cooperative environment when it suits them, but not motivated to modify their behavior in response to others’ sacrifices or outcomes.
cluster_intro: This cluster groups personas with related strategy patterns around reward, contributions, high, rewards, contribution.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a strict, unwavering full cooperator. They always contribute their entire endowment, with no variation across the game. Their behavior is non-conditional: cooperation does not appear to depend on others’ behavior, even though others also always fully cooperate. They follow a strong efficiency norm: they consistently choose the welfare-maximizing option rather than the individual payoff–maximizing option. There is no evidence of strategic hedging, experimentation, or risk adjustment; they do not test partial defection, even early or late in the game. This pattern is consistent with a stable “principled cooperator” type rather than a conditional or opportunistic cooperator. Fairness seems defined as equal, full contribution by all, which they both experience and maintain. Whether this norm would hold if others defected is unknown.

<COMMUNICATION>
They do not send any chat messages and do not respond to the one visible message from a peer. This indicates a strongly non-communicative or passive communication style in this context. They neither attempt to coordinate, persuade, nor clarify rules socially; instead, they rely entirely on the formal structure of the game. There is no evidence of socio-emotional signaling (no thanks, reassurance, or norm talk). Their silence, despite a smoothly cooperative environment, suggests they see communication as unnecessary for sustaining cooperation here, or they simply prefer to avoid social engagement. Their responsiveness to others’ messages is effectively zero, so their tone and persuasive tendencies remain unknown.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
Their strategy is completely invariant with respect to the game horizon. They maintain full contributions through the final stage without any sign of end-game defection or tapering. This implies either that they ignore or deprioritize standard backward-induction logic, or that they hold a norm-based or rule-based strategy (“always contribute fully”) that overrides end-game incentives. There is no evidence of increased self-interest, experimentation, or last-minute opportunism as the end approaches. Thus, they behave as if the cooperative rule is time-independent. Whether they consciously track the remaining rounds and choose to ignore that information, or simply do not integrate it into their decision rule, is unknown.

<PUNISHMENT>
They never use the punishment mechanism, even though they have ample opportunity and a highly effective punishment technology. Because all players always fully contribute and no one uses punishment, there is no trigger for justified or retaliatory punishment. From this transcript alone, we cannot distinguish whether they refrain from punishing because they are tolerant/forgiving, because they dislike harming others even at a cost-effective rate, or simply because there is no norm violation. Their selectivity and thresholds for punishment are therefore unknown. However, their consistency in not even testing the mechanism suggests a default preference for non-intervention when behavior is cooperative.

<REWARD>
They never use the reward mechanism, despite being in a group of perfectly cooperative peers. This indicates that, at least in this environment, they treat reward as unnecessary or not worth the cost, even when others’ behavior is fully aligned with their own cooperative choice. They do not engage in positive reinforcement or gratitude signaling via the formal reward channel. Possible interpretations include: they take mutual full cooperation as baseline/expected behavior that does not merit extra reward; they focus on maximizing their own payoff given that cooperation is already secure; or they simply ignore auxiliary mechanisms altogether. Their behavior does not reveal whether they would reward in a less cooperative group, so their propensity to use rewards strategically (e.g., to encourage higher contributions) remains unknown.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
They observe that others consistently match their own cooperative behavior and also avoid spending on punishment and reward. Despite this, they never adjust their own strategy; they already behave in the most cooperative way and keep doing so. There is no evidence of emotional or retaliatory reactions: others’ outcomes are always symmetric and favorable, and they do not attempt to alter that symmetry. They do not respond to others’ payoffs with extra reward, nor do they exploit their cooperative partners by defecting, even late in the game. This suggests they interpret alignment of contributions and payoffs as satisfactory and needing no further intervention. Their sensitivity to inequality, exploitation, or norm violations cannot be inferred here because none occur; how they would react to uneven outcomes or visible misuse of punishment/reward is unknown.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a stable, unconditional full cooperator under the given parameters. They always contribute their entire endowment to the public fund, without any experimentation, hedging, or apparent conditionality on others’ behavior. Their strategy is highly consistent and does not change over time, indicating a strong internal norm or fixed rule rather than reactive adjustment. They appear comfortable with the risk that others might free-ride, although in this instance others also fully cooperate, so their beliefs remain untested; their willingness to repeatedly expose themselves to potential exploitation is inferred but unconfirmed (low confidence). They behave as if efficiency and group welfare are the primary objective, and they do not display concerns about relative payoff advantages or fairness imbalances, since they make no effort to exploit or protect themselves against possible deviations by others.

<COMMUNICATION>
They do not send any chat messages. They ignore at least one explicit attempt by another player to engage in discussion about the game setup. This suggests a silent, non-negotiating style: they neither seek to coordinate, nor to persuade, nor to clarify norms verbally. Their cooperation is “action-based” rather than “talk-based.” Motivations for silence are unknown (could be strategic minimalism, disinterest in communication, or external constraints). They also show no observable responsiveness to the content of others’ communication; they simply maintain their existing behavioral pattern.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
They show no end-game shift in behavior. Their contribution pattern is identical early, mid, and late in the game, including the final rounds, despite full knowledge of the remaining number of rounds. There is no decay of cooperation, no final-round defection, and no evidence of strategic horizon-based adjustment. This indicates either a rule-based or norm-based cooperative strategy that is insensitive to the finite-horizon structure, or an absence of opportunistic reasoning about the end of the game.

<PUNISHMENT>
They never use punishment, despite having access to a relatively powerful and efficient punishment technology. This holds even though the group is fully cooperative, so they never face a genuine temptation to sanction free-riders. As a result, their underlying punishment thresholds and motives are unknown. What is observable is a preference to conserve resources and avoid imposing costs when everyone is already cooperating. They do not engage in any gratuitous or exploratory punishment, suggesting an aversion to unnecessary harm or a narrow, instrumental view of punishment (only worth considering if there is actual misbehavior). Whether they would punish defectors in other conditions remains uncertain.

<REWARD>
They never use reward, even though other players fully cooperate throughout. This indicates that they do not pay extra costs to express gratitude, reinforce cooperation, or signal approval when cooperation is already maximal. They appear to treat reward as redundant in an already efficient, fully cooperative equilibrium, rather than as a tool for building or signaling relationships. Their strategy suggests a cost-conscious stance toward positive incentives: as long as others cooperate without needing extra inducement, they keep all remaining payoff rather than spending on symbolic or reinforcing rewards. Whether they would introduce rewards to rescue or encourage cooperation under strain is unknown.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
They consistently observe that others cooperate fully and receive identical payoffs, yet they neither adjust their own contributions nor change their use of punishment or reward. This implies satisfaction or at least acceptance of equal, high-payoff outcomes, with no signs of envy, competitive concerns, or attempts to secure relative advantage. Their behavior is stable and unreactive: seeing that others match their contribution, they neither escalate cooperation (already maximal) nor “thank” others via rewards, nor “discipline” anyone. They treat the current outcome as adequate and do not attempt to fine-tune payoffs. There is no evidence of learning from others’ outcomes because there is no variation to learn from; their internal rule simply persists unchanged.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a perfectly stable, unconditional full cooperator in this environment. They always choose to contribute their entire endowment, with no variation across time and no sensitivity to round number. They do not probe, hedge, or adjust based on others’ behavior; instead, they lock into a maximally cooperative strategy from the start and never deviate. Their behavior aligns with a strong fairness norm: equal, full contributions by all are both expected and enacted. They exhibit high risk tolerance with respect to potential exploitation, but in this specific interaction their expectations are met by others’ matching behavior. There is no evidence of strategic self-interest in the narrow sense (they never attempt to free-ride or test whether cooperation would persist under partial contribution). Instead, they act as if cooperation is both normatively right and instrumentally sufficient, and once that equilibrium is visible they simply maintain it.

<COMMUNICATION>
Their communication is extremely sparse and neutral. They send a single brief message wondering whether the current configuration is “the best setup,” which suggests a low-key, analytic curiosity about the game’s structure or efficiency rather than emotional expression or social bonding. They do not attempt explicit coordination, persuasion, or norm-setting; they neither direct others nor respond to any visible chatter from them (none is present). The tone is matter-of-fact and non-confrontational. Overall, they adopt a highly low-communication, low-engagement style: they participate cooperatively through actions rather than through talk, and they show no drive to use chat for negotiation, praise, or sanctioning.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
There is no observable end-game effect on their strategy. They continue full cooperation unchanged up to and including the final round, with no sign of decay, last-round defection, or strategic anticipation of the game’s termination. Despite being able to see the number of remaining rounds, they do not attempt to capitalize on others’ cooperation near the end or to “cash out” on earlier cooperative norms. This pattern is consistent with either a rule-based cooperative type (who treats the contribution choice as a fixed rule regardless of horizon) or a player who is focused on maintaining a stable cooperative pattern and does not shift to backward induction reasoning in practice.

<PUNISHMENT>
They never use the punishment mechanism, even though it is highly effective in terms of deduction per coin spent. Given that all players contribute fully and no antisocial behavior occurs, there is no obvious behavioral trigger for punishment, so their underlying willingness to punish norm violations remains unknown. What is clear is that they do not engage in punishment for its own sake and do not experiment with it when cooperation is already perfect. This suggests a strictly conditional, if-any, punishment orientation: if they are a punisher at all, they reserve it for actual deviations rather than using it symbolically or preemptively. Their behavior here is consistent with a non-punishing cooperative type in fully cooperative groups.

<REWARD>
They never use the reward system, despite its availability and the fact that others cooperate fully. Because rewards are exactly cost-equal to what they grant, using them would be at best redistributive and at worst wasteful from their own perspective; they avoid this entirely. This indicates that they do not seek to “tip,” reinforce, or express gratitude via material rewards when cooperation is already stable and symmetric. They appear to regard mutual full cooperation as sufficient without needing extra positive incentives. Their approach to reward is therefore minimalist and efficiency-oriented: as long as everyone is already doing what they consider appropriate, they see no reason to spend on reinforcement.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
They consistently observe that others’ contributions, payoffs, and sanctioning behaviors are identical to their own: full contributions, no spending on punishment or reward, and equal earnings. They make no visible behavioral adjustment in response; they simply match the cooperative pattern and maintain it. The single chat remark about whether they have “the best setup” plausibly reflects recognition that the current outcome—complete symmetry, high joint earnings, and no sanction costs—is already very good, perhaps even optimal given the structure. They do not react to others’ outcomes with envy, opportunism, or attempts to differentiate themselves. Instead, they accept equal outcomes and stable cooperation at face value and remain aligned with the group pattern without testing its limits.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a strict high contributor who consistently gives the entire endowment to the public good in every round. Contribution behavior is extremely stable and does not react downward even when partners contribute less. Their pattern reflects a strong internal norm for full cooperation rather than conditional cooperation based on others’ behavior. They tolerate repeated instances of others contributing less without any reduction in their own contribution, indicating low sensitivity to short-term exploitation risk and a willingness to bear that risk to sustain group efficiency. There is no evidence that they strategically shade contributions near the end; they treat all rounds similarly, suggesting either that they do not heavily factor in horizon effects or that they prioritize norm-consistent behavior over end-game optimization. Their fairness standard appears to be that everyone should contribute fully; deviations below full contribution are tolerated in terms of contribution choices (they do not “teach a lesson” by lowering their own contributions) and handled instead via punishment.

<COMMUNICATION>
Unknown. No chat content is provided, so their tone, explicit coordination attempts, and responsiveness in messaging cannot be inferred. Any persuasive or engagement style in communication is unknown.

<PUNISHMENT>
This player is willing to incur real costs to punish perceived under-contributors and does so selectively and repeatedly toward the same partner who contributes less than the others. They never punish when all players contribute equally and highly, and they never punish the consistently high-contributing partner when that partner matches their own contribution. This indicates a clear norm-enforcing use of punishment rather than random or spiteful use. They appear to view contributions below what the other cooperator is giving as deserving of sanctions, even when the low contributor still gives a nontrivial amount; thus their punishment threshold is relatively strict. They occasionally refrain from punishing moderate under-contribution, so their application is not mechanical; their sanctioning seems to cluster around periods when one player is repeatedly below the other two. The pattern aligns more with deterrence and enforcement of a “everyone should give as much as the top contributor” norm than with retaliation for being personally targeted, because they are never punished themselves and have no need to retaliate. Their punishment is targeted at relative free riding and is not used to settle payoff inequalities arising from punishment by others. Overall, they are a motivated but controlled norm enforcer: not punishing every small deviation, but reliably punishing clear and repeated under-contribution.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
This player appears attentive to the alignment between contributions and resulting payoffs. When the group fully cooperates and payoffs are equal and high, they refrain from sanctioning and maintain full contributions, suggesting satisfaction with mutual gains and no desire to alter an efficient, fair pattern. When one player earns relatively high payoffs while contributing less than the other two, the focal player is willing to reduce that player’s payoff via punishment, implying discomfort with payoff advantages earned through lower contribution. They accept personal payoff reductions to redress these perceived imbalances, indicating that their utility incorporates norm enforcement and distributional concerns, not just own-earnings maximization. They do not react against the partner who also spends on punishment toward the low contributor; there is no observed counter-punishment, suggesting that they perceive aligned norm enforcers as legitimate. They never attempt to equalize outcomes when inequality arises solely from punishment decisions that both enforcers made; they seem primarily focused on penalizing the original low contributor rather than compressing all payoff differences. Overall, they respond to others’ outcomes through the lens of contribution-based fairness: high payoffs are acceptable when backed by high contributions, but high payoffs tied to relative free riding trigger costly corrective action.
