text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a stable, unconditional high contributor. They always contribute the maximum available amount in every round, without deviation, regardless of others’ behavior, the presence of a persistent low contributor, or the game stage. Their stated and enacted norm is group-efficiency maximization: they argue that everyone should always contribute everything to maximize the total pot and explicitly say they will keep contributing the maximum “no matter what.” They do not appear to condition their own contribution on others’ cooperation, punishment, or fairness considerations; instead, they treat full contribution as the dominant rule given the multiplier. They show relatively high risk tolerance in the social sense: they keep fully cooperating even when others are talking about defecting, punishing, or end-game betrayal. They prioritize expected value from the mechanism over guarding against exploitation or free-riding.

<COMMUNICATION>
They are highly engaged, sociable, and often playful, mixing serious strategic guidance with humor, pop culture, and light teasing. Early on, they initiate coordination by explaining that the multiplier is very favorable and urging everyone to contribute everything, then reinforce that plan several times. They return to a theme of “maximize the total pot” and “trust exercise,” explicitly discouraging punishment to avoid spiteful dynamics that could hurt group payoffs. They respond to others frequently, participate in meta-discussion about bots vs humans and about the experimenter’s role, and share approximate earnings information when someone asks about conversion rates, indicating attention to the financial incentives. They adopt a relaxed, joking tone (e.g., sports references, music references, playful remarks about a “hivemind”), but underneath that maintain a consistent prosocial message: stay cooperative, ignore provocations, and focus on maximizing income. Their style is inclusive and encouraging rather than confrontational; they do not join in direct attacks on the low contributor and instead reframe the situation around group benefit and self-focus.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
They are clearly aware of the finite horizon and mention the possibility of changed conditions near the end, yet they do not alter their own behavior: they continue to contribute the maximum in the final rounds and express mild surprise that there is not more last-round betrayal. This suggests they know standard end-game logic but still treat full cooperation as the correct strategy and social norm. Rather than exploiting the approaching end, they reinforce group identity (“good work team”) and maintain a cooperative, humorous tone through the conclusion. Their strategy does not decay as the end approaches; if anything, they double down on a narrative of collective success and shared earnings.

<PUNISHMENT>
They never use punishment, not even against a persistent under-contributor who is widely targeted by others. They explicitly advocate against deducting from low contributors, arguing that punishment risks spiteful cycles and reduces the overall pot. Their motive is not leniency per se but efficiency: punishing costs coins and may not reliably change behavior, so it is, in their view, not worth it. They show no inclination toward retaliation or expressive punishment; they do not threaten future punishment, and they do not appear swayed when others proudly report large deductions. Even when low contributions trigger frustration in the group, they remain consistent in discouraging punishment and focusing on their own cooperative behavior and earnings.

<REWARD>
They never actively reward others, despite the environment making that possible and others sometimes using it. They do receive rewards multiple times but do not reciprocate in kind. Their earlier comments about not wanting to reduce the pot via punishment carry over implicitly: rewarding is exactly break-even here (cost equals benefit), so it does not improve efficiency. Their choice not to reward seems economically motivated rather than antisocial: they already get near-maximal outcomes through universal high contributions and see extra transfers as unnecessary. They do express appreciation and solidarity verbally, using chat to reinforce cooperation and group identity instead of spending coins on formal rewards. Overall, they rely on verbal encouragement rather than material incentives to sustain cooperation.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a strong, almost unconditional high contributor. They consistently give the maximum possible amount in nearly every round and only deviate once, briefly lowering their contribution to a moderate level despite a strong group norm of full contribution. That single deviation looks more like a momentary probe or slip than a sustained strategy: they quickly revert to full contributions even as one other player persists in under-contributing. They appear to value the high-multiplier logic of the game and buy into the cooperative norm, continuing to contribute fully even after expressing frustration toward the persistent free rider. They do not retaliate by lowering their own contributions against the free rider, instead separating contribution decisions from punishment decisions. They tolerate some exploitation: they keep contributing fully despite a known, repeated defector in the group, suggesting a norm-driven or outcome-maximizing orientation rather than purely reciprocal play. They are willing to sacrifice private payoff for both group earnings and for norm enforcement, indicating relatively high risk tolerance and willingness to accept inefficiency at the margin when it supports their moral or emotional goals.

<COMMUNICATION>
Their tone is informal, humorous, and socially engaged. Early on they align with the cooperative mood, affirming the all-in plan and participating in light banter about whether others are “real” or bots. They joke about “bankrupting the researcher,” indicating they understand and endorse the collective payoff logic and enjoy the shared mission framing. As the free rider’s behavior persists, their language becomes more openly hostile and retributive toward that player; they explicitly state an intention to dedicate their income to harming the free rider, which signals strong emotional investment in fairness and norm compliance. They also engage in playful side comments with other highly cooperative players, reinforcing in-group cohesion and a sense of shared identity (“no rugrats”, joking with the consistently cooperative chicken). Near the end, they express appreciation to the group and mark the final round as an “honor,” emphasizing a pro-social, group-bonding orientation despite negativity toward the one deviant. They respond to others’ informational messages (e.g., exchange about the points-to-money rate) and then incorporate that into their strategic talk about how much they can “spare” for punishment, indicating they read the chat carefully and integrate it into their reasoning. Overall, they are socially attuned, expressive, and willing to voice strong opinions, especially about fairness and punishment.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
They are explicitly aware of the game horizon and call out the final round clearly, but they do not use the end game to defect. Instead, they maintain full contributions through to the last round, including when everyone is aware that no future punishment is possible. They do not engage in last-minute exploitation, nor do they escalate punishment at the very end; they neither “cash out” by withholding contributions nor use their remaining coins to lash out. Their final-round chat emphasizes social closure and shared experience rather than payoff manipulation. This pattern suggests they treat cooperation as a stable norm rather than a temporary tactic, and they do not appear to reason in a strictly backward-induction way. End-game awareness affects their communication more than their strategy: it prompts a farewell and group-bonding message rather than a change in contribution or sanctioning behavior.

<PUNISHMENT>
They are clearly willing to punish and show a high intensity of norm-enforcement when sufficiently provoked. Initially they abstain from any punishment even when one player under-contributes; they watch group discussion and do nothing, suggesting a baseline reluctance to use costly sanctions or a wait-and-see stance. After multiple rounds of free riding by the same individual, they shift sharply: they begin to punish that specific player at a relatively large scale, explicitly framing this as a personal campaign and expressing a desire to use much of their income to harm that player. The punishment is highly targeted—only the chronic free rider is ever punished by them, and they do not punish anyone else, even when others discuss using sanctions. This indicates strong selectivity: sanctions are reserved for repeated, salient norm violations rather than minor deviations. Their language shows a mix of deterrence and emotional retaliation motives: they talk as if they want to “destroy” the free rider, but they also endorse the idea of using punishment to push the free rider toward higher contributions. When other players argue that punishment is inefficient and suggest ignoring the deviant, they do not argue back extensively but they do not fully abandon punishment either. They appear comfortable sacrificing a nontrivial amount of their own earnings when a fairness line has been crossed, though they do later pause in heavy punishment and even skip punishing in some subsequent opportunities, suggesting their emotional intensity is somewhat episodic and can be tempered by group discussion and the sense that punishment may be futile.

<REWARD>
They never actively spend their own resources on rewards, despite repeatedly benefiting from others’ anonymous rewards. Early on, they join in the verbal celebration of mutual all-in behavior but translate that approval only into continued high contributions, not into formal reward allocations. When others propose rewarding good behavior, they do not follow, even though they clearly value and appreciate the cooperative group. This pattern suggests they treat rewards as unnecessary when cooperation is already high, or as less compelling than punishment in shaping behavior. Their expressed willingness to sacrifice income is directed toward punishing defectors rather than boosting cooperators. They do enjoy recognition and social bonding and they verbally praise the group near the end, but they reserve costly actions for negative enforcement rather than positive reinforcement. In short, they are a strong cooperator and vocal supporter of the group, but a pure punisher rather than a rewarder.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a steadfast full cooperator. They always contribute the entire endowment and never deviate, even when others free‑ride or when one player repeatedly undercontributes. Their behavior is stable rather than reactive: they do not reduce their own contribution in response to exploitation, social conflict, or punishment dynamics. They appear to be guided by a simple, principled rule—maximize the group pot by always contributing the maximum—rather than by short‑term self‑interest or conditional reciprocity. They tolerate substantial inequality in net payoffs as long as the public good is maximized, suggesting low concern for immediate fairness compared to efficiency. There is no evidence of risk aversion about being exploited; instead they accept that risk as part of their cooperative strategy.

<COMMUNICATION>
They are relatively quiet but not absent from the chat. Early on they affirm the all‑in cooperative strategy clearly and repeatedly, signaling alignment with high cooperation and group coordination. For most of the game they do not engage in arguments about punishment or meta‑discussion about the experiment; they let others debate and continue playing cooperatively. Their tone is generally light and informal; they are willing to joke and use mild, playful insults directed at the undercontributor only after repeated norm violations. Even then, the tone suggests group banter more than deep hostility. They are responsive to group context: they echo consensus positions (support for all‑in, group irritation with the free‑rider) rather than trying to lead or reframe the group. They do not use chat to threaten sanctions or to bargain; instead, their communication mainly signals loyalty to the cooperative norm and shared group sentiment.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
They show full horizon awareness (they comment on “last round”) but do not change their behavior as the end approaches. Contributions remain maximal through the final rounds, including the very last one, and they do not engage in last‑round defection or opportunistic exploitation. Their end‑game strategy is identical to their mid‑game strategy: keep contributing fully and ignore the temptation to withhold. There is no visible attempt to cash out, hedge, or punish harder near the end; they maintain the same non‑punishing, fully cooperative stance. This indicates that their cooperation is not expectation‑based on future rewards or fear of future punishment, but rather rule‑based or intrinsically motivated: they continue to play “correctly” even when instrumental incentives to cooperate are weakest.

<PUNISHMENT>
They never spend any coins on punishment despite having multiple clear opportunities and strong social license from others to punish a salient free‑rider. They also do not escalate punishment after the free‑rider repeatedly undercontributes and others openly retaliate. Even when they verbally criticize the undercontributor and join in the group’s mockery, they still refuse to translate that disapproval into costly sanctions. This dissociation between talk and costly action suggests a reluctance to waste resources on punishment, whether out of efficiency concerns (not wanting to reduce their own earnings) or out of a general aversion to harming others, even norm‑breakers. They are not a moralistic punisher or an enforcer; they rely on their own unchanging cooperation and let others handle any sanctioning. Their stance is consistent and not conditional on round number or group mood.

<REWARD>
They never use the reward mechanism either, even though they are embedded in a highly cooperative group and personally benefit from others’ full contributions. They depend on others’ generosity but do not pay to reinforce it. This suggests they do not view costly positive incentives as necessary or cost‑effective when cooperation is already high; they appear to trust that verbal norms and the obvious payoff structure are enough to sustain cooperation. Their refusal to reward even in the final round, when future interactions are impossible and signaling is purely expressive, indicates either a strong preference for conserving their own coins or a belief that the marginal benefit of rewarding is negligible. Overall, they adopt a “pure contributor, non‑sanctioning” profile: they invest maximally in the public good but stay entirely out of formal reward and punishment systems, leaving those levers to others.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a mixed cooperator with pronounced volatility and evident conditionality. They switch several times between full contribution and full free-riding rather than picking a stable pattern. Early on, they publicly align with “all in” norms in chat but do not always follow through, indicating a gap between stated intentions and actual contributions. They do not appear driven by a strict fairness rule such as “match the group average” or “only contribute if everyone does”; instead, they sometimes contribute even when multiple others free-ride and sometimes free-ride when many invest. This suggests they experiment and react to the overall climate but are not rigidly principled.

They show relatively high tolerance for personal risk in cooperative directions: they frequently invest everything in the public fund even after seeing that some group members systematically contribute nothing. However, they also occasionally exploit cooperative clusters by contributing zero while many others contribute fully, implying that self-interest is salient and occasionally overrides their cooperative impulses. Their pattern resembles a “conditional cooperator with opportunistic streaks”—they are willing to help grow the pie, but they are not reliably altruistic nor strictly reciprocity-based.

<COMMUNICATION>
The player’s communication is brief, affiliative, and coordination-oriented. They use short, upbeat signals that endorse full contribution and mirror the cooperative language of others. This suggests they value being seen as part of the cooperative coalition and care about appearing aligned with group norms. They do not initiate complex persuasion, arguments, or moralizing; instead, they echo and reinforce the prevailing cooperative call.

They do not confront or criticize defectors in chat, nor do they engage with expressions of anger or moral condemnation by others. Their communication style is low-conflict and low-intensity: they join the “we should all cooperate” chorus but avoid debates. They appear more comfortable with simple, inclusive messages than with pushing specific enforcement strategies or calling out hypocrisy, even when their own actions diverge from their cooperative words.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
The player is aware of the finite horizon, but they do not markedly reduce cooperation toward the end. Their contributions remain high or even solidify in the final stages, with several full contributions late in the game despite decaying trust and visible frustration from others. They do not clearly switch to pure free-riding when the remaining number of rounds shrinks.

This pattern indicates that the player does not strongly implement backward-induction logic. Their end-game behavior is closer to “stick with some cooperation if others still seem willing” rather than “exploit in the last rounds.” Even after other players express resignation and disappointment about greed and failed coordination, this player continues to put all their round endowment into the public fund at times, suggesting a persistent or identity-based cooperative tendency that does not fully collapse with the horizon.

<REWARD>
The player uses the reward mechanism frequently and at non-trivial personal cost, especially in the earlier and middle stages. They sometimes spend a large fraction of their payoff to give rewards, which indicates a strong willingness to engage in positive reinforcement. They also receive considerable reward amounts in some cooperative rounds, suggesting others perceive them as part of the cooperative core at least at those moments.

Their reward use appears more prosocial than strategic in the narrow payoff-maximizing sense: they reward even when it meaningfully reduces their own earnings. The pattern aligns with a desire to sustain or encourage high contributions, but without fine-grained targeting visible in this transcript (who exactly they reward is unknown). There is no evidence that they condition rewards tightly on specific individuals’ recent behavior versus on a broad notion of “reward the cooperators.” Over time, they reduce or stop spending on rewards in some later rounds, which may reflect learning about the limited effectiveness of rewards in stabilizing the group, increasing self-interest as the game progresses, or simple fatigue with subsidizing others.

Overall, they are a willing but not fully consistent rewarder: early generous, later more restrained. Their use of rewards fits a cooperative-enforcement role more than a purely self-interested one, albeit with some adjustment when that enforcement does not seem to produce stable cooperation.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
The player plainly observes others’ contribution and payoff patterns but does not verbally comment on specific individuals’ costs or rewards. There is no explicit evidence of them tracking particular players’ histories or publicly reacting to who is spending heavily on rewards versus who is free-riding. Their behavioral adaptations, however, suggest they respond to aggregate patterns: they tend to contribute more in periods where many others are investing and reduce contributions in periods where defection or chaos is more salient.

They appear sensitive to the social mood signaled through chat and outcomes—participating more cooperatively when there is visible collective momentum and some reward activity, and backing off when it becomes apparent that a subset of players consistently exploits the group. Still, their reactions are not strictly tit-for-tat: they sometimes continue to contribute fully while several others free-ride, and they do not systematically withdraw cooperation in direct proportion to observed defection.

They also do not use the chat to shame or praise specific players based on outcome patterns, which suggests that while they notice the environment, they prefer quiet behavioral adjustment and occasional rewarding over verbal enforcement. Overall, they show moderate responsiveness to others’ outcomes at the group level but low explicit, individual-level accountability or commentary.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a calculated conditional cooperator–defector mix, oscillating between full contribution and full free-riding rather than settling into a stable pattern. They never choose intermediate amounts, suggesting they treat the decision as a binary strategic choice rather than fine-tuning.

They sometimes fully invest even when many others have not done so in the recent past, indicating at least some willingness to “test” or sustain cooperation rather than strictly following immediate payoff-maximizing defection. At other times, they clearly exploit cooperative environments by taking the endowment while others give. This mix shows a moderate tolerance for risk: they are willing to contribute fully into imperfectly cooperative groups, but also comfortable switching to pure self-interest when that seems advantageous.

There is no clear evidence they follow a simple rule like “match the majority” or “reward cooperators and defectors symmetrically via their own actions.” Instead, their contributions are volatile and appear driven by short-term expectations about returns rather than a strong fairness norm. They do not consistently punish low contributors through their own defection, nor do they consistently reward high contributors by always contributing when others do; they sometimes free-ride even when cooperation is high.

Overall, they prioritize personal earnings, but they are not a pure free-rider: they sporadically invest fully, especially when cooperation seems relatively high or being reestablished, and they are willing to forego some private gain for the public fund in those moments. Fairness norms, if present, are weak or secondary to payoff considerations. Altruistic motivation is present but inconsistent and easily displaced by opportunistic defection.

<COMMUNICATION>
The player does not send any chat messages. They exhibit a pure observer/quiet style in communication: they read others’ coordination attempts and moral appeals but never reply or initiate. This implies low explicit engagement in norm-setting and no overt persuasion attempts.

Despite being silent, their choices respond somewhat to the overall cooperative climate, so they likely attend to the chat and contribution patterns. Their lack of verbal coordination signals a preference for remaining unidentifiable and unaccountable in discussions, which is consistent with opportunistic strategy shifts: they can adapt behavior without having committed verbally to any group norm.

Because they never speak, there is no evidence of tone (friendly, hostile, moralistic, etc.) from chat content. Any underlying attitudes about “greed,” “fairness,” or “rationality” remain unknown. They also never confront or support particular individuals socially; their social style is best characterized as disengaged and instrumentally silent.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
The player shows awareness of the finite horizon, as the game interface makes remaining rounds visible, but their behavior does not show a clear, sharp end-game collapse that deviates qualitatively from earlier volatility. They continue to alternate between contribution and defection late in the game as they did earlier, and they end by defecting while many others contribute, which is consistent both with standard end-game defection and with their general opportunistic tendencies.

There is no visible attempt to “repair” group cooperation near the end, nor any final-round generosity. The last decision is profit-oriented and exploits others’ continued cooperation. This suggests that, by the final stage, they prioritize maximizing final payoffs over sustaining any cooperative norm.

Because they never comment on the approaching end, their explicit beliefs about backward induction or “last round, so don’t give” logic are unknown. Still, their willingness to defect in the final period when others largely cooperate is consistent with standard end-game reasoning in PGGs combined with their ongoing opportunistic streak.

<REWARD>
The player uses the reward mechanism actively but selectively. They sometimes spend nontrivial amounts on reward and sometimes spend nothing. This shows that they are willing to incur personal costs to influence others, not purely to maximize immediate payoff.

Their reward spending tends to occur in periods where they themselves are cooperating, suggesting that they use reward more as reinforcement for a cooperative phase than as a free-standing strategy. When they defect, they generally refrain from rewarding, indicating that they do not try to buy goodwill or stabilize cooperation while personally free-riding.

Who they reward is not identifiable from the summary data, so their specific targeting criteria (e.g., high contributors, consistent cooperators, those who reward others) are unknown. However, the fact that they ever choose to spend on reward in a setting where rewards are anonymous implies an interest in shaping group behavior rather than seeking reciprocal credit. They likely hope that generous behavior gets reinforced at a group level, even if they cannot claim individual credit.

Their reward behavior is not extreme or constant; they are not a “reward fanatic.” Instead, they use it intermittently and at moderate cost, suggesting a conditional willingness to pay for influence when cooperation seems worth supporting. When cooperation appears unstable, they seem to revert to self-protection: they neither contribute nor reward, relying on others to finance the public good.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
The player can see others’ payoffs and reward expenditures, but there is no direct verbal reaction from them: they never comment on “parasites,” “greed,” or “bots,” even as other players do. This silence makes their emotional reactions unknown, but their behavioral adjustments provide some information.

They sometimes contribute fully after periods when some players have defected and others have sacrificed payoffs to reward cooperators, suggesting they are responsive—at least mildly—to emerging cooperative clusters and to evidence that some participants are willing to support prosocial norms. At other times, they free-ride on exactly such cooperative and rewarding behavior, taking advantage of high contributions and active rewarders by keeping their own endowment.

They do not mirror the extreme behaviors of others (e.g., very high reward spending or consistent hard-line defection), instead occupying a middle ground: opportunistic but occasionally supportive. They do not visibly retaliate against low contributors via their own reward decisions (e.g., no costly counter-reward or obvious non-reward campaigns are inferable) and they exhibit no clear “teaching” pattern such as suddenly withholding cooperation right after observing severe free-riding.

In summary, the player monitors others’ actions and outcomes enough to adjust strategy, but they do so quietly and pragmatically rather than normatively. They are influenced by the evolving payoff landscape, shifting between contributing, defecting, and rewarding in ways that seem aimed at benefiting when group cooperation is high while avoiding losses when it appears fragile or exploited. Their underlying beliefs about fairness, deservingness, or blame are not directly observable beyond this opportunistic, mildly conditional pattern.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a mixed-strategy, opportunistic cooperator with clear willingness to free‑ride when it is individually profitable and low social pressure, but also willingness to fully cooperate under visible group norms. They only ever choose extreme actions (all or nothing), never intermediate contributions, and alternate between them multiple times, suggesting they treat the decision as a simple “invest vs. keep” choice rather than fine‑tuned optimization.

They repeatedly join “all in” waves once group members vocally coordinate and most others appear to invest. When many others contribute and returns to contribution are high and salient, they fully contribute. When others begin to defect more, they oscillate but still sometimes go all in again, indicating they are not a pure unconditional defector nor a pure conditional cooperator.

They demonstrate tolerance for short‑term payoff loss relative to strict selfish best response when group cooperation is salient and socially coordinated, but also show readiness to exploit cooperative others when the environment allows, accepting the social label of “parasite” or “greedy” with no visible behavioral correction. Their risk tolerance appears moderate: they are willing to invest in collective cooperation when success probability seems high, but do not insist on cooperation when others clearly defect.

Overall, they fit a “playful, somewhat cynical conditional cooperator/free‑rider hybrid”: they adjust contributions to the social climate and perceived payoff structure, rather than following a fixed moral or efficiency norm.

<COMMUNICATION>
They engage in brief, somewhat playful and ironic chat, with low effort at persuasion or leadership. They acknowledge others, offer short confirmations, and occasionally inject light humor or meta‑comments. They do not explicitly shame defectors or argue for a norm of contribution, and they do not defend their own free‑riding when others complain; they largely ignore moralizing statements.

Their communication shows awareness of group dynamics (referencing coordination slogans, reacting to others’ arithmetic joke, and making a late, somewhat cynical remark about the participant pool). They respond minimally when directly implicated (e.g., when someone wonders if an avatar is a bot, they give a terse confirmation of being present rather than engaging in a longer justification). This suggests a socially aware but low‑investment, somewhat detached interaction style: they are present, but not deeply invested in repairing or building norms through talk.

They follow the conversational themes others start (e.g., “all in” consensus, joking answers), rather than initiating strategic coordination themselves. Their tone is casual, lightly sarcastic, and not hostile. Overall, they communicate as an observing participant who enjoys the social banter but avoids emotional confrontation or sustained persuasion.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
They remain willing to fully contribute even in the final rounds, despite the finite horizon and declining cooperative sentiment voiced by others. They do not pivot to a last‑minute exploitation strategy; instead, they continue to join high‑contribution patterns when others appear likely to do so. They also show explicit awareness of the experimental context and participant pool late in the game, indicating horizon and meta‑awareness, but that awareness does not push them into pure end‑game defection.

This pattern suggests they do not strictly implement backward induction. Their end‑game response is shaped more by immediate social cues (others’ apparent willingness to keep contributing) and possibly a mild preference for maintaining a cooperative or playful identity, rather than maximizing the final‑round private payoff at all costs. End‑game behavior therefore continues the same mixed, socially responsive strategy rather than shifting sharply.

<REWARD>
They almost never spend on reward, and when they do, they spend minimally and without establishing a clear pattern of targeted reinforcement. There is no evidence they systematically reward high contributors, nor that they use rewards to punish (by omission) or to strategically steer behavior. They are a near‑non‑user of the reward mechanism.

They do, however, accept rewards from others without apparent reciprocal behavior, indicating they are comfortable benefiting from the incentive system while rarely contributing to it. This absence of reciprocal rewarding reinforces an image of a player who does not invest in institution‑building or norm‑enforcement, even when mechanisms exist.

Their limited reward usage suggests that their main levers are direct contributions and playful communication, not incentive engineering. They are unlikely to pay personal costs purely to thank or encourage others, even when the reward technology is mildly efficient.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
They display awareness that others’ contributions and reward spending affect outcomes, but their behavioral adjustments center on contribution decisions, not on mirroring reward or punishing through non‑reward. They see participants who contribute a lot or spend heavily on reward; there is no sign of them responding with extra generosity, solidarity, or retaliation. They neither publicly praise nor criticize specific payoff profiles.

When others voice frustration with “parasites” or “greed,” the player does not shift into more altruistic patterns in direct response. Instead, they maintain their own mixed contribution strategy and keep ignoring the reward tool. This indicates insensitivity to moral appeals based on outcome fairness, or at least a decision not to publicly acknowledge or behaviorally accommodate those appeals.

Overall, they register others’ outcomes and commentary but treat them more as background context than as binding social obligations. They update enough to occasionally rejoin cooperation waves, but not enough to participate in active norm enforcement or outcome‑based reciprocity.
cluster_intro: This cluster groups personas with related strategy patterns around reward, cooperation, contribution, free, contributions.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a strict, unconditional full cooperator. They always invest their entire endowment into the public fund and never deviate, regardless of past group behavior, free-riding levels, or the remaining number of rounds. Their cooperation is stable and not visibly contingent on others’ contributions, even when many others free-ride and group payoffs drop. This suggests either a strong internal norm for contributing fully, or a deliberate choice to maximize group efficiency even at clear personal cost. They do not show evidence of experimenting with defection or partial contribution, nor of conditioning their contributions on specific individuals’ histories; instead, they adhere to a fixed cooperative rule. Their risk tolerance for exploitation is high: they keep cooperating in situations where many others are demonstrably not doing so, indicating either a principled or rule-following approach rather than a payoff-maximizing or tit-for-tat style. Their fairness norm seems to be “everyone should fully contribute,” but they enforce this norm only indirectly, via positive reinforcement rather than by changing their own contribution.

<COMMUNICATION>
They never send any chat messages. They do not propose strategies, react verbally to others’ comments, or attempt to coordinate. This indicates a fully silent engagement style: they observe and act but do not participate in social signaling or persuasion. It is unknown whether they read chat actively or ignore it. They do not attempt to shame defectors or praise cooperators in text; any norm enforcement they perform is entirely through their reward behavior. Their tone and responsiveness in communication are therefore unknown; what can be inferred is a preference (or constraint) for non-verbal, action-based expression.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
They maintain full cooperation and continue to spend on rewards through the final rounds, with no visible end-game defection or withdrawal. They do not reduce their contributions or obviously change their reward strategy as the game approaches its last rounds, even when others comment on the diminishing sense of donating near the end. This suggests they either discount the end-game incentive to defect, follow a fixed cooperative rule independent of horizon, or prioritize maintaining a cooperative pattern over exploiting the final period. There is no evidence of strategic tapering, last-round opportunism, or “we tried, now give up” behavior in their own actions; if they are aware of the horizon, they do not let it undermine their cooperative stance.

<REWARD>
They are an active and sometimes heavy user of the reward mechanism. They spend on rewards in many rounds, occasionally at substantial personal cost. They do not reward in a purely self-serving way: they both receive and give rewards, and their reward expenditure sometimes clearly lowers their own payoff relative to non-rewarding cooperators. This indicates a willingness to incur real cost to support or encourage others.

Their rewards are selective, not random. They do not reward every cooperator each time, and they sometimes choose not to reward even when many others contribute fully. Their reward use appears to serve as a positive reinforcement tool: they are more engaged in rewarding when cooperation levels are high or improving, and they sometimes intensify reward spending after periods of mixed behavior, consistent with trying to stabilize or encourage high cooperation. They do not use reward as a substitute for punishment against defectors; instead, they focus on acknowledging or supporting those who contribute or who are aligned with cooperative norms. Because individual reward targets are not identifiable in the transcript, their exact targeting criteria are unknown, but the pattern of repeated use, including in late rounds, is consistent with them valuing norm reinforcement, reciprocity of kindness, or “thanking” cooperators, even when it is not strictly payoff-maximizing.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
They see detailed information about everyone’s contributions, payoffs, and reward activity, and their choices show that they are responsive to this information through reward spending but not through changes in contribution. When many others contribute fully and the group’s outcome is strong, they are willing to allocate some of their surplus to reward, even though they could keep those coins. When the group performs poorly, they usually maintain contribution but may reduce or withhold rewards, indicating some sensitivity to overall group behavior when deciding whether to spend additional resources.

They do not visibly retaliate against high-earners or free-riders through their own actions; they lack punishment tools and do not switch to defection, so their reaction to defectors’ high payoffs remains purely behavioral-silent. They do not reduce their own contribution in response to opportunists, which suggests that others’ high selfish payoffs do not cause them to abandon their cooperative rule. Instead, their main behavioral channel for responding to others’ outcomes is deciding whether to spend on rewards that redistribute some payoff toward those they see as deserving. Their emotional stance is not verbalized, but behaviorally they act as a robust, positive norm supporter who tries to bolster cooperation via selective rewards rather than by withdrawing from the public good. Overall, they appear to interpret outcome information primarily as input for whom to support, not as a cue to change their own cooperative baseline.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a strongly cooperative, near “always‑contribute” type with one brief deviation. They repeatedly choose the fully cooperative action even when many others free‑ride, indicating that they value group efficiency and are willing to accept personal risk and exploitation to preserve high public returns. Their pattern shows high stability: they almost always invest fully, with a single mid‑game free‑ride that aligns with a temporary collapse in group contributions. This deviation appears reactive rather than a permanent shift, as they promptly return to full contributions once the group’s cooperation rebounds. They do not appear to condition their contributions tightly on individual others’ past behavior; instead, they respond more to the overall state of group cooperation. They tolerate unfairness to a notable degree, continuing to cooperate despite persistent free‑riding by some peers, and they do not “punish” defectors through their own contribution decisions. Risk tolerance is high: they repeatedly invest all despite uncertainty and despite evidence that some others are exploiting the system. Overall, they fit a “stubborn cooperator with one exploratory defection” profile.

<COMMUNICATION>
The player does not send any chat messages. They ignore ongoing coordination attempts, emotional commentary, and informal social tests in the chat. This silence suggests a low‑engagement or observational communication style, not necessarily antisocial but clearly non‑verbal and non‑persuasive. They neither try to motivate others nor join in shaming or praising; any influence they exert is purely through their economic decisions. Their lack of visible reaction to the sometimes moralizing or frustrated tone of others implies emotional restraint or at least non‑expression. They are willing to let others debate norms while they quietly implement their own cooperative and rewarding strategy.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
The player shows clear awareness of the finite horizon (it is common knowledge), but there is no evidence of classic end‑game unraveling in their behavior. They maintain or even reaffirm full contributions through the final rounds, including the very last one, despite others openly questioning the value of continued cooperation near the end. Rather than decaying their cooperation as the game closes, they remain aligned with a norm of contributing, suggesting that their strategy is not purely backward‑induction driven. Their reward behavior also does not collapse at the end; they continue to incur nontrivial reward costs in the final round. This pattern is consistent with a type that prioritizes sustaining cooperative norms and rewarding pro‑social behavior even when there is little or no future to “recoup” investment. Horizon effects on strategy are therefore minimal; if anything, the player doubles down on their cooperative identity near the end.

<REWARD>
This player is a frequent and relatively heavy user of the reward mechanism. They are repeatedly willing to spend noticeable amounts of their own payoff to transfer benefits to others, and they do so both early and late in the game. Their rewards do not appear random: they tend to reward in contexts where cooperation is high or recovering, and they also do reward themselves when possible, indicating they are not purely altruistic. The pattern suggests they use reward in two strategic ways: (1) to reinforce or sustain cooperative norms by positively recognizing contributors, and (2) to supplement their own payoff when others choose to reward them. They do not systematically “bribe” low contributors into contributing; instead, they mostly support environments where cooperation is already occurring or where cooperative peers are identifiable. Their willingness to spend on rewards remains substantial even when many others stop rewarding, implying intrinsic approval of reciprocity and norm‑support rather than pure payoff maximization. This points to a conditional altruist with some self‑regarding pragmatism: they are prepared to lose coins to support pro‑social patterns, but they are not indifferent to their own material outcome.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
The player is sensitive to collective outcomes, as seen by their brief withdrawal of contributions when group cooperation collapses and payoffs for contributors become relatively poor. However, their long‑run behavior shows that they are more committed to cooperative norms than to strict reciprocity with any one individual. They do not visibly retaliate through reward behavior against high earners who free‑ride; instead, they simply become less generous in that short low‑cooperation phase, then return to supporting cooperative states. They are willing to reward even when their own relative payoff is not outstanding, indicating that they evaluate others based on contribution and perceived group benefit rather than sheer income levels. Their continued cooperation after observing that some non‑contributors earn more suggests that they either discount these “parasites” as noise, or accept some exploitation as the cost of maintaining a cooperative environment for the majority. Overall, they respond to outcomes by cautiously adjusting intensity (briefly withholding contribution and/or rewards), but ultimately revert to a principled cooperative and rewarding stance rather than adopting sustained defection.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a mostly high contributor with occasional, strategically-timed free riding. They begin by contributing fully and openly endorse full cooperation, and they repeatedly return to full contributions even after others defect. This suggests they accept the group-efficiency logic of contributing in a high-multiplier environment and are willing to act on it.

Their pattern alternates between full cooperation and full defection rather than using intermediate or gradually adjusting levels (which are not available here anyway, but their switching is still coarse rather than nuanced). When they defect, they do so in rounds where partial group breakdown is already visible, and at least once after having just experienced that everyone can and will cooperate. This indicates they understand the temptation to grab a larger private payoff when others are contributing and are willing to exploit it at times.

They are not a pure altruist or pure free rider; instead, they behave like a conditional cooperator with selfish lapses: they support high-contribution norms, but they occasionally defect even when such norms are viable. They do not appear to condition contributions finely on specific individuals’ past actions; their shifts align more with broad group mood and recent cooperation levels than with any individual’s history. Risk tolerance seems moderate: they are willing to contribute fully even after some defection has appeared, but they also hedge by defecting when coordination looks fragile. Fairness norms appear present but weakly enforced by their own behavior, given that they sometimes free ride on contributors they have verbally encouraged.

<COMMUNICATION>
They communicate briefly, in a positive and coordination-oriented tone. They explicitly endorse the “all in” cooperative strategy and use short rallying messages aimed at encouraging group investment. Their language is simple and cooperative rather than accusatory or moralizing; they do not call out specific defectors, complain, or shame others. They engage with the group’s cooperative narrative (e.g., echoing the logic that everyone gains from contribution) but do not engage in detailed argument or negotiation.

They respond to the ongoing chat dynamic: they join others’ calls for full contribution, reaffirm their own choice, and later mirror a playful math answer, showing attention to the chat context rather than ignoring it. They do not initiate complex discussion about strategy changes when cooperation starts to break down, nor do they confront free riders directly. Their style is low-drama, encouraging, and socially affiliative, but not deeply involved or highly persuasive. They appear more interested in signaling alignment with cooperation than in actively managing or enforcing it.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
They show awareness of the horizon but do not strongly deteriorate their cooperation near the end. After having alternated between contributing and not contributing in the middle rounds, they resume and maintain full contributions in the final rounds, even when others comment that cooperation now makes “little sense.” This suggests that they do not adopt a purely backward-induction logic of “defect at the end because future punishment/reward is gone.”

Their end-game behavior is more consistent with a player who wants to preserve or reassert a cooperative identity or norm even when it is no longer strictly payoff-maximizing. They neither explicitly reference the number of remaining rounds nor openly change strategy in anticipation of the game ending. Any end-game adjustment they make is subtle and leans toward renewed cooperation rather than a final exploitation push. Overall, horizon effects exist but are weak; they do not fully unravel their cooperative stance as the game closes.

<REWARD>
They never spend any coins to reward others, despite having multiple opportunities and seeing others do so. This shows a clear reluctance to incur personal costs to reinforce cooperation, even when they themselves benefit from the cooperative environment. Their stance on reward is purely passive: they accept rewards directed toward them but do not reciprocate or reward others in turn.

This non-use of reward is not paired with any justification or discussion, so the motive is uncertain. It is consistent with several possible interpretations: a payoff-maximizing reluctance to sacrifice earnings, an expectation that the group will sustain cooperation without extra incentives, or simple inattention or low engagement with the reward mechanism. Given that they clearly understand and verbally endorse the collective benefit of contribution, the most direct inference is that they conceptually support cooperation but prefer not to pay to enforce or encourage it. There is no evidence that they use or view rewarding as a strategic tool to shape others’ behavior; they treat it as a feature to ignore.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
They see detailed information about others’ contributions, rewards, and payoffs, but they never comment on specific individuals’ earnings, reward spending, or free-riding behavior. They do not publicly praise heavy contributors or heavy rewarders, nor do they condemn defectors or “parasites,” even when others do. Their chat contributions remain upbeat and generic rather than reactive to particular outcome patterns.

Their own contribution choices do, however, respond in aggregate to the level of group cooperation. They continue to cooperate when many others are contributing and occasionally defect when cooperation is more mixed or when some have shown persistent defection. This implies that they are paying attention to group-level outcomes, but they internalize this as a private adjustment in strategy rather than as social commentary or sanctioning.

They also do not change their reward behavior in response to seeing others spend heavily on rewards; they remain non-rewarding throughout. They accept receiving rewards without visible expression of gratitude or attempt at reciprocity. Overall, they are outcome-aware but socially quiet in their reactions, adjusting their own contributions while leaving mutual monitoring and norm enforcement to others.
cluster_intro: This cluster groups personas with related strategy patterns around reward, cooperation, contribution, free, contributions.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a predominantly self-interested free-rider with one brief, non-sustained cooperative deviation. Their default is to take the entire private endowment and contribute nothing, even when they publicly endorse full investment and when most others are cooperating. This pattern is stable across almost all rounds, indicating a deliberate strategy rather than confusion.

They show no evidence of conditional cooperation: others’ high or low contributions do not systematically change their own choice, aside from a single instance of contributing fully that they do not repeat. That single contribution occurs in a context where overall cooperation has already eroded and does not lead to any lasting shift. The move appears either experimental, reactive to group pressure, or momentary, not a change in underlying preference.

They tolerate substantial inequity in their favor: they are willing to benefit repeatedly from others’ contributions without reciprocating, despite being fully aware that universal contribution would raise group payoffs. Risk tolerance regarding trust in others’ cooperation seems low; they consistently choose the individually safe payoff of non-contribution. Their behavior is consistent with a payoff-maximizing, low-trust defector who may occasionally test the waters but quickly reverts to free-riding when cooperation seems unstable or when they do not expect universal adherence to “all in.”

<COMMUNICATION>
They are sparing but pointed in chat. Early on, they verbally align with the cooperative norm, explicitly affirming an “all in” stance along with others. This is at odds with their actual contributions, suggesting either strategic misrepresentation (cheap-talk cooperation while defecting) or a willingness to say what the group expects while not following through.

Later, they make a moralized remark about disliking free-riders, even though they themselves are behaving as one. This creates a strong hypocrisy signal: they rhetorically condemn the very behavior they enact. This could indicate self-justification, projection, or a desire to deflect blame from themselves within the group narrative.

They do not respond directly to criticism directed at “bunny” / “rabbit,” nor do they defend or explain their behavior. Their style is thus low-engagement and non-confrontational in the face of social disapproval; they neither argue nor correct others. They use normative language (e.g., condemning “parasites”) but do not invest effort in sustained coordination, persuasion, or repair of group norms. Overall, their communication is minimal, sometimes misleading relative to their actions, and they avoid back-and-forth when the group starts to single out their type of play.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
They show no clear end-game escalation of defection because they are already defecting from near the start. Their contribution pattern does not become more generous as the end approaches, and they do not engage in last-round reciprocity or symbolic fairness gestures. Even when others express resignation and frustration about greed and failed cooperation late in the game, they maintain non-contribution.

Their awareness of the horizon is implied but not behaviorally distinct: they do not appear to change tactics when rounds are nearly over. The one cooperative deviation occurs in the mid-game rather than as a final-round act. Overall, they behave as if the game is effectively one-shot from the beginning, not as if future interaction or reputation within the session will significantly alter their payoff-maximizing calculus.

<REWARD>
They never spend any coins on rewarding others, despite having multiple opportunities and despite many group members using rewards to support cooperators. Even when others reward them on at least a couple of occasions, they do not reciprocate. This shows no observable inclination toward gratitude signaling, reputation-building via reward, or strategic reinforcement of high contributors.

Given the relatively favorable reward technology (slightly socially efficient), their strict non-use points to a strong preference for keeping private payoff over investing in group-level incentives. They do not use reward instrumentally (e.g., to encourage everyone to go “all in”), nor do they selectively reward those who cooperate or who reward others. Their type thus involves ignoring the reward channel altogether, behaving as if such second-order cooperation mechanisms are not worth the personal cost.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
They receive rewards despite being a consistent free-rider, which means at least some players misidentify or indiscriminately reward them. There is no behavioral sign that these positive outcomes change their own behavior: they do not start contributing more after being rewarded, nor do they “pay it forward” via rewards. This suggests that external positive reinforcement, as implemented here, does not shift their underlying strategy.

They also witness other players repeatedly sacrificing payoff to reward cooperators, and later, some cooperators suffering lower payoffs when others defect or spend heavily on rewards. They do not react by adjusting their own contributions to stabilize the cooperative cluster; instead, they continue to exploit the system-level contributions of others.

Their reaction to social information is expressed mainly in chat through a moralizing statement about disliking free-riders. However, this does not translate into alignment with those who are visibly bearing costs for the group. They are aware of who cooperates and who spends on rewards but remain unmoved in their own actions. Their type is best characterized as: cognitively aware of outcomes and norms, sensitive enough to talk about “parasites,” but behaviorally committed to a self-serving, low-cost strategy regardless of the social and payoff landscape.
cluster_intro: This cluster groups personas with related strategy patterns around reward, cooperation, contribution, free, contributions.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a mixed-type, outcome-sensitive contributor who alternates between free-riding and full cooperation rather than following a stable pattern. They only ever choose the two extremes offered (all or nothing) and switch several times over the game. Their behavior suggests they track how much others are putting in and adjust accordingly: when others’ cooperation is high and socially reinforced, they are willing to contribute everything; when there are salient free-riders or when coordination looks fragile, they withdraw to zero and take the high private payoff. They do not appear to hold a strict fairness norm (“I always give if others give”), since they free-ride even in periods where most others are contributing. Their willingness to return to full contributions after previously free-riding indicates some openness to cooperative norms, but this is conditional and unstable. Overall, they balance self-interest and group interest in a pragmatic, opportunistic way, rather than following a principled cooperative or purely selfish strategy.

<COMMUNICATION>
Their communication is sparse, reactive, and lightly humorous rather than directive. Early on, they express confusion or misalignment about whether they have “invested it all,” which indicates attention to the norm of full contribution and some desire not to appear as a defector. Later, they briefly affirm that they are contributing in line with others without expanding on it, suggesting they accept the group’s cooperative frame without trying to lead. At another point they join in a side conversation about which avatars might be bots, making a short, playful remark that targets likely non-cooperators; this shows awareness of the social and reputational dynamics but not a strong moral stance. They do not initiate persuasion, do not scold defectors, and do not try to coordinate specific strategies. Overall, they engage lightly and socially, but avoid argument or leadership, keeping their comments low-key and non-confrontational.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
This player is aware of the finite horizon (the remaining rounds are visible) but does not show a straightforward “end-game defection” pattern. Instead, they end with full contributions in the last two rounds, even as some others complain about greed and as at least one player comments that donating now “makes little sense.” This suggests that their willingness to cooperate is not purely backward-induction based. They seem influenced by the fact that many others are again contributing fully toward the end: when broad group cooperation re-emerges, they align with it despite the short remaining horizon. There is no evidence of them explicitly referencing the number of rounds or changing their strategy purely due to proximity to the end; their behavior is more responsive to others’ current actions than to the abstract end-game logic.

<REWARD>
They never spend on rewards at any point. This is consistent across both cooperative and free-riding phases. Their abstention from rewarding persists even when they personally benefit from others’ rewards and when many others are clearly rewarding high contributors. This suggests either a strong reluctance to incur any cost for social enforcement, a belief that rewards are not worth the cost in this environment, or a preference to let others bear the cost of norm enforcement. There is no indication of strategic reward use to shape future behavior or to reciprocate those who reward them. Overall, they are a pure non-rewarder: they rely on the public good mechanism and on others’ enforcement, but do not actively reinforce cooperation themselves.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
They appear to monitor others’ contributions and, indirectly, how the group’s behavior affects payoffs, but there is no sign that they systematically track or respond to who spends on rewards or who earns more or less. They never comment on specific players’ payoffs, nor on the costs others bear to reward. Their brief remark about possible bots implicitly targets players who are not contributing in line with the group, but it is framed as casual speculation, not as a moral reaction to unequal outcomes. They do not adjust their reward behavior in response to being rewarded, nor do they openly praise or condemn big spenders on rewards or chronic free-riders. Their primary adaptation seems to be at the aggregate level: they notice when the group is broadly cooperative or not and shift their own contribution patterns accordingly, without visible emotional or normative commentary on individual outcomes.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a mostly high-contribution, somewhat erratic conditional cooperator with occasional free-riding. After an initial defection, they shift quickly toward frequent full contributions and maintain that for most of the game, even when others do not consistently reciprocate. They are willing to invest fully into the public fund when there is at least some social pressure or precedent for cooperation, and they do not appear to systematically match others’ contribution levels. Instead, they often keep contributing fully even when average contributions fall, suggesting a relatively high tolerance for being “used” by partial defectors, or at least a willingness to prioritize group efficiency over strict payoff maximization in many rounds.  

Their pattern includes a couple of clear free-riding choices embedded within a majority of full-contribution decisions, indicating that they are neither a pure altruist nor a strict egoist. The free-riding choices do not obviously align with a clear trigger (e.g., no visible punishment or explicit retaliation), so their use of defection seems exploratory or opportunistic rather than strongly rule-based. They do not show an obvious strategy of punishing low contributors via their own defection, because they continue contributing fully in multiple situations where some others free-ride. Fairness concerns are not strongly expressed in behavior: they do not systematically reduce contributions in response to others’ low contributions, and they accept payoff losses relative to free-riders. Risk tolerance is moderate to high—contributing fully in a large group with mixed behavior exposes them to coordination risk, but they keep doing so for most of the game.

<COMMUNICATION>
The player is almost entirely silent in chat, engaging only once with a very minimal, task-irrelevant message that simply answers a trivial question posed by another player. They do not initiate coordination, persuasion, or appeals to norms. They also do not respond to direct social criticism, speculation about bots, or moralizing comments about greed and parasites. This suggests a strongly passive communication style: they monitor the chat but avoid using it for strategy formation, norm enforcement, or reputation management.  

Their single message is neutral and playful rather than strategic, indicating no visible attempt to signal reliability, align with cooperative players, or shame defectors. They are effectively a “quiet observer” socially, despite being behaviorally engaged through their contributions and early rewards. Their avoidance of dialogue even when directly mentioned (others speculate about them being a bot) suggests low concern for social impression within the game context, or a preference to keep social and strategic dimensions separate. Overall, they cooperate (often) without using language to build or defend cooperation.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
The player does not exhibit a classic end-game collapse in cooperation. On the contrary, they keep contributing fully through the last rounds. They are aware of the horizon (the interface shows remaining rounds), but there is no behavioral sign that they strategically reduce contributions as the end approaches. Toward the end they remain a full contributor even as others express resignation or frustration about greed and failed coordination.  

There is no visible shift toward more self-interested behavior in the final rounds: they do not start free-riding more, and they do not strip away rewards to maximize final payoffs (they have already largely abandoned rewarding earlier). This pattern is consistent with a relatively stable cooperative inclination that is only weakly sensitive to end-game logic, or with a simple rule like “just contribute” rather than forward-looking payoff optimization. Their minimal communication at the end also suggests they do not try to leverage end-game rounds for last-minute coordination or signaling.

<REWARD>
The player is willing to spend on rewards early, then stops rewarding entirely for the rest of the game. Initially they invest a nontrivial amount of their income to reward others, despite already having chosen to defect in that same early stage. This reveals two things: they understand and use the reward mechanism, and they are willing to incur personal cost to influence or acknowledge others’ behavior. Because rewarders are anonymous in the mechanism, their spending cannot credibly build personal reputation; this implies their early rewards are not obviously self-branding but rather aimed at supporting cooperation in general or expressing approval toward high contributors.  

After these initial uses, they completely cease rewarding, even in later rounds when many players contribute fully or when some appear to “come back” to cooperation. This discontinuation may indicate disappointment in the stability of cooperation, learning that rewarding has little discernible effect on group behavior, or a recalibration toward conserving payoffs. There is no later resurgence of reward aimed at late-round cooperators. Overall, they are a short-lived rewarder: they test or employ prosocial incentives early, then pragmatically abandon them when returns (in terms of group behavior) appear limited or unclear.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
The player pays attention to outcomes enough to adjust at least once (they move from initial defection to frequent cooperation and briefly invest in rewards). However, their subsequent behavior suggests that their response to others’ outcomes is weakly conditional and not strongly retaliatory or reciprocal. They do not visibly track which specific peers earn high payoffs via free-riding versus cooperation, and they do not tailor their own contributions or rewards in a way that clearly discriminates among them once the early reward phase ends.  

When some peers are repeatedly labeled “parasites” or “greedy” by others in chat, this player does not echo those judgments behaviorally via defection or reduced generosity toward the group. They also do not compensate “victims” of free-riding with targeted rewards. Instead, they keep using a relatively coarse strategy: usually full contributions, no further rewards, and no obvious calibration to the detailed pattern of who is spending heavily on rewards versus who is saving. Their silence in chat when others complain about outcomes and their continued willingness to contribute in mixed groups suggest they internalize outcome information enough to adjust reward usage but not enough to adopt a complex contingent strategy; they appear to accept outcome inequality without visibly reacting to it through punishment analogues (defection) or selective rewarding.

text:
<CONTRIBUTION>
This player is a high-earning free-rider with intermittent cooperation. They choose the non-cooperative option in roughly half the rounds, especially when many others are contributing and the public fund is already high. They also periodically switch to full contribution, including in the final rounds, but this pattern does not stabilize into consistent cooperation. Their contributions do not track any simple rule like “always reciprocate high group contributions” or “always follow the apparent majority”; instead, they alternate between exploiting cooperative environments and joining them.

They accept strong inequality in their own favor when they free-ride: they repeatedly take the full private endowment while still benefiting from others’ high contributions, and they do not attempt to offset this via rewards. They seem comfortable with “being the parasite” that another player complains about, showing no observable corrective response.

Their intermittent full contributions appear compatible with two possibilities: (a) occasional experiments with cooperation to see if others maintain it, or (b) some internal norm that they sometimes honor but are willing to violate when the gains from free-riding are large. Because they never comment in chat, there is no explicit articulation of fairness or reciprocity norms; any such norm is at best weakly implemented.

They display risk tolerance in the sense that they contribute fully even in some rounds where many defectors are present, accepting a risk of low payoff from cooperation. However, across the game, their pattern yields high earnings, suggesting that payoff maximization is a dominant motive and that the cooperative moves are not driven by strong altruism.

<COMMUNICATION>
They never send chat messages. They also never respond verbally to others’ attempts at coordination, moral appeals, or social pressure. This indicates a strongly silent, non-engaging communication style: they rely entirely on action rather than talk, and they appear indifferent to conversational norms of greeting, explanation, or justification.

Because they do not speak, they make no visible attempts to persuade, shame, or encourage others. They neither defend their free-riding nor endorse cooperative norms. This suggests a preference for anonymity and non-confrontation at the communication level, even while their behavioral choices are socially provocative (exploiting cooperators).

Their silence may be strategic: by never speaking, they avoid being singled out or morally targeted, especially since rewarders are unidentified. It may also reflect low interest in the social dimension of the task and a focus on individual payoff rather than group cohesion.

<RESPONSE_TO_END_GAME>
They show awareness of the game horizon (the number of rounds is known), but they do not display the classic end-game collapse into pure defection. In the final rounds they continue to contribute fully in some cases rather than switching to a strict non-contribution strategy.

Their final-round behavior is consistent with either: (a) indifference to horizon effects and simple continuation of their mixed strategy, or (b) a mild inclination to “exit” on a cooperative note without sacrificing earlier gains. There is no clear pattern of escalating selfishness near the end; instead, the same alternation between cooperation and free-riding persists.

They show no sign of changing behavior in response to others’ explicit end-game comments about greed or failed cooperation; their contribution in the last round is cooperative despite these complaints, but they do not follow up with any verbal response or rewards, indicating limited concern with repairing relationships or reputations when the game concludes.

<REWARD>
They never spend any coins to reward others, despite frequent opportunities and repeated observation that other players do reward cooperators. This holds both when they themselves have cooperated and when they have free-ridden; in all cases, they refrain from using the reward mechanism.

This consistent non-use suggests that, for them, the small positive return from rewards is not worth the cost, or that they do not prioritize shaping others’ behavior via incentives. They show no sign of gratitude signaling: even when they benefit heavily from others’ contributions and from an overall cooperative environment, they do not reciprocate with rewards.

Their refusal to reward persists even when most reward activity clearly targets high contributors and cooperative behavior. They remain a pure second-order free-rider with respect to the reward system: they benefit from the cooperation that other players try to sustain through rewards but contribute nothing to that institutional maintenance.

<RESPONSE_TO_OTHERS_OUTCOME>
They observe detailed outcome information each round, including who contributed, how much reward was spent, who received it, and resulting payoffs. Nonetheless, they show no overt behavioral reaction to specific others’ outcomes through either chat or rewards.

Their contribution pattern is not tightly coupled to whether cooperators are being rewarded or whether defectors are profiting. They sometimes cooperate in strongly cooperative, high-reward environments and sometimes free-ride on them; they also sometimes cooperate when defectors are doing well. This indicates that they do not strongly condition on others’ current outcomes in a norm-enforcing way (e.g., “cooperate only if cooperators are doing well relative to defectors”).

They do not appear to punish success indirectly by withholding cooperation from “winners” or by adjusting to those who overspend on rewards; they simply maintain their own alternating strategy. They also show no visible concern for players who burn many coins on rewards and end up with lower payoffs, nor do they “reward the rewarders.” Overall, their behavior suggests low emotional or normative responsiveness to others’ fortunes and a primary focus on their own payoff trajectory.
